story:
What is "The Produce Section"?

"The Produce Section" is an award-winning, HipHop (Higher Inner Peace Helping Other People), eco-conscious curriculum, produced by 2013 Denver Westword Mastermind award-winner Dj Cavem Moetavation, featuring collaborative works with artists that work in the sustainability and health field. This curriculum introduces healthy plant-based recipes, the six steps to community organizing and leadership, green job development, urban organic farming, holistic health care, and "The Produce Section" serves as a continuation of the Going Green Living Bling curriculum, taught to youth and families around health, quality food access, and HipHop. 

Straight out the garden, fresh beats, and 2014 Grammy Music Educator Award Nominee, Ietef "Dj Cavem" Vita is an O.G. (Organic Gardener), educator, emcee,  Dj, b-boy, urban calligraphy guru, mid-wife, vegan chef, and producer. Ietef Vita, aka Dj Cavem (Comminicating Awareness Victoriously Educating the Masses) was born on the East Side of Denver, CO, in the Historic Five Points community, a booming jazz mecca in 1930-1960. In the 1980's and 90's, this area became the site of violent crimes with a strong gang presence. Ietef lived his most formative years during the latter and made the decision to have a positive future sparked by a visit to Africa. Upon his return to America, he began studying the art of break dancing under the L.O.F (lords of Finesse) crew and the R.F.R (Raw Foods Rockas).


OUR STUDENTS DID THIS VIDEO IN OUR CLASS. CHECK IT OUT ...


He has lectured at the Denver, San Francisco, and Chicago Green Festivals, the Sustainability Summit at the Denver Convention Center, Ted Talk, University of Wyoming, Goergetown University, CU Boulder, Powershift, International Association of Culinary Professionals, Makerere University in Uganda, and in classrooms at Metro State College and University of Colorado, Denver. He has also put together panels for the Green Festival and the 2010 Biennial of The Americas hosted in Denver. 

His internationally recorded sixth album, The Produce Section, has been recently featured in Oprah Magazine, and has also been presented in hisTED TALK in 2013 and 2014 exhibition.  Our Campaign, The Produce Section, a curriculum, is a worldwide project launching in Denver, aiming to provide inner-city schools with the curriculum supported by our results-driven interactive workshops, and gardening programs.  We want schools to not only implement the award-winning curriculum through our interactive, results driven workshops, but also help fund and activate indoor and outdoor gardens with schools and their communities on a larger scale. Our goal is to address the health epidemic, food access crises, and advocate green jobs development, food production and localization using this curriculum. Planting the seeds (with the youth) is the key to a fruitful future, and we are taking it upon ourselves to provide the youth and community with the education and tools necessary around these issues. Your contribution is vital in making this happen. 


The Problem

THE STRUGGLE TO FEED OUR FAMILIES. The ability to access high quality, fresh food in low income and communities of color is a major issue. The lack of access and nutritional education has created a health epidemic in these communities. A new Canadian Study recently conducted shows "There was a 20% higher risk of diabetes in the lowest 2 income groups compared with the highest group, which translated into an extra 2500 diagnoses of diabetes for that year," senior author of the research, Lorraine Lipscombe, MD, from the University of Toronto, Ontario, told Medscape Medical News.

TOXIC FARMING AND LONG DISTANCE FOOD TRANSPORTATION. Food travels an average of 1,500 miles from farm to fridge by ship, plane and truck. Pesticides leak into the soil, water, and our bodies. Industrial agriculture leads to unhealthy soil and loss of wildlife. If we localize food production and distribution on a community level, we can easily solve this problem. 

CORPORATE DOMINATION. Corporate concentration causes small businesses to struggle. Consumers feel disempowered to make change. Lets empower our communities by creating entrepreneurial opportunities around holistic health, food production, and green jobs. 

LACK OF EDUCATION. The leading unhealthy corporate heads spend billions per year marketing their unhealthy products to young children and families. Most families are simply unaware of the vicious cycle of low quality food and health, and further more, what to do to change that. Education is the key to providing communities to spark change. 

How do we get the inner city youth and families on board with creating healthier, greener, sustainable communities?


THE PRODUCE SECTION is a tool that can change that

The Produce Section is a HipHop album and curriculum that bridges the gap of inner-generational dialogue around alternative medicines and food security. In order to spark the conversation with the future (the youth) an interest has to be created, and it has to be relevant. The curriculum was designed to teach young people the importance of a localized food system, what it means to live in a food desert and how to sustain themselves in one. Some of the activities include hands on healthy cooking and juicing demonstrations, film, hip hop yoga, urban gardening, introduction to Aquaponics and more. Since its release in 2012, it has been taught at various schools and has reached and impacted over 6,000 youths aged 7 to 24. 


The Need

Our goal is to raise $55,000. The funds will be allocated to the activation and mass production of The Produce Section curriculum on a larger scale. As a part of the curriculum, we will also be launching urban gardening programs and providing supplies (gardening tools, organic seeds, organic compost supplies, Tower Gardens, production of educational printed materials, workshop materials and supplies such as yoga mats, dehydrators, blenders, juicers, and cooking supplies, mobile documenting devices, etc.) as well as providing the interactive workshops in inner-city schools. For your generous contribution, we have partnered with other organizations who support our movement. We have created levels of sponsorships and gifts as a special thank you for your donation. 

The Impact

To spark change, the interest must be created in an informative and relevant way. We want to see schools and their communities with equitable access to good food, has enough to eat, end health disparities in low-income and communities of color, and honor every community's right to culturally relevant, safe, and healthy food. Providing the education as groundwork, and the ability to grow food in these communities is vital. We want to localize food production, reduce energy consumption and the carbon footprint by funding schools and communities with the education and tools to do so.


Other Ways You Can Help

Sound travels. If you are unable to contribute economically, please blast this and create the awareness for this campaign to your friends, family, co-workers, your social media, educators, mayors, artists, and EVERYONE. The more we raise, the more we can do! We sincerely thank you for your time and contribution. Peace.

story:
What is HandsOn Bay Area?

HandsOn Bay Area creates opportunities for people to volunteer, learn and lead in their communities. We strive to provide volunteers with a high-quality experience that fuels further action, and we envision a day when everyone is inspired and equipped to be the change they wish to see in the world.

HandsOn Bay Area works with local nonprofits, schools and parks to identify high-impact, group-based volunteer projects. We recruit volunteers to get the job done and match each project with a trained Project Leader to ensure that both the community partner and the volunteers are satisfied with the work.

Not only do we manage more than 80 direct-service projects a month, we offer educational programming to help volunteers become well-informed community leaders. HandsOn Bay Area's TeamWorks fuses volunteer service projects, community issue education and team-building activities to produce a unique, team-based service learning program. To accommodate busy schedules, we offer our programs on weekends and evenings, and we give volunteers an easy way to sign up for projects, track their service hours and learn about new opportunities through our Project Calendar.

For corporate clients, we offer comprehensive planning services for employee volunteer events through our Hands@Work program. We work with companies to further their corporate social responsibility goals by engaging their employees in hands-on service.

What We Need & How You Can Help

Your contribution helps the LIFT Team put together events in efforts to generate awareness and further HandsOn Bay Area's mission. We appreciate any contribution, big or small. 

Along with increasing community impact, your generous donation supports HOBA's dedication to achieving its many goals, including but not limited to the following:

  • Sponsor a Volunteer or group of Volunteers
  • Sponsor a Project Leader
  • Sponsor a Volunteer Service Project
  • Sponsor a Community Agency
  • Organize signature events, such as Martin Luther King, Jr. Week of Service, 9/11: From Remembrance to Change, and Family Volunteer Day.

The Impact

Our volunteer projects provide more than 65,000 hours of service to more than 200 nonprofits across the Bay Area, meeting critical community needs including education and literacy, HIV/AIDS, health and aging, homelessness and hunger, and the environment. 

In 2009, HandsOn Bay Area hosted over 100 service-learning events, and our Leadership Institute Fellowship Team (LIFT), a year-long immersion into nonprofit management, has graduated over two dozen new community leaders.

Other Ways You Can Help

Your time is a precious donation. If you are unable to provide a financial contribution to our campaign but would still like to be part of our initiative, please email the LIFT Team or find us online to see other ways to give. 

Visit our Project Calendar and learn about the myriad of causes that you can get involved with right away, right here in the Bay Area. Sign up on your own or volunteer with friends and family. 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!

story:
Short Summary

Empowering Young Entertainers host a series of workshops, classes and camps that focus on all aspects of performing arts and the entertainment industry.

Our signature Youth EYE Media Camp gives our youth and young adults the opportunity to learn various aspects of production, writing, acting, casting, hair & make-up, directing, editing and more! 


What We Need & What You Get

EYE Media Camp want young people to see beyond what they see on TV.   Our goal is for low income kids to see/learn various aspects of the TV/Film industry.  

Help give a youth the tools to tell their story.  Sponsor a kid to attend the camp ($150 camp fee).  If we do not reach our entire goal we can still assist in their dreams by giving partial scholarships and reducing  the camp fees!


The Impact

There are so many stories to be told from our youth that doesn't have the platform to tell it.  There are so many dreams they do not know how to obtain.   

Many kids see what's on the screen as their only way for success, when in actuality Empowering Young Entertainers EYE Media Camp want to show how they could use their passion in other areas in the industry and have a fulfilled career!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you  can't contribute, we still need your help! Please share our campaign to your community!  Please use the  Indiegogo campaign sharing tools!

Don't forget to create an Indiegogo account so we know your name for your thank you shout out.

story:
My name is Saki Bernier. I am a College junior by credit hours Fifth year student by time frame (I received a degree in Graphic Arts then changed my major.) I am a Childhood education major at SUNY Cortland, where I am getting one of the best educations I could imagine. I have come across some financial difficulties and am trying my best to save up enough money for my next year at school.

I know what you all might be thinking, "So what, everyone is in school and everyone needs money to pay for it, what makes you so different?" Well I think my case is different. My parents can no longer fund me to go to the school I desire so, I have decided to take matters into my own hands and  truly work for and pay for the education I so desperately want.

Don't think I am only relying on you all to help me reach this goal, I am staying Prayed up!, saving all of my paychecks, applying for scholarship after scholarship,  researching grants and loans while also hoping a spot opens up as a Resident Assistant on campus.

I know everyone is not financially stable, but send prayers my way because I have wanted nothing more in my life, than the opportunity to become an educator. I want to be your future son/daughter/grandchild/niece/nephew's teacher one day I hope you all see the same victory I see for myself in this vision.

My Grandfather always told me "Your education is the one thing no one can ever take from you, remember that." and I will remember that, I will teach that, and I will stand by that for the rest of my life.

God Bless!

story:
Have you ever had a calling in life, but did not know how to go about financially achieving it? It's a tough one! But I have faith. I feel like if I put it out there in the universe, then maybe, just maybe, I can achieve this calling with the financial help of others - even if they don't know me.  

     My calling? - To share the gift of yoga. I would like to attend Sondra Loring and Raghunath's 500 hour teacher training so that I may have the opportunity to offer my gratitude and devotional service through yoga. By helping others soothe the mind, body and spirit, I hope to help them journey through the rediscovery that our self worth radiates from the soul. Sound a little new age-ish? Maybe. But I don't have all the laws of the universe figured out, so until then, I don't discount anything :) 

      I humbly ask your assistance to help me achieve my goal. Many thanks in advance.

     And now...a little humor - and no, I can't bend myself into a pretzel or like a piece of origami!

story:
The USC Neighborhood Academic Initiative (NAI) is a college pipeline program that helps students from Title 1 schools in South Central Los Angeles better prepare for college. Students voluntarily sign up for Saturday school and other educational enrichment activities for 6 years, beginning in the 6th grade. The program has a 100% high school graduation rate and a 99% college entry rate.

For the past few years the Dickens Project has been cultivating the idea of formalizing a partnership with NAI. The pieces have now all finally fallen into place, and both NAI and the Dickens Project are ready to move forward with a new program. With the establishment such a program, the Project would increase its number of annual scholarships, and award them to NAI students who have demonstrated the highest levels of dedication on their journey through English Literature. (See this article in Sunday's L.A. Times for a profile of this year's two scholarship winners!)

We would like to launch the new partnership program with a $10,000 scholarship fund. We have secured matching funding from the Salesforce.com Foundation, so if you help us reach our goal of $5,000, the funding will instantly double.

Thank you in advance for your support of this amazing program.

NOTE: Your donation is indeed tax-deductible, as it will be deposited directly into the coffers of the UC Foundation.

story:
Our cause

Hello! We are people that have been harassed for our support of #GamerGate, a consumer revolt against the lack of transparency in the gaming industry. We have been doxxed and been sent death threats (Screenshots available at the bottom)

Doxxing is the Internet-based practice of researching and publishing personally identifiable information about an individual. It is a form of cyber-bullying that can often affect the targeted person in real life. 

We would like to use these unfortunate events to promote and raise funds for UNICEF. 

Who is UNICEF?

The United Nations Children's Fund is a United Nations Program headquartered in New York City that provides long-term humanitarian and developmental assistance to children and mothers in developing countries. It is one of the members of the United Nations Development Group and its Executive Committee.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNICEF

http://www.unicef.org/about/who/index_introduction.html

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign on social medias! Hashtags: #GamerGate #NotYourShield #Unicef

If you consider purchasing a gift for someone or an item for yourself, please visit: 

http://www.market.unicefusa.org

Profit goes directly to the cause. 

Who we are and proof of our ordeal

story:
Silicon Rally - Road to Innovation

SILICON RALLY:
 + Visit our Web Site

 + Check us on Facebook


PARTNERS:

 + ESCP Europe - Our Business School
 + i7 - Institute of Innovation
 + Lectra - Multi-national company, involved in integrated technology solutions
 + Bouygues Telecom
 + Extra Verso - The smarter cover for your smartphone
 + Motionsquare - Motion graphics+Web+Branding

Hello and THANK YOU for considering helping us! We are 16 young students from different nationalities that have met at ESCP Europe, a French Business School based in Paris. We are currently specializing in Innovation and always had ONE DREAM in common: going to Silicon Valley. 

Here in Europe, especially in the kind of environment we live in, SILICON VALLEY is the Innovation MYTH that everyone wants to understand. We would like to learn from the leading innovators in order to achieve the same success here in Europe, especially in France. 

For us being able to go to California would mean being able to see with our own eyes what many of us have been studying for all their life! We always hear about Google, Facebook, Apple, LinkedIn, Splunk and many others, but we were never able to understand how could a small area of the US be so influential for the rest of the world. Now it is time to answer this question!!

Why do we need your help?

As you know, traveling from Paris to California is quite an hard task, especially when you have to move 16 people to the other side of the globe!!

YOUR HELP IS FUNDAMENTAL TO US TO GET TO CALIFORNIA! (but of course....no pressure!)

In fact 75% of our budget is just for traveling... Once we get there the hard part is (almost)  over! But we can't wait too much! We will have to leave by the end of April, so the clock is ticking ... Can you hear it? (TICTOCTICTOC...)

Thanks to our university we are able to get tickets at a fair price, but the more we wait, the more it is going to cost!! 

We are now looking for a place to stay and we are confident that through contacts and friends, we are going to find a place to sleep (don't worry we wont sleep in the streets....hopefully). 

If we don't reach our goal we have serious doubts that we are going to make it to Silicon Valley, but we are confident that is not going to happen. 


Want to help?



With every donation you will receive this BEAUTIFUL and SUPER INNOVATIVE smartphone cover

                ...Aren't you CURIOUS to know what's the secret of this MAGICAL cover?

Find out what makes this Extra Verso cover so SPECIAL and UNIQUE  --> Extra Verso

Of course the cover is available for ALL kind of smartphones...after the donation we will contact you in order to have better details for the delivery and for the type of smartphone that you have! 

But do NOT forget to....

MAKE NOISE! ;) 

We want to be innovative, we want people to TALK about our project!! 

SHARE our website, our campaign, our FB page and our Twitter profile! 

EVERYTHING HELPS! 


Why us?

We are going to Silicon Valley to study it. To understand it. To breathe it. 

We decided to focus on 4 MAIN TOPICS that are now becoming very influential for the future of people and businesses.

These four topics are: 

  1. BIG DATA: FROM HYPE TO OPERATIONAL REALITY

  2. FASHION & INNOVATION

  3. HOME AUTOMATION

  4. THE FUTURE OF EDUCATION

For each one of these topics, our AIM is to study the recent trends, understand the technology behind them, talk with experts and learn as much as possible from them. We want to make you feel part of our project and it is exactly for this reason that we will SHARE our findings with all the people that will support us!

Market researches, reports, summaries, conversations, conferences... We will try to SHARE as much as we can WITH YOU and we invite you to let us know how you want to be part of our experience.

We HOPE to enable each one of you to become an Innovator, an Inventor, an Entrepreneur, or just to satisfy our same CURIOSITY about Silicon Valley and the magic that happens there everyday.

Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Google Docs are the TOOLS that we are going to use to keep you updated. So do not worry, you will know everything at the same moment we do, because, in the end, YOU ARE THE ONE THAT MADE OUR DREAM COME TRUE!


PLEASE...

....if you have advice, feedback, critics or anything else, just drop us a message! You can find a "contact us" form at the bottom of our website and we welcome any suggestion!

Let us know what you think about the Silicon Rally!!


THANK YOU FOR (may) SUPPORTING US!

story:
Our Program

Teach for Palestine is located in the West Bank city of Nablus (visit us at: tfpnablus.wordpress.com). Inspired by an educational movement after the Second Intifada, our program aims to equip our students with the necessary skills to effectively access and contribute to their country and build a better life for themselves and their families. Our after-school program’s unique approach to English education is unmatched in the region. Our holistic, interactive approach has proven effective in mentoring students and developing fluency.  

Our average student acquires 350 new words and advances slightly more than one grade level in reading each semester. After their initial exposure to our international teachers, our students’ verbal fluency increases exponentially and continues to grow rapidly throughout the program. This also broadens their world view in a very positive way.

Moving beyond the classroom, our communicative and compassionate approach draws out and engages children who have suffered from violence, abuse, and oppression for the better part of their lives.  

We serve in the poorest neighborhoods, the Balata and New Askar refugee camps, and the villages around Nablus. In these areas unemployment is well over 80%. While our main focus is an engaging and safe environment for these students to learn English, we are also able to offer our brightest students scholarships to our partner school, Pioneers Baccalaureate School (www.pioneers.ps).

We are now operating in four community centers in and around Nablus. As we develop, we face numerous challenges due to location and funding. Providing our students and teachers with the necessary resources is not easy. Our hope is that you will help sponsor one of our classrooms.

Salem Village

Mr. Philip is teaching in Salem, a small village to the east of Nablus. Due to the high demand, we currently have five classes running, two beginners, two intermediate and one higher. Classes are mixed and the ages range from 6-14. We meet in the village community centre. 

He is focusing on speaking, writing, reading and listening. He uses a variety of teaching methods and styles to engage the students, including music, games, activities and grouped work. The lower classes are working on basic greetings, vocabulary and phonic knowledge, while the higher groups are tackling comprehension and improving their spoken and written English. Teach for Palestine believes in total immersion classes, where the students learn to explain, express and communicate completely in English. 

The semester has got off to a great start with topics on 'colour,' animals,' 'who are you?' and 'fly away' being covered already. With 'numbers,' 'my family' and 'Salem's got Talent' still to come, it's going to be an exciting couple of months!

We are a small organization and run on a very small budget. In the past, we have been solely funded by prominent leaders in the community. However, this is unsustainable and makes the expansion of our program unlikely. In order to grow our program, we are looking to establish more reliable funding channels.

Our project goal of $500 will cover the cost of classroom resources, including workbooks, paper, pencils, and markers, etc.; as well as, the monthly transportation stipend provided for our volunteer teaches. These resources are the bare minimum of what is needed to create a successful classroom. Our teachers are what make the difference. Our volunteers devote their time and energy to help make their classes engaging and fun with such limited resources.

In the event that we do not reach our goal, we will still use the dedicated funds for classroom resources. Any amount that you can contribute will go towards this classroom, and we thank you in advance for your help!

The Impact

Taking the time to help any child in need is a valuable thing. However, by donating to this campaign you are putting much needed resources in the hands of our capable teachers and students who would not otherwise be able to afford it.

Our students seriously love learning. For some it is a chance to learn in a safe environment, and for others, it is a chance to truly better their own lives. With your one-time donation you will be paving the way for a successful classroom and become part of our students’ lives.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can donate at this time. We would also fully appreciate your help in spreading the word about our program and its mission. By sharing our story with people that you know can help, you are doing us a wonderful service. Cheers!

story:
We are creating a documentary to disseminate the history and teaching of the Enneagram, a modern typology system based on ancient wisdom, that helps improve relationships, life purpose, and society. We are both enthusiasts and students of this system and are both practicing in psychology and spirituality. The Enneagram has the power to develop greater compassion while also cultivating depth and connection with self and other.

Our initial budget is $5,000 which will be used for the director of photography, editor, travel for experts, and distribution. It would be a lot more money, but we have kind friends! The perk for you will be free enneagram assessment and coaching by us for a donation of $25 or more. (Value $150) 

This project has the capacity TO CHANGE OUR SOCIETY BY CONNECTING PEOPLE TO THEMSELVES AND OTHERS MORE DEEPLY, while also cultivating more care for our environment. We have experience with one completed documentary that has gotten 4,000 views so far - and the comments show that the documentary has helped many people. Additionally, the editor has 30 plus years running a successful post-production company.

Help yourself, your relationship, society, and our environment by supporting this film.

story:
My name is Eben Bein and I'm a 27 year old Dartmouth College graduate and a biology teacher at a Revere High School, an urban district just outside of Boston. A small group of my most passionate students are waiting to be made the environmental leaders of their generation. All they need is experience in the field and the guidance of experts. Please help me provide this by funding our trip to Yellowstone National Park with the organization Ecology Project International.

Ecology Project International trip to Yellowstone

This program is designed for high schoolers to get hands on experience collecting and synthesizing field data under the guidance of real field ecologists that are experts in the Yellowstone ecosystems. They will learn about conservation efforts by the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service, help monitor the population of several keystone species (Grey Wolf and Mountain Bluebird) and participate in the rehabilitation of  abandoned farmlands.

I had the good fortune to attend a college that afforded me many field research experiences. Whether studying the hunting habits of ant lions in Costa Rica or the peculiar evolution of local damselfly species, such opportunities opened my eyes the powerful role of science in addressing environmental issues. My students are hungry for such pivotal experiences and I am so excited to oversee this trip and share my love for our biosphere with them.

The Money

This 9 day program is over 2000 miles from our high school and costs ~$2,300/student to cover transportation, food and housing at research stations, and to compensate the experts that will work with us. We are fundraising locally by bake sale, raffle, Valentines delivery, etc and the students' families are working very hard to get their kids this exceptional opportunity. However, the cost is beyond the reach of many of the students and our school system has no extra funds to offer. So we ask you for your help, and will gladly use every penny you can donate.


The Impact

A trip like this provides students with:

  • unparalleled application of the scientific method, particularly as it applies to environmental issues
  • exposure to landscapes and organisms that they have never known and will remember for their entire lives
  • the opportunity for them to soak in each other's passion for environmental issues
  • a unique resume builder that will give them a foot in the door for job and college applications

Other Ways You Can Help

Perhaps you can’t contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help. Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. Feel free to get in touch with me if you have something other than money to offer. Email me at ebein@revere.mec.edu.

Thank you so much for your support!

Yours, gratefully,

~Eben Bein

story:
We are a class of graduate students at Illinois State University that want to spend our Spring Break bringing FREE Shakespeare to inner-city youth in New York City. 

First and Foremost,

Goal #1) Offer three free performances of our 40-minute abridgment of William Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet to inner city youth, followed by a discussion with the students. We have already scheduled performances with three schools: one in the Bronx, one in Harlem and one in Brooklyn. Through our exploration of ‘original practices’ (practices thought to have been used by Shakespeare and his company) our touring abridgments focus on poetry and language. Without a set, costumes or planned blocking, each performance is a completely new experience that is built on the connection with each new audience and each new space. This exciting and engaging type of “guerrilla Shakespeare” is easily accessible for audiences of all ages, regardless of their experience with classical theatre. Our performances work to compliment the literary studies of English classes, helping students find new meaning and connection to classical text. The discussions allow students to ask questions, share their experience, and discuss how theatre can be thought about in new and exciting ways.

Goal #2) Participate in theatre workshops with leading artists in the areas of community-based, site-specific, and experimental theatre—all of whom have interest in civic engagement. Already the Obie award-winning Peculiar Works Project has offered us a workshop!

Goal #3) Experience current, innovative NYC theatre and begin relationships with similar artists that have already met with success in order to most effectively shape the remainder of our studies to prepare us for successful careers that will make a difference in the world. 

We are looking to expand our skills by taking the work outside Illinois as we continue to explore the ways in which theatre can reach new audiences, engage communities, and incite change. We are at the point where testing our skills outside our home community will be a unique and important challenge. 

We hope you will make it possible to share the passion we have for this work with hundreds of children in New York City and support us in our pursuit to become artists that make a powerful, positive difference in our communities.



We have already secured funding for plane fare and free lodging in the city. However, in order to make this project possible with our very limited grad student budgets, we need your help to cover the workshop and incidental expenses that add up very quickly. Our $3,000 goal includes the Peculiar Works workshop, transportation to and from airports and within the city, student rush tickets and incidentals. Every contribution to our effort helps, whether it is $1 or $1,000.  Any donation will help us make the most of this opportunity.

 

Already, our company has completed a successful tour of Shakespeare abridgments to local elementary, middle and high schools. We have created a devised theatre piece based on a “story circle” with ten Jewish and Arab teenagers from Israel. The project was so successful in helping the teenagers immediately relate to each other that the non-profit organizer of the trip, Friends Forever, is insisting that every group that comes to the U.S. participates in a similar workshop. Additionally, we conducted interviews with patients and staff at the Community Cancer Center and performed The Hope Monologues at the unveiling of its 'Wall of Hope,’ which received laudatory recognition from newspapers around the area:

http://www.pantagraph.com/lifestyles/health-med-fit/wall-of-hope-uses-art-to-tell-stories-of-people/article_6885084c-8972-11e3-8848-001a4bcf887a.html

http://stories.illinoisstate.edu/magazine/illinois-state/state-side/student-actors-embody-cancer-patients-hope-monologues/


Other Ways You Can Help

If you prefer to support us via mail-in donation, please make your check payable to “The School of Theatre and Dance” with “MFA Actors” in the memo line, and mail your donation to

Valerie Dambold

Illinois State University 

School of Theatre and Dance

Campus Box 5700

Normal, IL  61790-5700


Even if you cannot contribute one dollar, you can still help! Tell everyone you know about us and what we’re up to! 

Send them to our website: 

www.isftouringcompany.com

or our Facebook page:

www.facebook.com/isftc

Post about us on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram. Right below our video you can easily click to share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter or the social media network of your choice.

Additionally, we conducted interviews with patients and staff at the Community Cancer Center and performed The Hope Monologues at the unveiling of its 'Wall of Hope,’ which received laudatory recognition from newspapers around the area:http://www.pantagraph.com/lifestyles/health-med-fit/wall-of-hope-uses-art-to-tell-stories-of-people/article_6885084c-8972-11e3-8848-001a4bcf887a.htmlhttp://stories.illinoisstate.edu/magazine/illinois-state/state-side/student-actors-embody-cancer-patients-hope-monologues/
Other Ways You Can Help
If you prefer to support us via mail-in donation, please make your check payable to “The School of Theatre and Dance” with “MFA Actors” in the memo line, and mail your donation to
Valerie Dambold
Illinois State University 
School of Theatre and Dance
Campus Box 5700
Normal, IL  61790-5700

Even if you cannot contribute one dollar, you can still help! Tell everyone you know about us and what we’re up to! Send them to our website: www.isftouringcompany.comor our Facebook page:www.facebook.com/isftcPost about us on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram. Right below our video you can easily click to share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter or the social media network of your choice.

story:
Hi,

My name is Christopher and I'm a sophomore at the University of Miami and I was accepted into the Kalu Yala internship program in San Miguel, Panamá.

I'm looking to raise $5,500

This covers:

Food

Housing

Airfare

Tuition

Miscellaneous items (iodine pills for water purification, mosquito net, etc.)

This programs is very important to me. I'll be able to help others abroad and have a lasting impact on q community in need. I also will be conducting research and earning college credit, so it's an integral part in my success at the University of Miami.

Thank you!

Thank you for visiting and checking out my campaign and if you could share it will your friends and loved ones that would be amazing.

story:
/// Para leer una descripción en español, haga clic aqui. ///

Introduction

Medios del Pueblo is an initiative started by two educators from California. We have had the opportunity to teach English Language Development, social science/history, narrative, creative writing and Special Education in U.S. public schools. For several years, we helped run a community center in City Heights, San Diego, with free English classes for adults and after-school tutoring for neighborhood youth. We have also facilitated web and journalism workshops in Honduras and media-making (audio and video) workshops with unions and indigenous communities in southern Mexico. Our hearts are in teaching and facilitating the flow of knowledge from one source to another. We understand the vital role that education, free self-expression and critical analysis play in social change and try to use our skills to support those efforts.

Our aim is to collaborate with organizations, movements and communities in Honduras that are engaging in or are interested in popular education and media production. We plan to provide the technology and facilitate the acquisition of skills needed to make and disseminate media. Community-created media is a powerful conduit for ideas and opinions that are shut out of the dominant discourse. Thus, the process of making media has the potential to be liberating both for the creators as well as for the viewers/listeners. Our goal is to create structures that enable participants to continue making thought-provoking media that reflects community issues and needs regardless of whether we are present. 

What We Need

We are trying to raise $3500 to cover the costs of technology for media-making workshops. In order to conduct the media-making workshops, we need smartphones/devices that can capture high definition video ($150 each x 10 = $1500) and tripods to stabilize the shots ($20 each x 10 = $200). We also need shotgun microphones that will be able to capture quality audio ($30 each x 10 = $300). Participants in workshops will use free video and audio editing software on low-cost laptops ($150 each x 10 = $1500).

Context and Goals

Honduras is a country on the Caribbean Sea in Central America with the highest rate of inequality in the Western Hemisphere. An oligarchy of around 10 Honduran families are owners of 90% of the wealth in the country. They have been able to maintain control through a US-style two-party system that has brutally repressed demands for change even while neighboring Guatemala, El Salvador and Nicaragua experienced significant social uprisings. Police, military and the media collaborate to create a climate of fear that serves to protect the power of the ruling class.

In this context characterized by marked socioeconomic disparities, independent, grassroots sources of media are essential for the empowerment of marginalized sectors of society. If communities are informed, barriers are removed that discourage active participation in struggles for social change.

The act of making media is a multi-step process. Each step in the process, from choosing a topic of interest, to determining the shape of the narrative, to editing the final product, is an opportunity for the creator to exercise agency and to express their personal or their community’s point of view.

Example Workshop

In Copan Ruinas, Honduras, nurses and doctors from the public health center and local clinics give womens' health workshops for midwives and promotor@s de salud (health promoters) in the surrounding Mayan communities. We would assist with these workshops in a support role and facilitate a media-making workshop that complements the content of the popular health education course. Participants would identify community issues that they would like to critically explore through video, audio, photography and creative/expository writing. Examples of community-based media will be provided and participants would gain the technological skills needed to produce their own media. A community screening would be organized by the participants where they can present their work to others and open a dialogue on the given topic(s). If possible, we would like to leave technology in communities so that the work can continue at a minimal expense.

Other Ways You Can Help

Have you already pledged to support this campaign, and want to do more? Can’t make a financial contribution at this time, but you’d like to help out in other ways? There are many ways to help! Help us spread the word by sharing this link to the campaign with your friends and family: www.igg.me/at/Independent-Media-Making-in-Honduras

_____________________________________________________________

En Español

Medios del Pueblo: Producción de medios desde las raíces

Medios del Pueblo es una iniciativa comenzada por dos educadores de California, Adriana y Kyle. Su enfoque es el facilitar flujo de conocimientos y habilidades de una fuente a otra a través de la creatividad, el análisis crítico y la educación participativa y no jerárquica.

Sinopsis

Nuestro objetivo es colaborar con organizaciones, movimientos y comunidades en Honduras que están involucrados o están interesado en la producción de los medios de comunicación y la educación popular. Tenemos la intención de proporcionar la tecnología y facilitar la adquisición de habilidades necesarias para realizar y difundir ideas por los medios de comunicación. En concreto, vamos a traer equipo para la captura y edición de audio y vídeo.

Propósito

Sabemos que los medios de comunicación creados por la comunidad son un conducto de gran alcance para las ideas y opiniones que son excluidas de los discursos predominantes. Los medios de comunicación populares tienen el potencial de ser liberador tanto para los creadores como para los espectadores/oyentes. Nuestro objetivo es crear estructuras auto-suficientes que permiten a los participantes a continuar haciendo los medios de comunicación que reflejan la voz y las necesidades de la comunidad.

Muestra de un taller

Los participantes identifican asuntos de la comunidad que les gustaría explorar críticamente a través de vídeo, audio, fotografía y escritura creativa/informativa. Se proporcionarán ejemplos de medios de comunicación comunitarios y participantes aprenderán  las capacidades tecnológicas necesarias para producir sus propios medios. Una proyección para la comunidad  podría ser organizada por los participantes donde podrán presentar sus trabajos a los demás y abrir un diálogo sobre los temas dados. Si es posible, nos gustaría donar la tecnología a las comunidades para que puedan continuar el trabajo a un costo mínimo.

Fondo

Adriana y Kyle han tenido la oportunidad de enseñar el desarrollo del lenguaje Inglés, ciencias sociales/historia, la narrativa, la escritura creativa y la educación especial en las escuelas públicas de Estados Unidos. Ayudaron a dirigir un centro comunitario en City Heights, San Diego, con clases gratuitas de inglés para adultos y tutoría para los jóvenes del barrio. Adriana y Kyle han facilitado talleres de web y el periodismo en Honduras y talleres de fabricación de medios (audio y video) con los sindicatos y comunidades indígenas en el sur de México.

                                               THE POWER OF A DREAM

TRUE STORIES OF CHANGE IN AFRICA

VISIT US AT:

TWITTER: www.twitter.com/powerofadreamdo

Student Vulcain Yengo Launches Power of a Dream Crowdfunding Campaign...to bring hope to  African...

Yengo hopes crowdfunding will give him the resources to create a documentary  in Congo. Last year he trained over 400 entrepreneurs who launched several businesses in Africa that are thriving and growing today.

..............................................................................................................................................

Yengo grew up in the small town of Brazzaville located close to the river Congo in the Republic of Congo. Yengo's childhood was fraught with hunger and poverty. Though his parents worked hard to take care of their family of 11, the most they could make in any given day was a little under $2. This amount barely allowed for Yengo and his siblings to eat, let alone provide for other necessities.

At the age of 15, Yengo started his first business selling household lamp oil, cloths, and juice on the streets of Brazzaville. Though he worked hard at building his first business in the end it failed because of the continual rise in oil prices and the complexity of the business. Yengo recalls, “I think I had a heart for business, but I did not have a head for business yet.”

Now with his degree in Business Management, Yengo is striving to create a movement behind a new hybrid of African entrepreneurs – change makers with a mind for business. It is Yengo’s belief that entrepreneurship with heart will bring the real freedom that his continent is seeking.

Through his efforts Yengo hopes to inspire and empower a million Africans. He plans to do this through his documentary and by offering hands on training courses in entrepreneurism. Last year Yengo went back to the Republic of Congo to conduct seminars and a pilot program for his entrepreneurship training courses. The results from his seminars and program trained and impacted more than 400 people in different skill set and helped launch several African businesses that are thriving and growing today.

That trip and seeing the impact the training had on many successful Congolese entrepreneurs, he was inspired Yengo to create the "Power of a Dream" documentary. For example, Verone Mankou, is a 25 year old Congolese, who is the first African to create a tablet and a smart phone. “Verone amazed me because he was able to create something for our country that will have a significant impact in business and with fewer resources then most European and U.S. technology companies. He made history, but who knows about him?”

Each entrepreneur Yengo met in Congo had a similar amazing story to tell. He saw how he could be a source of empowerment, hope, and confidence for many more Africans. Yengo wants to capture these stories in his documentary and freely make them available to anybody via the Internet. “I hope by creating The Power of a Dream and having it available to both Africans and the entire world that people will begin to understand that Africans need skills, and not just food and clothing.”

Support Yengo’s dream by supporting his campaign on IndieGoGo.com or participating on his Facebook page. All proceeds go to creation of The Power of a Dream and helping African entrepreneur succeed.

NO COMMENT: I THINK OF AFRICA AS.......

THE GOAL OF THE POWER OF A DREAM DOCUMENTARY IS TO REACH AND EMPOWER 1,000,000 AFRICANS BY THE END OF THE YEAR 2014. YOU CAN READ THE ARTICLE AT THE BEGINNING AT THE TOP. 

One of the most important phase in creating a documentary consist of recording and the editing. As you may have noticed on our chart below, our biggest expense will come from transportation (car rent) within Congo. The plan is to have three teams working, each team will have 15 days to record all the stories of the entrepreneurs that will be assigned to him. We will hire few local journalists (video makers) to help film the stories and provide guidelines about sensitive matters


THE BIDGET: Follow on our blog after the documentary to see how we have used the fund. 

TARGET COUNTRY: REPUBLIC OF CONGO. SEE THE MAP BELOW

TARGET CITY: BRAZZAVILLE. SEE THE MAP BELOW

OUR TEAM WILL COVER THIS FOLLOWING AREA:  MFILOU, MOUNGALI, OUENZE, MAKELEKELE, DIATA


          AMAZING STORIES OF SUCCESS

I was empowered to create the "Power of a Dream" documentary after my trip in Congo last year (2012). For example, Verone Mankou, is a 25 year old Congolese, who is the first African to create a tablet and a smart phone. “Verone amazed me because he was able to create something for our country that will have a significant impact in business and with fewer resources then most European and U.S. technology companies. He made history, but who knows about him?”

Each entrepreneur Yengo met in Congo had a similar amazing story to tell. He saw how he could be a source of empowerment, hope, and confidence for many more Africans. Yengo wants to capture these stories in his documentary and freely make them available to anybody via the Internet. “I hope by creating The Power of a Dream and having it available to both Africans and the entire world that people will begin to understand that Africans need skills, and not just food and clothing.”

The Power of a Dream will be source of empowerment for Africans. Our goal is to publish the documentary at the beginning of next year and empower 1,000,000 Africans by the end of the year 2014. 

If everything is good and perfect in your life, do not underestimate the power of a documentary because there are so many people in African who live below $2 a day because they think they can't achieve anything.

You are the one who will help our team make this happen. This is not a request for donation to provide food to Africans, instead it is a call for your support so we can empower African to get out of poverty using their own brain and skills, and by following the example of other Africans. 

CONTACT US ANY TIME AT: 

powerofadream.documentary@gmail.com

story:
SATURDAY, September 28th! 2-6pm at Veterans Park in White Settlement, Texas

Short Summary 


Each fall, Kale's Kisses finds a cause they are passionate about, assembles a large fundraiser & donates the money to the cause.  

  • We are a family of 7(one in heaven) Eathn, Dorie, Kendall, Dane, Katelyn, Kale (our angel) & Kaleb (our rainbow) We enjoy channeling our free time to continue Kale's legacy, helping others! 
  • This year's fall festival will benefit Project Sloopy: an organization collecting unused  medical supplies and equipment, and presenting them to those in need. Tommy & Kate organized this project in honor of Ana Cru, their daughter, who they lost in February 2013.  In most cases, people on home health often receive far beyond what they need & a shortage of what they do. Most medical supplies end up getting thrown away because it becomes a burden taking up space in crowded homes. There were no charities that would take these supplies, UNTIL NOW! This organization collects those items and gets them to patients who desperately need them. 
  • Helping Project Sloopy means giving to the less fortunate, and those who are desperately in need of medical supplies that would otherwise be wasted. Help us fund their passion and get patients the help they need! 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our location is $130. Supplies and rentals are an additional $100 average per vender.
  • The remaining donations will go directly to Project Sloopy.
  • Our fall festival will help our community get out without obligation of hefty prices. We give and you give what you can

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Monetary donations are not our only needs! Project Sloopy will always take medical supply donations & will also be able to give you supplies at this fundraiser! 
  • We urge you to spread word of the fall festival, visit Kale's Kisses & Project Sloopy on Facebook & Instagram.
story_txt:
SATURDAY, September 28th! 2-6pm at Veterans Park in White Settlement, Texas
Short Summary 




Each fall, Kale's Kisses finds a cause they are passionate about, assembles a large fundraiser & donates the money to the cause.  

We are a family of 7(one in heaven) Eathn, Dorie, Kendall, Dane, Katelyn, Kale (our angel) & Kaleb (our rainbow) We enjoy channeling our free time to continue Kale's legacy, helping others! 
This year's fall festival will benefit Project Sloopy: an organization collecting unused  medical supplies and equipment, and presenting them to those in need. Tommy & Kate organized this project in honor of Ana Cru, their daughter, who they lost in February 2013.  In most cases, people on home health often receive far beyond what they need & a shortage of what they do. Most medical supplies end up getting thrown away because it becomes a burden taking up space in crowded homes. There were no charities that would take these supplies, UNTIL NOW! This organization collects those items and gets them to patients who desperately need them. 
Helping Project Sloopy means giving to the less fortunate, and those who are desperately in need of medical supplies that would otherwise be wasted. Help us fund their passion and get patients the help they need! 

What We Need & What You Get

Our location is $130. Supplies and rentals are an additional $100 average per vender.
The remaining donations will go directly to Project Sloopy.
Our fall festival will help our community get out without obligation of hefty prices. We give and you give what you can

Other Ways You Can Help

Monetary donations are not our only needs! Project Sloopy will always take medical supply donations & will also be able to give you supplies at this fundraiser! 
We urge you to spread word of the fall festival, visit Kale's Kisses & Project Sloopy on Facebook & Instagram.

story:
Short Summary

I've started a video blog project called Special Shades of Color aimed at offering parents of special needs children support, resources and tips via video blogs. The birth of Special Shades of Color has been so important to me because my 11-year-old son CJ has a dual diagnosis of Down syndrome and autism. We need your help! I have set up a fundraiser to spread the word about my project and website as well as raise funds to increase the number of families we help. 

What We Need & What You Get

I have set a personal goal of raising $1500. 
  • $10 - Personal Thank You Email
  • $25 - Donor Recognition
  • $100 - Donor Recognition + Personal Thank You Video
  • $500 - Sponsor Recognition
  • $750+ - Grant Named in Your Honor

The Impact

Your contribution will make the difference! We will be able to:

  • Distribute our blogs to more families and more special needs organizations.
  • Finalize our non-profit status and provide families with small grants for therapy, communication devices, mobility equipment and so much more!
  • Connect families with more resources, tools and support in raising their special needs child.
  • Develop webinars and online trainings for special needs families.
  • Continue our work in providing video blogs to help families, educators, and the general public understand the life of special needs families.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute monetarily, there are still ways you can help! Please:

  • Spread the word and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share on Facebook, Twitter and more!

story:
Our campaign is described in a few paragraphs below the image for a quick, easy and fun read.

We need your help to release THE WISHAPHANTS and their power from the crystal ball so they can be visible to children and inspire others around the globe.  Let the magic begin!

 

 

 

We are a team of creative artists, educators and marketers who want to use our WISHAPHANT characters as teachers and positive role models for children.  We have self-published our first book on Nutrition featuring the Wishaphants.  The book is entitled The Mysterious Lunch at Hope Street Elementary and was written by Dr. Peter DeWitt and illustrated by Rick O’Boyle.  We held a public reading of our first book to over 600 school children to wild enthusiasm and applause!  We are already planning our second book on Bullying with future books on important topics to follow.

Our Wishaphant Team needs to raise a total of $50,000.  The initial $25,000 will be used so we can develop a traveling educational children's musical  that will be presented FREE to a test market of elementary schools.  We will also use these funds to write and use multi-media elements in our show. We plan to support these shows with educational activity sheets, songs and personal appearances by our 6 ft. Wishaphant mascot!  The final portion of these funds will go to further development of a Wishaphant website that will allow schools and students to interact in a safe environment.  We need the additional $25,000 to create a 90 second animation pitch piece for investors and for an animated cartoon series.

Our project is ongoing and we plan to expand it as of October 2012 and try to reach our $50,000 goal in 60 days with your help!  We’ve also developed some great giveaways for our donors like autographed posters and books which will become collector items someday.  We also plan to raise additional funds through licensed products and a children’s musical.

We need your help to spread the Wishaphant magic!  Use indiegogo’s share tools, Facebook, Twitter, text and telephone. WE NEED YOUR GIFTS AND HELP!!

 

PLEASE VISIT OUR GALLERY ON THE TOP LEFT WHERE YOU CAN SEE ARTICLES INCLUDING THE COVER OF PARENT PAGES, COVER OF THE RECORD,THE COVER OF THE SPOTLIGHT AND THE NEW JERWEY HERALD. PROTO TYPES, MASCOT, THE COVER OF OUR FIRST BOOK, PHOTOS ,VARIOUS ART AND ARTICLES ON NORMAN REA'S COMMUNITY WORK.

story:
Short Summary

The Inaugural Black History Bowl is an academic competition providing high school students with a unique opportunity to demonstrate their knowledge of African American History, compete for scholarships, engage in cultural enrichment activities, and build their self-confidence.  This year's inaugural event is focused exclusively on students of the high school age.  The day-long event plans to start with breakfast and/or include lunch, cultural enrichment activities and a concluding awards ceremony. The students are challeneged to learn all the information provided in our Black History packets. On the day of the event they will compete against eachother's knowledge of Black History with the hopes of winning scholarships.  The prospective venues for the event, the Boyde Vance Theatre (located in the George Washington Carver Museum and Multicultural Center) or the Millennium Youth Event Center, will allow the students and patrons of this event to experience a visit to one of Austin's most prized venues.

 

What We Need

We are raising funds for the following:

Scholarship Awards (monetary scholarship awards for 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place winners.)

Trophies to all placed winners

Certificates and/or trophies to all contestants that participated.

T-Shirts for all partcipants and volunteers of the event.

Study guide binders for all participants.

Flyers to publicize event

Banners and posters for actual event. 

Room/ venue reservation fee.

 

The Impact

The purpose of this event is to engage Greater Austin youth in an academic competition in the subject area of African American's accomplishments so that they may be inspired and feed their minds of the rich history of their ancestors and the ancestors of their friends.  The Black History Bowl also gives young people in Austin the chance to grow intellectually, win scholarships (should they win the competition), and bring about positive change in our community. This is a grass root effort to offset the problems that get so much coverage every day, from low achievement scores to dropout rates.

The students who participate learn how important it is to study and experience positive peer competition. The latter translates into better relationships, an understanding of diverse backgrounds and lifestyles, and the importance of tolerance and respect for others. In addition, they gain a broad knowledge and understanding of African Americans and our contributions to the history of our country.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

For those of you who are unable to donate financially to this project, you can still donate your time! For more information on  how you can get involved in making this event happen, email:

SOnyekwere@gmail.com

                  or 

chas.d.moore@gmail.com

story:
KIPP Bayview Academy's Mission.

The mission of KIPP Bayview Academy is to develop in the students of southeastern San Francisco the knowledge, critical thinking skills and character traits needed to succeed in top quality high schools and colleges, and to lead deliberate and productive lives.

History.

KIPP Bayview Academy is a tuition-free, college-preparatory, public middle school located in the Bayview Hunters Point neighborhood of San Francisco. Since KIPP Bayview Academy opened its doors in 2003, it has consistently proven that with hard work and commitment, traditionally underserved students can achieve outstanding success.

Values.

Excellence | Initiative | Integrity | Positivity | Responsibility | Tenacity

Enrollment and Demographics.

255 students, grades 5–8

  • 90% from southeastern San Francisco
  • 73% African American
  • 16% Latino/Hispanic
  • 9% Pacific Islander
  • 2% Asian or other
  • 81% qualify for federal free and reduced-price meals

 

Our Kids and Teachers Are the Bomb!

KIPP Bayview Academy students and teachers work tirelessly to accomplish our common goals of getting our students to and through college. Part of creating this amazing learning environemnt is working and learning in a nice space. We believe that our students and teachers deserve a beautiful place to spend their days! 

 

We Need Your Help and Donations!

Our school building has seen better days. We operate out of an old parochial school that has been around since 1955, with few repairs. The walls in the classrooms and hallways have chipped paint, uneven layers of old paint, and a color scheme that would make your head spin. This is not just about making things look pretty: we know our students learn better, and our teachers teach better when they are in a beautiful space. With your help, our students will take greater pride in their education, their community, and their school.

Your assistance will give our school a makeover, with a fresh coat of paint!  

We need a large, large, large (!) amount of money to professionally paint the inside of our school. This includes 2 long hallways, 10 classrooms, 4 bathrooms, the front office, and 1 library. The total price tag of this job is $60,000. 

If we don't reach our entire funding goal, we will start with one of our buildings, and continue working to fundraise for the other building.

 

Gratitude.

We appreciate your donation, large or small. Our students and teachers will be forever grateful!

 

Pass the Word Along! 

If you feel passionate about our cause (and we hope you do!), please pass this message along to everyone that will listen! 

There are tools within Indiegogo.com that can help you spread the word!

story:
What is ARSN?

The objective of the Atlantic Regional Solidarity Network (ARSN) is to maintain a dialogue between groups in Atlantic Canada who work in solidarity with the people of Latin America and the Caribbean according to:

- The wishes and needs of Latin American and Caribbean people in the struggle for self-determination, peace and justice.

- The most effective ways of working for changes in Canada which will be beneficial to that struggle.

-ARSN is committed to working for changes in Canada which will be beneficial that struggle. This includes supporting the struggles of Indigenous nations and other communities in Canada in their defence of their territory and the earth for the benefit of all.

What We Need!

What your donations will be contributing to:

  • Transportation costs for speakers and resource people.
  • Bursaries for attendees in order to make the conference accessible to everyone!
  • As well, your donations will be contributing to awareness and education about issues and successes of Latin America.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not donate, you can still help by sharing our event for others to donate to. Also, promoting awareness of Latin American issues in your own community and/or joining local solidarity groups.

story:
Inherit Your Rights is a non-profit organization based in Arusha, Tanzania that works to empower and protect Maasai widow’s rights.

To hear more about Jessica's story: http://youtu.be/8GpUfO7-f00

To hear more from Sengu: http://youtu.be/47Y7Jj1ubbU

To hear from Anande, another Bachelor of Laws grad: http://youtu.be/mYmK8FTD3bc

Our Project

We are launching a Legal Fellowship Program this year to expand our work.

Through the Legal Fellowship Program, IYR will hire Tanzanians committed to public interest issues, then after a year of work, fund their legal certification. After they are newly minted as certified lawyers, IYR will offer them a spot to come and work for IYR for another year. This program will improve IYR’s capacity to provide direct legal aid and education by expanding our staff and our expertise.

The Fellowship will help IYR improve three problems:

  • Maasai widows often have their land and sometimes even their children illegally taken from them by their late husband’s relatives. The Tanzanian Constitution ensures equal rights for women. This Fellowship will allow IYR to assist more of these women in need and better protect their rights. 
  • There is a dire lack of lawyers in Tanzania and in particular a lack of public interest lawyers working with the rural poor. This Fellowship will help educate a base of lawyers committed to public interest law.
  • Legal education is expensive. After getting a Bachelors in Laws, a prospective lawyer then must complete a one-year legal certification program only available in Dar es Salaam. Saving for the certification can take years. This Fellowship will provide funding for the certification program. 

Please check us out at inherityourrights.org for more information about our programs.

 

Fellowship Program Details

Once we have raised the funds, we will select a Fellow who has recently completed their Bachelors of Laws from a local Tanzanian law school but who has not obtained their legal certification. The Fellow also must have a commitment to women’s rights in rural Tanzania. We hope to hire Maasai fellows.

The Fellowship Program will be three years:

  • The first year the fellow will be employed at IYR on a salary.
  • The second year, IYR will then provide a loan for tuition and expenses for a certification program at the Dar es Salaam law school.
  • The third year, after finishing the certification program, the Fellow can come back to work for IYR, at a higher salary and to work off the school loan for one year or can work elsewhere and pay off the loan over the year.

Why Is This Important?

Protecting women’s rights

In Tanzania, Maasai widows are vulnerable to abuse: when a man dies, his wife inherits nothing unless she is childless and there are no other relatives. The man’s children are the rightful heirs. However, if the children are too young to assert their rights, the man’s family often takes advantage of the situation and expels the widows from the land. These women, alone and with no means of supporting themselves or their children need both legal representation and practical assistance.

IYR will be able to assist more women in need with the additional help of the Fellow. IYR hopes this experience will be meaningful and that the Fellow will continue with such work beyond the Fellowship Program.

Lawyer shortage

Tanzania faces a severe lawyer shortage, and in particular has a shortage of lawyers working in rural Tanzania where the majority of people live. Tanzania only has about six lawyers per 100,000 inhabitants. Neighboring Kenya has three times that and the United States has over 300 lawyers per 100,000 inhabitants.

The IYR Fellowship Program directly addresses this issue by helping add another lawyer to the workforce in Tanzania. And not just any lawyer – the Fellowship Program will select candidates based on their desire for public interest legal work in rural Tanzania, which will increase access to justice for the rural poor.

The High Cost of Legal Education

One reason there are too few public interest oriented lawyers working in rural Tanzania is the high cost of legal certification, in particular for students who live far from Dar es Salaam.

In Tanzania, “law school” is a two-step process. First, you get your bachelors in law in a four-year university program. However to become a fully qualified laywer, you have to complete step two: a one-year certificate program at the University of Dar es Salaam.

The cost of attending the certificate program at the University of Dar es Salaam is a major problem for many would-be lawyers. It costs more than $3,500 in tuition, housing, and room and board. In a country with a per capita adjusted GDP of just $1,515, the cost of law school is overwhelming and prevents many qualified and interested students from attending, especially those not interested in corporate work. Interested students have to work for many years to build up enough money to be able to afford to get this certificate.

The Fellowship will turn what is often many years of saving and struggle into a faster, less stressful process.

 

What Value Does This Fellowship Create?

The benefit to Inherit Your Rights from this program is huge. Currently, we have three full-time staff. We also have a temporary full-time volunteer lawyer and anywhere from three to five volunteers who come to work for IYR for a two to three month period. We work every day to provide education on legal issues and support women in need of help, but we could do even more!

By hiring Fellows who speak Maasai and Swahili, we will be able to spend more time out in Maasailand giving lectures and educating the community. We will also be better able to provide legal aid – fighting for land rights locally, bringing cases to court, advising on legal rights, and drafting legal documents like wills and deeds to protect property rights.

In addition, we will have helped educate a lawyer committed to human rights and working to help the rural poor. Even after each fellowship has ended, we will have the benefit of knowing that we have a lifelong ally in the fight to empower women and protect their rights.

Perks

In addition to the gifts listed on the right side of this page. Everyone who donates will receive an update about the fellows after they are hired.  

What We Are Asking For

$9,000

This covers everything to fully fund the first two years of the fellowship. Included are wages, tuition, expenses, everything.

IYR is a non-profit organization, so it doesn’t have the cash on-hand to fund a fellowship. That’s why we need your help. Please donate now to contribute to this important work.

Every dollar you donate will be generously matched by the Eagles Wings Foundation for one fellowship. If we surpass our goal, the surplus dollars will be used to fund an additional fellow and the third-year salary of returning fellows. 

What is Inherit Your Rights?

Inherit Your Rights seeks to educate, empower, and represent widows in Tanzania, concerning their property and inheritance rights. Our main goal is to empower widows to claim their property and inheritance rights, thereby strengthening their families and communities. We have initiated a pilot project in northern Tanzania, in a small village in the foothills of Mount Meru. Through a local Pastor, we have met and started working with a group of 35 widows. We have acquired a plot of land there, where we can operate micro-enterprise projects to assist the women with their immediate needs. We are also working with some other women who are making their own jewelry and wheat flour to earn an income for themselves.

For more information, do not hesitate to follow us on Facebook and Twitter, or visit our website: www.inherityourrights.org

Tanzania only has about six lawyers per 100,000 inhabitants. Neighboring Kenya has three times that and the United States has over 300 lawyers per 100,000 inhabitants.
The IYR Fellowship Program directly addresses this issue by helping add another lawyer to the workforce in Tanzania. And not just any lawyer – the Fellowship Program will select candidates based on their desire for public interest legal work in rural Tanzania, which will increase access to justice for the rural poor.
The High Cost of Legal Education
One reason there are too few public interest oriented lawyers working in rural Tanzania is the high cost of legal certification, in particular for students who live far from Dar es Salaam.
In Tanzania, “law school” is a two-step process. First, you get your bachelors in law in a four-year university program. However to become a fully qualified laywer, you have to complete step two: a one-year certificate program at the University of Dar es Salaam.
The cost of attending the certificate program at the University of Dar es Salaam is a major problem for many would-be lawyers. It costs more than $3,500 in tuition, housing, and room and board. In a country with a per capita adjusted GDP of just $1,515, the cost of law school is overwhelming and prevents many qualified and interested students from attending, especially those not interested in corporate work. Interested students have to work for many years to build up enough money to be able to afford to get this certificate.
The Fellowship will turn what is often many years of saving and struggle into a faster, less stressful process.

 
What Value Does This Fellowship Create?
The benefit to Inherit Your Rights from this program is huge. Currently, we have three full-time staff. We also have a temporary full-time volunteer lawyer and anywhere from three to five volunteers who come to work for IYR for a two to three month period. We work every day to provide education on legal issues and support women in need of help, but we could do even more!
By hiring Fellows who speak Maasai and Swahili, we will be able to spend more time out in Maasailand giving lectures and educating the community. We will also be better able to provide legal aid – fighting for land rights locally, bringing cases to court, advising on legal rights, and drafting legal documents like wills and deeds to protect property rights.
In addition, we will have helped educate a lawyer committed to human rights and working to help the rural poor. Even after each fellowship has ended, we will have the benefit of knowing that we have a lifelong ally in the fight to empower women and protect their rights.
Perks
In addition to the gifts listed on the right side of this page. Everyone who donates will receive an update about the fellows after they are hired.  

What We Are Asking For
$9,000
This covers everything to fully fund the first two years of the fellowship. Included are wages, tuition, expenses, everything.
IYR is a non-profit organization, so it doesn’t have the cash on-hand to fund a fellowship. That’s why we need your help. Please donate now to contribute to this important work.
Every dollar you donate will be generously matched by the Eagles Wings Foundation for one fellowship. If we surpass our goal, the surplus dollars will be used to fund an additional fellow and the third-year salary of returning fellows. 
What is Inherit Your Rights?
Inherit Your Rights seeks to educate, empower, and represent widows in Tanzania, concerning their property and inheritance rights. Our main goal is to empower widows to claim their property and inheritance rights, thereby strengthening their families and communities. We have initiated a pilot project in northern Tanzania, in a small village in the foothills of Mount Meru. Through a local Pastor, we have met and started working with a group of 35 widows. We have acquired a plot of land there, where we can operate micro-enterprise projects to assist the women with their immediate needs. We are also working with some other women who are making their own jewelry and wheat flour to earn an income for themselves.
For more information, do not hesitate to follow us on Facebook and Twitter, or visit our website: www.inherityourrights.org

story:
Imran Khan had promised to introduce fresh blood into Pakistan’s politics, which has been monopolized for decades by feudal lords and capitalists and he lived up to his words.

On April 15th, Imran Khan allotted 35% of tickets to educated Pakistani youth below the age of 40. Please see the video below to learn more about some of these youth candidates.

With only 14 days left before the most important elections in Pakistan's history, these youth candidates desperately needs your financial assistance to run their political campaigns. There is no better way to invest into a Naya Pakistan by helping these future leaders of Pakistan at this critical juncture. 

In exchange for your generous support, you will receive Imran Khan's book, "Pakistan: A Personal History" signed by himself or a Cricket bat signed by Imran Khan.   

People may often ask you what Tabdeeli Imran Khan and PTI will bring. You need to tell them that Imran Khan and PTI without even coming into power have already brought at least one thing back to the people of Pakistan and that one thing is Hope. Hope for Tabdeeli and Hope for Naya Pakistan in the form of these youth candidates is what Imran Khan and PTI has given to Pakistan. Now it is up to us to turn this hope into a reality!

Support these youth candidates because it will always remind you of your contribution to this historic movement of our times that will free Pakistan from corrupt status quo, and will bring peace, prosperity, and progress to our country. Together, let's put Pakistan back on track of progress, self-reliance and self-respect, Inshallah!  

 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=poq7l7wLfY4
