story:
Meet the first robot in the world that develops together with children. With Photon they can:
 
 

Children love to learn by experimenting. Acquiring logical thinking ability is the key to success in their future life. Playing with most of educational toys feels like a chore and gets boring quickly. And that’s why we decided to build Photon.

 

STORYTELLING DRIVEN LEARNING ► Photon’s story motivates children to gain knowledge while keeping them engaged in a fun tale similar to popular comic books and cartoons.

DAILY CHALLENGES ► The robot gives kids programming related challenges. After coding simple programs, Photon can perform hundreds of tasks and show living proof of how lines of code affect reality.

FREEDOM OF CUSTOMIZATION ► Finishing challenges awards experience points known from RPG games. Children can use them to unlock new senses for the robot or boost his parameters according to their taste. No two robots will be the same!

PAIRED MOBILE APP ► Photon is integrated with an intuitive child-friendly application for smartphones and tablets that lets kids interact with their robot and create their own programs.

EASILY DIGESTIBLE PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE ► The language used by Photon is based on colorful blocks and inspired by Scratch and Google Blockly. Even a 6 year old can master it in no time.

 

 

The robot develops along his owner by gaining new abilities, senses and functionalities with each programming related task completed. Completing a quest to create a simple program may let the kid pick some sort of upgrade for Photon, like the ability to see or detect obstacles. This way, progress is visible right away and works as wonderful motivational tool.

It's not just another toy, it's a true friend and companion.

 

 

 

 

► Coding - has become the most sought after skill of the 21st century.

► Over the next ten years, programming will be one of the fastest growing occupations.

► There will be 1.4 million programming jobs…

► …and only 400 thousand graduates in computer science.

►A computer science major can earn 40% more than the average college graduate . Unfortunately, few adults can program and even fewer can teach the skill.

► Children highly benefit from learning about technology and understanding how it works. High technological literacy will become crucial for future generations.

 

 

Prominent people like Bill Gates or Barack Obama and corporations like Facebook are trying to inspire children and ignite their passion for coding.

Our team wants to join these efforts and support the idea that every child should be a digital creator.

We believe letting the younger generation learn about new technologies will allow them to succeed in their adult lives, professional careers and let them fulfill their dreams.

The user communicates with Photon through the “Photon-Human Translator”® (a smartphone application). The robot presents a unique story with gradually harder challenges. All stories have been developed with the involvement of educators, psychologists, and game specialists. Thanks to 10 programmable sensors you can send Photon on specific missions like going through a maze while detecting obstacles or following a child's hand as Photon passes safely through a hazardous lava filled cave!

 

Step by step children encounter further challenges which teach them how modern technology works. They study the basics of programming as well as exercise their ability to think logically.

The application creates additional challenges designed in a manner that allows children to play together with their parents Children are able to proudly show off their problem solving skills to their moms and dads while parents get the opportunity to spend time with their children and support them. We want to help in building this relationship.

Finishing different tasks earns you points and allows progressing to the next level in Photon. Points may be used to further upgrade the robot, like unlocking new sensor functions, new ways to interact, and to personalize it according to your child’s preferences. No two robots will have the same set of features! That’s a first! After numerous trials and research with children, we know that it is an incredibly effective motivator.

Photon is equipped with a number of sensors which allow it to “feel” and interact with the surrounding world.

 

 
 
 
 
Teaching programming takes place in steps of increasing difficulty. The application guides your child through the basics of programming and explains in detail how all the blocks that constitute programs work.
 
 
Children may program the robot using a tablet or a smartphone, through an intuitive visual block language, inspired by well-known and proven languages for children – Scratch from MIT and Blockly from Google. We’ve simplified the language to create a programing engine suitable for children (e.g. complicated settings or excessive/negative numbers have been removed). Additionally it has been adjusted to the capabilities of the robot and the mobile devices it works on. The only limit will be your child’s imagination.
 

 

 

In the beginning Photon can’t do anything and is just your everyday plastic toy. That doesn’t last long though. Kids connect with him through the app, get acquainted and receive their first coding related missions. Each task completed gives them experience points which can be spent on robot’s development. They can for example:

► Make Photon’s wheels faster, which lets him perform better at many endeavors 

► Unlock his vision module allowing him to notice them, as well as get better at avoiding obstacles 

► Make his eyes glow in a completely new color

► Teach him to react to sounds and many more

Each new function and sense unlocked motivates them to experiment and gives a bigger set of tools usable in programming. 

 

 
Just like a growing child, the robot gets smarter, stronger and keeps developing. RPG-like freedom of choice lets kids personalize their robots to their own tastes. Children are proud when their progress and successes in studying can be shown off and appreciated.
 
 
 
 
It is difficult to keep children stay focused and motivated. That’s why we worked together with experts in the fields of psychology and gamification to make playing with our robot as fun as possible. We’ve created an interactive story where the child and the robot are the main characters and have to work together. This builds a sense of responsibility which is a huge motivator and fosters learning.
 
 
Photon’s story encourages kids to take action and gain knowledge while having fun. When the robot was traveling to Earth, he had an accident and collided with an asteroid. His spacecraft broke into pieces that scattered all over the world. Now Photon wants to find these pieces, but he needs help from children! During their journey together they will meet many interesting characters that have found some of the spacecraft’s parts. These characters will present further challenges for Photon and the kids. Only if they pass a specific challenge, they will be allowed to pick up the missing piece.
 
 
All heroes of the story feel distinct and likeable. Their personalities are based on real human emotions like sadness, joy, anger, fear or curiosity. We’ve consulted the designs with a bunch of friendly kindergarteners and primary schools who had to approve every single one. 
 
 
 
 
Photon has been created for children who are in elementary school. The system has been designed together with kids in order to perfectly fit their expectations, abilities and needs. After countless months of work and numerous prototypes, we’re happy to announce that children love playing with the final version of Photon.
 
 
We’re committed to assuring parents that they are giving their children a high quality and a well-designed tool that can help develop creativity, social skills and ignite interest in STEM(Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics).
 
 
 
Children were a huge source of inspiration when it comes to design and ergonomics of our creation. Yes, they pointed us in the right direction and described what their dream robot should look like. The entire interface design process unfolded with a constant participation of parents, children, teachers, and psychologists. We have made every effort to make Photon safe, attractive as well as user-friendly. You can even add new accessories to change his appearance. A top hat? Maybe a stylish dress? The choice is yours! :)
 
 
 
Kids are creative by nature, and their ideas can be extremely surprising. That’s why we’ve created our robot with safety as a top priority. The robot is made out of durable and child-friendly materials. The internal electronics have been secured in a way that makes children unable to access them by any means.
 
 
Worrying about your favorite Bella, Duke, Sparky or other furry family member having a hard time, getting scared or too jealous of Photon? We have tested our robot with the help of dogs and cats and they seem to love it as much as kids. While learning to code with it might be a bit out of their reach, they still have heaps of fun.
 
 
 
 
 
One of the most interesting things we’ve noticed during the testing phase is the fact thatchildren aid and motivate each other while working with Photon. Cooperation and team-play are crucial for them and make the entire learning process much more engaging.
 
 
The robot teaches young people that they have to work together to overcome challenges. When one child has problems with a particular level, the other attempts to explain what he or she is doing wrong and how to do it better. Cooperating like this positively affects children, their development and social skills.
 
 
 
Children are adorably social creatures. With their robots being unique and personalized they love to show them off. When testing Photon at a friendly kindergarten we’ve noticed that they quickly came up with some funny competitions like races, obstacle courses and our favorite… sumo wrestling. That ensured us that creating a good multiplayer mode that could encourage positive rivalry is a must in Photon’s case.
 
 
Robots can communicate with each other, play games or fight, and use special moves.For example you can “cast a spell” and gain an advantage in a racing game - just like in the legendary Mario Kart (R) games! We plan to add leaderboards and daily challenges so that our beloved ones can compete with other children from around the world.
 
 
 
 
Our aim is to make the entire Photon experience enjoyable – from opening the box to setting it up and usage. The box itself looks like a spaceship and sets the stage for Photon’s journey. We want the magic of working with Photon to begin as soon as its little owner sees the mysterious package.
 
 
 
Everything made for kids should be as intuitive as possible. The smartphone app is based on visual hints to help the children that still lack a solid grasp on the alphabet get the most of it. . The coloring, shapes and patterns were also based on the research and analysis of our youngest specialists.
 
 
 
 
Our dream is to bring Photon to every child's house! To fulfill that dream we need your help. We appreciate all your support and hope we can do a lot of good for the world!
 
 
 
 
Photon was conceived in the minds of Martin Joka, Mike Grzes, Chris Dziemianczuk, Michael Bogucki and Mac Kopczynski, four students and one academic teacher from the Bialystok University of Technology, Poland. Now we're an international team consisting of engineers, programmers and developers from the USA (Chicago), Poland (Bialystok) and Belgium (Bruxelles).
 
 
Photon's creators have received numerous distinctions and honorable mentions for their work. They have won prestigious technological contests organized by companies such as Microsoft or Phillips and have been awarded by the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education – they are prize-winners of the “Generation of the Future” program. The team members are graduates of many prestigious programs, e.g. TOP500 Innovators. They are also mentioned in many well known rankings, e.g. New Europe 100 ranking - the list of 100 most dynamically developing innovators in Europe, which is created by laRespublica and Google. 
 
 
Their personal experience is worth noting - in 2014 one of the creators of Photon, Mike Grzes, worked as the coordinator and the main constructor of Hyperion 2, an award-winning Mars rover. This year the CEO of Photon, Martin Joka, has become a nominee for MIT Innovators under 35.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

Promise is a promise. This phrase – incredibly important when you’re creating something for kids - is one of our main mottos when building Photon. That’s why we have decided to provide honest delivery dates, and avoid making children wait pointlessly.

Photon will arrive on Earth after December 2016. There is a chance we can make it for Christmas, provided there are lots of preorders and we get our hands on production molds earlier.

 

On our way we have met lots wonderful people, companies and organizations that never hesitated to help us. Photon is able to become reality thanks to their help!

 

 

Risks and challenges

We are focused on delivering our robot to every type of backer in a timely manner, however, as with any product that involves complex manufacturing, production delays could become an issue. We will focus on keeping our backers informed at all the times and mitigating any potential delays.

We will treat every backer as if they were our first, and promise to deliver you a high quality product.

story:
Muscota - Turn The World Around

Muscota New School is fortunate to have a community of involved parents, talented educators and joyful learners dedicated to progressive learning. Together our fundraising efforts have helped support and grow our award winning science and arts programs, and these contributions have enriched the education of every child at Muscota. This year our parents have established a new goal of raising money so that all of our children can go on exciting and innovative field trips.

Why we need your support

Currently, when Muscota students participate in field trips we grapple with the limitations imposed by school buses;

  • we can only go to locations within the five boroughs
  • we cannot leave until 9:30 AM, but must return no later that 1:30 PM, leaving us very little time to learn and experience new things outside of the classroom.
  • We find that many truly wonderful field trip options are simply out of our price range.

How your donation will help

Your support will help us enrich the experience of every child at Muscota, by allowing us to hire private buses to take us on longer field trips and trips outside of city limits and enable us to go to places that were never previously accessible to us because of cost.

Muscota PA is a 501c3 organization, so all donations are tax deductible. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not every family will be able to make a financial contribution, but you can help by getting the word out to family and friends.

Thank you for your consideration.


Muscota - cambiar el mundo

Muscota New School es afortunada de tener una comunidad de padres involucrados, educadores talentosos y estudiantes alegres dedicados al aprendizaje progresivo. Junto a nuestros esfuerzos de recaudación de fondos han ayudado a crecer apoyo y nuestro galardonado programas de ciencia y de las artes, y estas contribuciones han enriquecido la educación de cada niño en Muscota. Este año nuestros padres han establecido un nuevo objetivo de recaudar dinero para que todos nuestros niños pueden ir en excursiones emocionantes e innovadoras.

¿Por qué necesitamos su ayuda?

En la actualidad, cuando los estudiantes de Muscota participan en excursiones que lidiar con las limitaciones impuestas por los autobuses escolares;

  • sólo podemos ir a lugares dentro de los cinco condados
  • no podemos dejar hasta las 9:30 AM, pero debemos volver a más tardar el 13:30, dejándonos muy poco tiempo para aprender y experimentar cosas nuevas fuera de las aulas.
  • Encontramos que muchos verdaderamente maravillosas opciones de viaje de campo son simplemente fuera de nuestra gama de precios.

Cómo su donación ayudará

Su apoyo nos ayudará a enriquecer la experiencia de cada niño en Muscota, al permitirnos contratar autobuses privados para llevarnos en viajes y excursiones más largas fuera de los límites de la ciudad y nos permitirá ir a lugares que nunca fueron previamente accesible a nosotros debido a costo.

Muscota PA es una organización 501c3 , por lo que todas las donaciones son deducibles de impuestos

Otras maneras que usted puede ayudar

Entendemos que no todas las familias será capaz de hacer una contribución financiera, pero te atendemos por hacer correr la voz a familiares y amigos.

Gracias por su consideracion.
story_txt:
Muscota - Turn The World AroundMuscota New School is fortunate to have a community of involved parents, talented educators and joyful learners dedicated to progressive learning. Together our fundraising efforts have helped support and grow our award winning science and arts programs, and these contributions have enriched the education of every child at Muscota. This year our parents have established a new goal of raising money so that all of our children can go on exciting and innovative field trips.Why we need your supportCurrently, when Muscota students participate in field trips we grapple with the limitations imposed by school buses;

we can only go to locations within the five boroughs


we cannot leave until 9:30 AM, but must return no later that 1:30 PM, leaving us very little time to learn and experience new things outside of the classroom.


We find that many truly wonderful field trip options are simply out of our price range.

How your donation will helpYour support will help us enrich the experience of every child at Muscota, by allowing us to hire private buses to take us on longer field trips and trips outside of city limits and enable us to go to places that were never previously accessible to us because of cost.Muscota PA is a 501c3 organization, so all donations are tax deductible. Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand that not every family will be able to make a financial contribution, but you can help by getting the word out to family and friends.Thank you for your consideration.

story: Carol is an invaluable part of the Garfield family who is being unfairly misrepresented. We ask that you chip in to help pay for her legal fees and send a strong message of support for the amazing program she has built and her tireless efforts on behalf of students.

story:
Our Story

Arts Enterprise creates communities of arts and business students that develop new ideas for a triple-bottom line of social, cultural, and economic growth. 


Arts Enterprise is excited to announce our next Arts Enterprise Summit: The Creative Economy and You will be held March 23-25, 2012 at Claremont Graduate University, hosted by the MA in Arts Management, a joint program of the Peter F. Drucker & Masatoshi Ito Graduate School of Management and the School of Arts and Humanities.


How do you channel your creativity to develop a fulfilling career in an economy where innovation is key? The 2012 AE National Summit will give you the opportunity to tap into your creative mind, form career strategies, and strengthen your entrepreneurial skills. Designed by students for students interested in both the arts and business, The Creative Economy and You will be a powerful way to build your cultural network with some of the key players in the arts and business sectors.

Registration information to be announced shortly - see below for early bird offer!

The Impact

Because the Arts Enterprise Summit is designed by students for students, it brings the best creative ideas to the brightest young talent, ready to tackle the early years of their careers.  This year, the AE Summit is designed and implemented entirely by graduate students of the arts management program at the Drucker School of Business, which means the panels, speakers, and workshops are uniquely tailored for the needs of students beginning their careers in a world where innovative ideas are paramount.  


Rarely do arts and business majors have a chance to network, yet design and innovative ideas permeate throughout both the art and business worlds. Arts Enterprise, a non-curricular student-based club, is one of the only formal forums where these students can share ideas and learn to work together before they venture out into the real world.


What We Need & What You Get

If you ARE A STUDENT, contribute $35 before January 15th and your contribution will become your registration fee - this is a 30% discount! By helping us reach our goal of $5,000, you will be creating a one-of-a-kind Summit that will build the next generation of arts leaders.


Other Ways You Can Help

We're expanding - start an AE chapter at your school! Visit www.artsenterprise.com to learn more about our values, philosophy, and the first steps to beginning a chapter at your university.

story:
My Story

Hi. My name is Ryan. I am the oldest of 3 children and a first generation college student. I am a senior at Texas Tech University from Houston, Tx. I'm acquiring my Bachelors degree in Advertising with a minor in Psychology. I have been a full time employee and full time student since the beginning of my college career in 2008. My parents and I have struggled tremendously to help put me through school. It has been an extremely hard and rigorous journey. Despite all of the trials, I have been able to stay on track with my 4 year degree plan, and will be graduating on May 19, 2012! 

 

Both of my parents attended college at my age, but both dropped out early on. My parents failure in their college career has always been their drive to push me to go above and beyond. They never wanted their mistakes to influence my choices in a negative way. They have been my backbone throughout my college journey the last 3 and half years, and everyday I strive to make them proud. My parents have always wanted the best for me and I've always wanted the best for myself. My family really didn't have the funds to finance my college career, and I wasn't ready for the big responsibility of taking care of myself at such an early age. From rent, to bills, to school finances, I have struggled each year to maintain my sanity in the mist of such a high work load. 

 

My school is 10hrs. away from my home in Houston, Tx. And when things go wrong, I'm left alone. I have no family and no savings to help me when emergencies occur. For instance, in August of 2011, I was involved in a car accident where my car, which is my transportation to work and school, was wrecked pretty badly. It will cost $1450 just to fix it and its a very old car. I've been driving it despite not having a headlight and also having a cracked radiator. My car starts smoking on occasion and it has really limited me in making it to work and school. On top of auto failures, I have no groceries and hardly any clothing. Things have been very hard for me, but I persist because I can see the light at the end of the tunnel! My mom, always tells me that the struggles I go through today are only preparation for the success in my near future, and I believe that with every fiber of my being!

 

Although I am very excited to be graduating with a degree and finishing school, I'm stressing everyday to stay on top of finances for school tuition, loans, food, and other necessities. This last year of school has been the worse for me because my younger sister started her first semester of college and now the funds me and my family have are stretched even thinner. Sometimes my tuition doesn't get paid on time, and I can't even see my final grades until I've paid the amounts in full. I'm very fearful that I won't be able to pay my tuition off before graduation and then they won't let me cross the stage. I'm working 40hrs (plus overtime) a week at my job in the Lubbock,Tx, but that's not even enough to cover everything... 

 

I'm not big on asking for help, but I heard about this opportunity and thought it would be a great chance to least try something when everything else has failed me. I would greatly appreciate any kind of contribution you can offer. Anything you can do to help will make the end of my senior year less stressful and more exciting.

 

Thank you,

Ryan Cne' Allen

story:
Hi Indiegogo,

To tell you a bit about myself, I'm a British student living in the UK. Recently for both work and personal business, I have almost be forced into buying a 3D printer. However, as I'm sure you all know, 3D printers are costly. Currently, especially with the economy as it is, I am unable to spend such a large amount of money on this single item.

As I'm tight for cash (I'm a student) there isn't much I can give you for your help. Everyone that sponsors will get a personal thank you from me. For those that chose the perks, thae rewards are listed below.

I am relying on you, the generous public to help keep my ambitions alive and to help fund my project so that I can aqquire a 3D printer with your help. Every little helps, whatever the support, I will be most grateful!

Many Thanks in advance for all your generosity. 

Alex

story:
This Project will invite 30 motivated youth (ages 14-20) to a seminar to create an Issyk-Kul north shore volunteer network, which will provide these individuals with contacts and skills they can utilize to improve their communities.  After the seminar, the participants will be expected to create a youth volunteer committees in their own villages. In the spring, we will organize a follow-up conference, where the participants can share their success, next-steps, and work together to improve their approaches to community development.

Everyday we see the impact that youth can make in their community and we hope to strengthen that impact by providing leadership and management skills. Also we are encouraging partnerships between neighboring towns and villages. Experienced youth leaders will share their skills and can inspire other young people to make a difference.

Background 

Kyrgyzstan is a small land-locked mountainous nation in Central Asia. Issyk-Kul is one of the 7 provinces of Kyrgyzstan.  During the soviet times, Lake Issyk-Kul was a premier destination for tourists.  Since that time, the infrastructure has started to crumble but economic activity still centers around tourism, which no longer provides economic stability for the locals in this oblast. 

Unemployment is relatively low during the summer.  However, for 9 months out of the year unemployment can be as high as 60%.  The population of the north shore of Issyk-Kul is 61,000 and 31.5% of people live in poverty. 

The schools in Kyrgyzstan lack after-school activities and there is no incentive for youth to be active in the community.  

As Peace Corps Volunteers living in different parts of Issyk-Kul Oblast in the Kyrgyz Republic, we are actively involved with youth development projects in our communities. We have reached over 3,000 children and young adults with projects ranging from simple English clubs to health lessons, and life-skills. Peace Corps is a grassroots organization, and after 2 years we are very familiar with the region, and are uniquely situated to help these communities.

A Peace Corps Volunteer works in country for only 2 years.  By getting students and young people involved in community development, our work will continue long after we leave.

Our Project  

The goal of our project is to provide youth the skills and knowlege to become leaders in their communities, begin their own volunteer committees, and engage their peers community based projects.

This project will fund a three day seminar for 30 students from 18 villages within a distance of 70 miles (114km). During the sessions participants will be taught project management skills, how to create work plans, how to assess community needs, and inspire each other to complete successful projects.

The funding will go towards:

  • Transportation for youth participants
  • Hotel and meals
  • Printing training materials
  • Toolkit for implementation in villages
  • T-Shirts

We hope to have a follow-up conference in the spring in which youth can report back and discuss what has worked and what hasn't in their own villages, and to get help from eachother with future projects. If we do not reach our entire funding goal, we will only organize the initial seminar.

Added Impact

In our initial impact we will provide skills and training to 30 motivated youth to spark them into taking action in their communities.

Additionally we hope that each of these conference participants will return to their village and inspire other youth to become active as well. We hope that by the follow-on seminar, our participants will have connected with a total at least 450 other youth encouraging them to be active.

Our overall goal is to get communities to join forces and invest in themselves, improving the quality of life for their residents. 

You can inspire youth action!

Donate to our campaign and invite your friends, family, and collegues to help too!

story:
Short Summary

The mission of Jobs with Justice is to promote worker and human rights across the United States and in the world at large. We are committed to the creation of living wage jobs, supporting organizing here and abroad, and maintaining pressure to demand corporate accountability in our communities.

The Equal Education and Employment Project trains and mentors undocumented students on how to apply to college and access scholarship opportunities. We also work with guidance counselors, administrators, and teachers with information specific to the high school and pre-college experience of undocumented immigrant students. We connect undocumented students with immigrant mentors, who walk them through every step of their application process. Given Obama’s recent announcement of deferred action for undocumented students, we are providing presentations on how to apply to apply for work visas and legalize one’s status.

Funding will allow us to provide scholarships for undocumented students who struggle to afford an education. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to scholarships for undocumented students who want to get involved in social movements! The money you donate goes directly to qualified undocumented students!!!

The Impact

Undocumented students are foreign nationals who either entered the United States without authorization, or entered legally but overstayed a visa without authorization. Like most young people whose parents force them to move, undocumented students rarely have any role in their decision to come to this country, or even to stay here. They are brought to this country by their parents or relatives. According to the 2000 census, over 2.5 million undocumented youth under the age of 18 were living in the United States.

Every year, 65,000 undocumented students graduate high school. But only 5% of these students go to college. While there are many factors at play in preventing low-income people of color from having access to a quality education, undocumented students face not only financial barriers, but the barrier of their status. Many do not see the purpose in applying to college when they do not believe that they will be able to utilize their degree for gainful employment.

Our campaign unites undocumented high school students with formerly or currently undocumented mentors that walk them through the college application process and trains undocumented students on becoming advocates for immigrant rights.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't contribute doesn't mean you can't help. Become an advocate for undocumented students by getting involved in the fight to pass the DREAM Act nationally, or join us at some of our presentations in local high schools and universities.

story:
That's Nargiza in the blue sweatshirt!

Our Story

Hi, I'm Alyson and I just returned from Kyrgyzstan after two years as a Peace Corps volunteer. Maybe you've never heard of Kyrgyzstan (my mom still can't pronounce it after two years), but it's among the poorest countries in the world. I lived in a small village without running water, sporadic electricity and little heat during the harsh winters. Despite the difficult living conditions, I had an amazing experience, entirely thanks to my students.  

One student always stood out. I was fortunate to count Nargiza as both a student and host family member.  Though she did not live with my host family, she was somehow related and would often come over to watch my host sisters and other family members. I was always in awe of her ability to take care of at least 5 children, prepare all the meals, milk the cows, clean the house, do the laundry (by hand!)-always with a smile and without complaint.  

Though her kindness shone in the household, she really stood out in the classroom. When I arrived, it was easily apparent Nargiza was the school's best English  speaker. The Peace Corps volunteer before me, Bridgette, had worked diligently with all students, but it really showed with Nargiza.  Over the next two years, Nargiza took advantage of every opportunity to learn English. She came to English club everyday after school, attended English summer camps and participated in national English competitions. It was clear Nargiza had ambitions and dreams far beyond her tiny village in a country many have never heard of. 

When Mercersburg Summer Programs graciously offered to waive the $6,100 tuition for one of my students from Kyrgyzstan, I knew it had to be Nargiza. Mercersburg Academy, a prestigious boarding school in my hometown, offers an array of summer programs and camps. One of the programs is an intensive 6-week English as a Second Language summer camp for international students. This program would mean a life-changing opportunity for Nargiza, .  

All we need now is funds for her airline ticket and visa/passport expenses. Nargiza once wrote in a classroom assignment: "my dream is to come to America because there I can have bigger dreams than I could dream here."

Here's a link to the summer program:

http://www.mercersburgsummer.com/programs/enrichments-the-arts/esl-language-programs/

The Impact

Many students in developing countries cannot see the efficacy of English study.  In their towns or villages, English is rarely spoken.  In my own village, students would often tell me they would never need English, because they would be farmers or taxi drivers or teachers.  Many students could not see the opportunities available only to English speakers. 

Nargiza's coming to America will be huge news.  Not only in my village, but in the many surrounding villages.  Students, parents and teachers will see the importance of not only English, but education. Nargiza will be an example of aiming higher and working hard, an example these villages desperately need. 

And of course, the impact for Nargiza is immeasurable.  The program offers TOEFL preparation (the American universities' admission exam for speakers of a foreign language), visits to American college campuses, intensive English study and trips to various sites (New York City, Washington DC, Gettysburg etc...)  This is the beginning of great things for Nargiza!

What We Need

A total of $1,800 for Nargiza's travel to the United States

  • Airfare $1,400 - Current ticket prices with Aeroflot airlines from Bishkek to New York City
  • American Visa expenses $140
  • Kyrgyz passport $100 - the cost of the actual passport as well as travel expenses
  • We have left a little cushion because the price of the airline ticket may increase by the time fundraising is through.  If there is any money left over, it will ALL be given to Nargiza so she can buy souvenirs and gifts for her family and friends.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tells others! Tell your friends and family. Or anybody who would be interested in helping a good cause. 


DISCLAIMER: applying for an American visa is never certain.  If for any reason her visa is denied and she is unable to come to the United States, all donors will be fully refunded.
story_txt:
That's Nargiza in the blue sweatshirt!
Our Story
Hi, I'm Alyson and I just returned from Kyrgyzstan after two years as a Peace Corps volunteer. Maybe you've never heard of Kyrgyzstan (my mom still can't pronounce it after two years), but it's among the poorest countries in the world. I lived in a small village without running water, sporadic electricity and little heat during the harsh winters. Despite the difficult living conditions, I had an amazing experience, entirely thanks to my students.  
One student always stood out. I was fortunate to count Nargiza as both a student and host family member.  Though she did not live with my host family, she was somehow related and would often come over to watch my host sisters and other family members. I was always in awe of her ability to take care of at least 5 children, prepare all the meals, milk the cows, clean the house, do the laundry (by hand!)-always with a smile and without complaint.  
Though her kindness shone in the household, she really stood out in the classroom. When I arrived, it was easily apparent Nargiza was the school's best English  speaker. The Peace Corps volunteer before me, Bridgette, had worked diligently with all students, but it really showed with Nargiza.  Over the next two years, Nargiza took advantage of every opportunity to learn English. She came to English club everyday after school, attended English summer camps and participated in national English competitions. It was clear Nargiza had ambitions and dreams far beyond her tiny village in a country many have never heard of. 
When Mercersburg Summer Programs graciously offered to waive the $6,100 tuition for one of my students from Kyrgyzstan, I knew it had to be Nargiza. Mercersburg Academy, a prestigious boarding school in my hometown, offers an array of summer programs and camps. One of the programs is an intensive 6-week English as a Second Language summer camp for international students. This program would mean a life-changing opportunity for Nargiza, .  
All we need now is funds for her airline ticket and visa/passport expenses. Nargiza once wrote in a classroom assignment: "my dream is to come to America because there I can have bigger dreams than I could dream here."
Here's a link to the summer program:
http://www.mercersburgsummer.com/programs/enrichments-the-arts/esl-language-programs/
The Impact
Many students in developing countries cannot see the efficacy of English study.  In their towns or villages, English is rarely spoken.  In my own village, students would often tell me they would never need English, because they would be farmers or taxi drivers or teachers.  Many students could not see the opportunities available only to English speakers. 


Nargiza's coming to America will be huge news.  Not only in my village, but in the many surrounding villages.  Students, parents and teachers will see the importance of not only English, but education. Nargiza will be an example of aiming higher and working hard, an example these villages desperately need. 
And of course, the impact for Nargiza is immeasurable.  The program offers TOEFL preparation (the American universities' admission exam for speakers of a foreign language), visits to American college campuses, intensive English study and trips to various sites (New York City, Washington DC, Gettysburg etc...)  This is the beginning of great things for Nargiza!

What We Need

A total of $1,800 for Nargiza's travel to the United States



Airfare $1,400 - Current ticket prices with Aeroflot airlines from Bishkek to New York City
American Visa expenses $140

Kyrgyz passport $100 - the cost of the actual passport as well as travel expenses
We have left a little cushion because the price of the airline ticket may increase by the time fundraising is through.  If there is any money left over, it will ALL be given to Nargiza so she can buy souvenirs and gifts for her family and friends.




Other Ways You Can Help
Tells others! Tell your friends and family. Or anybody who would be interested in helping a good cause. 


DISCLAIMER: applying for an American visa is never certain.  If for any reason her visa is denied and she is unable to come to the United States, all donors will be fully refunded.

story:
Short Summary

Catylator is a new makerspace being organized in Silver Spring, Maryland. In the summer of 2015, Catylator will be holding summer camp sessions for youth ages 12-17 years old to introduce them to designing and fabricating, including Computer Aided Design (CAD) and Computer Aided Manufacturing (CAM); Computer Numerically-Controlled (CNC) machining and 3-D printing. This crowdfunding campaign was created to fund 10 scholarships of $500 to expand access to this camp to minority and young women who otherwise might not have an opportunity to attend. Historically these two groups have been underrepresented in the maker community and in businesses. Catylator is interested in promoting a world with greater inclusion.

Note - the camps for June are filled with campers already, but there are slots left for the camps in July and August. 


What We Need & What You Get

Catylator is seeking $5,000 to offer 10 scholarships. Working with the minority achievement coordinators at local area schools, Catylator will identify deserving students who have shown an interest in self-advancing themselves in maker-related skills. Once that has been done, Catylator will communicate with those students and tell them, "Come on board. We'd love for you to attend our summer camp if you're available and interested."

These are the perks being offered to supporters of this crowdfunding campaign:

For a $10 or more donation - your name listed as a supporter on the Catylator web site
For a $50 donation - a thank you email from Steve Morris
For a $100 donation - a thank you phone call from SteveMorris.
For a $500 donation - a coffee meeting with Steve Morris in Silver Spring
For a $750 donation - a 3D printing demo with Steve Morris in Silver Spring

If we don't reach our entire goal, Catylator will offer partial scholarships or fewer scholarships.


The Impact

For the maker movement to succeed, it needs all hands on board, especially those who have been historically underrepresented in maker related creative activities and businesses. Your donations to this crowdfunding campaign will be a step in that direction.

The creator of this crowdfunding campaign, Phil Shapiro, a volunteer supporter of Catylator, has been working on digital inclusion initiatives in the Washington DC-area and nationally for the past 25 years. A few of his related projects are linked to below.

The Harlem Commmunity Computing Center - an introduction (1992)

Fannie Lou Hamer - Freedom Fighter (created at the Adult Literacy Services Division of Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Library, Washington DC)

The Man Who Gives Computers to Kids (Washington Post Metro section article, April, 2000)

Community Technology Centers' Network special award (June, 2002)

Phil also writes for MAKE magazine, including this blog post about Catylator. 


Risks & Challenges

The maker community in the Washington DC-area is just beginning to get organized. Thanks to the very successful Silver Spring Mini Maker Faires held the past two years, an emerging community of makers has appeared on the scene. This community is not yet united in an email list, so reaching the community will require outreach via existing email lists, word of mouth and other channels of communication. 

Phil Shapiro, Steve Morris, and Melinda Sims will use their existing contacts to help spread the word. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate to this campaign, you can still play a vital role in helping spread the word about the campaign.  Use IndieGoGo's social media tools and tell people you know about this campaign. Supporters of the campaign need not live in the Washington DC-area, too.

story: My name is Tyler McCoy, and I am a junior business major and philosophy minor at Calumet College of St. Joseph, a small liberal arts college in Northwest Indiana. I am a very engaged student, athlete, president of the student government, and club officer. I was adopted at age 12 by my grandmother who is unable to offer such steep financial assistance to me, and I am seeking out alternative means to raise the costs that might otherwise inhibit me from my involvement within the institution...3.98 cumulative GPA, captain of the wrestling team, hard working student, with a unique story. Along with the responsibilities I have as a student leader, my credits have averaged over 17.5 per semester, making it very difficult for me to keep up with finances for lack of time. I believe that I will be better suited to "pay it forward," if I can continue onward in my current path towards future success without the need to triage any of my potential achievements for reasons of poverty. In order to pay for three summer classes and rent, plus the added expenditures that go along with those studies, I would be forced to quit some of the positive extracurricular things I am doing. I know in my heart that there are people who would warm to my extraordinary story of triumph through struggle, so this is one way for me to ask for people to help me focus on my part in what can be an even more dynamic tale of success.

story:
(english follows)

Ενισχύστε το Σχολείο Μεσογειακής Περμακουλτούρας στο αγρόκτημα της Νέας Γουινέας στη Νέα Μάκρη

Σε αυτή τη γωνιά της Ανατολικής Μεσογείου, οι ιδιαιτερότητες του κλίματος και της τοπογραφίας, συνθέτουν μια σχεδόν μαγική εικόνα, δίνοντας στους ανθρώπους την αίσθηση πως είναι τυχεροί που ζουν εδώ. Όσο όμως και αν εκτιμούμε την άγρια φυσική ομορφιά και τις πλούσιες παραδόσεις του τόπου μας, δεν μπορούμε να παραβλέψουμε το γεγονός ότι στο μεγαλύτερο μέρος της χώρας, το φυσικό περιβάλλον έχει μετατραπεί πλέον σε ένα μωσαϊκό από υποβαθμισμένα οικοσυστήματα και ιδιαίτερα διαβρωμένα τοπία με αβαθή φτωχά εδάφη, που μπορούν πλέον να υποστηρίξουν μόνο μερικά ανθεκτικά είδη φυτών. Επαναλαμβανόμενες πυρκαγιές και λανθασμένες πολιτικές διαχείρισης των φυσικών πόρων επιταχύνουν περαιτέρω την ερημοποίηση, εγείροντας σε πολλές περιοχές ζητήματα επάρκειας νερού και επισιτιστικής ασφάλειας. Η κατάσταση αυτή αποτελεί την τοπική έκφανση ενός φαινομένου περιβαλλοντικής υποβάθμισης που εξελίσσεται σε παγκόσμια κλίμακα, με διαφορετική ένταση και ταχύτητα σε κάθε περιοχή, και αναδεικνύει την ανάγκη για τοπικές λύσεις, προσαρμοσμένες στις δυνατότητες και τις ιδιαιτερότητες των κατά τόπους κοινοτήτων και οικοσυστημάτων.

Καθώς το κλίμα μεταβάλλεται απρόβλεπτα, ο μόνος τρόπος να αποτρέψουμε τις επερχόμενες βαθιές οικολογικές κρίσεις και να διασφαλίσουμε τη επιβίωση και την ευημερία μας σε αυτό τον τόπο, είναι να κινητοποιηθούμε και να επιδιώξουμε την αναγέννηση των τοπικών οικοσυστημάτων και την επαναφορά τους σε μια φυσική κατάσταση ισορροπίας. Τώρα, περισσότερο από ποτέ, γεννιέται η ανάγκη να αναζητήσουμε τρόπους για να ενσωματώσουμε την ανθρώπινη δραστηριότητα στο φυσικό περιβάλλον με σεβασμό και συναίσθηση των ορίων που τίθενται από την ίδια τη φύση και να μετατρέψουμε την επίδραση μας σε ένα παράγοντα που θα προωθεί την πολυπλοκότητα και την ποικιλομορφία, ενισχύοντας έτσι την ανθεκτικότητα και την προσαρμοστικότητα των φυσικών οικοσυστημάτων, αλλά και των κοινοτήτων που υποστηρίζονται από αυτά.

Αναγνωρίζοντας την ανάγκη να δραστηριοποιηθούμε προς αυτή την κατεύθυνση, αναπτύσσουμε το εγχείρημα του Σχολείου Μεσογειακής Περμακουλτούρας (Περμασχολείο), με στόχο να αναδείξουμε και να μεταδώσουμε βασικές μεθόδους και πρακτικές σχεδιασμού, εστιάζοντας σε εφαρμογές που αφορούν στο μεσογειακό κλίμα. Οι εκπαιδευτικές δραστηριότητες του Περμασχολείου προτείνουν λύσεις σε ζητήματα βιωσιμότητας και αειφορίας που αφορούν στην οργάνωση της ανθρώπινης δραστηριότητας και τη διαχείριση των φυσικών πόρων σε επίπεδο αγροκτήματος, για την κάλυψη ενός μεγάλου φάσματος των βασικών καθημερινών αναγκών σε τροφή, νερό, ενέργεια και στέγη. Καλύπτουν τις βασικές ενότητες ενός σεμιναρίου σχεδιασμού Περμακουλτούρας και στοχεύουν στην ενδυνάμωση των συμμετεχόντων στη δραστηριοποίηση τους προς θετικές αλλαγές από τις οποίες θα επωφελούνται τόσο οι κοινότητες όσο και τα οικοσυστήματα που τους περιβάλλουν. Αυτή την άνοιξη πραγματοποιήθηκε ο πρώτος κύκλος μαθημάτων του Περμασχολείου με τη συνεργασία 10 δασκάλων Περμακουλτούρας από όλη τη χώρα. Η προσπάθεια αυτή είχε μεγάλη επιτυχία και άφησε πίσω της πολλούς ανθρώπους γεμάτους γνώση, έμπνευση και ενθουσιασμό!

Αυτή τη στιγμή ζητάμε την υποστήριξη σας για να δώσουμε σε άλλους 40 νέους ανθρώπους την ευκαιρία να αποκτήσουν αυτή τη γνώση και να τη χρησιμοποιήσουν σε ήδη υπάρχοντα και μελλοντικά εγχειρήματα, ενισχύοντας το αναπτυσσόμενο δίκτυο Περμακουλτούρας στην Ελλάδα. Ο επόμενος κύκλος εκπαιδευτικών δραστηριοτήτων του Περμασχολείου έχει προγραμματιστεί για την περίοδο Σεπτεμβρίου – Νοεμβρίου 2018. Βοηθήστε μας να συνεχίσουμε αυτή την αξιόλογη προσπάθεια και να την εξελίξουμε ακόμα περισσότερο! Τα χρήματα που θα συγκεντρωθούν προορίζονται για να καλύψουν τα τρέχοντα έξοδα του Περμασχολείου (αμοιβές δασκάλων, μεταφορικά και αναλώσιμα).

Support the on going project of the Μediterranean Permaschool of Nea Guinea, in Nea Makri, Greece

This part of the Mediterranean we call home, full of intense landscapes and diverse local traditions, is a really special place. Five thousand years of human activity have left behind a rich history and culture, but also a mosaic of degraded watersheds and highly eroded landscapes. Water scarcity and soil depletion has always been a primal concern for most part of the country. Lack of knowledge and wrong policies have been pushing people towards wrong solutions, aggravating the problem further. More recently, changing rain patterns and frequent - extensive wildfires are speeding up the desertification process, bringing up issues of water and food security.

Our story is the local manifestation of a global phenomenon of environmental degradation that takes place in every single region of the planet at different speed and intensity, and calls for local action, adapted to the abilities and the particularities of local communities and ecosystems. In order to ensure our survival and well being as a species we have to actively engage in restoring our local ecosystems, bringing them back to their natural state of lush and abundance. We need sets of conceptual tools and effective techniques for integrating human activity into natural ecosystems, converting it into a revitalizing and stabilizing factor that can promote complexity and diversity.

Recognizing the urge to act in this direction, we set up the Mediterranean Permaschool at Nea Guinea Farm in Nea Makri, in the North East region of Attica. This project consists of educational activities aiming at conveying Permaculture design methods and practices, with a special focus on applications relevant to the Mediterranean climate. The Mediterranean Permaschool’s educational activities aim at offering solutions to sustainability issues related to the arrangement of human activity and the management of natural resources on a farm scale, in order to meet a wide range of basic daily needs in food, water, energy and housing. They run on a weekly basis for a period of 2 1/2 months and cover the core modules of a Permaculture Design Course. The Mediterranean Permaschool aims at empowering participants to make positive changes that will benefit both their communities and the natural ecosystems that surround them. The first period of educational activities took place this spring, with the collaboration of 10 different Permaculture teachers from all over the country and it was very successful!

We are now asking for your support to continue with this amazing project and give the opportunity to 40 more young people to acquire this knowledge and support them in using it in existing and future land based projects that will reinforce the development of the Greek Permaculture network. The next period of educational activities is planned for September – November 2018. Help us keep up this valuable work and develop the project further! The money gathered in this campaign will cover teaching fees and transport as well as material costs.

Η προσπάθεια αυτή είχε μεγάλη επιτυχία και άφησε πίσω της πολλούς ανθρώπους γεμάτους γνώση, έμπνευση και ενθουσιασμό!

Αυτή τη στιγμή ζητάμε την υποστήριξη σας για να δώσουμε σε άλλους 40 νέους ανθρώπους την ευκαιρία να αποκτήσουν αυτή τη γνώση και να τη χρησιμοποιήσουν σε ήδη υπάρχοντα και μελλοντικά εγχειρήματα, ενισχύοντας το αναπτυσσόμενο δίκτυο Περμακουλτούρας στην Ελλάδα. Ο επόμενος κύκλος εκπαιδευτικών δραστηριοτήτων του Περμασχολείου έχει προγραμματιστεί για την περίοδο Σεπτεμβρίου – Νοεμβρίου 2018. Βοηθήστε μας να συνεχίσουμε αυτή την αξιόλογη προσπάθεια και να την εξελίξουμε ακόμα περισσότερο! Τα χρήματα που θα συγκεντρωθούν προορίζονται για να καλύψουν τα τρέχοντα έξοδα του Περμασχολείου (αμοιβές δασκάλων, μεταφορικά και αναλώσιμα).

Support the on going project of the Μediterranean Permaschool of Nea Guinea, in Nea Makri, Greece
This part of the Mediterranean we call home, full of intense landscapes and diverse local traditions, is a really special place. Five thousand years of human activity have left behind a rich history and culture, but also a mosaic of degraded watersheds and highly eroded landscapes. Water scarcity and soil depletion has always been a primal concern for most part of the country. Lack of knowledge and wrong policies have been pushing people towards wrong solutions, aggravating the problem further. More recently, changing rain patterns and frequent - extensive wildfires are speeding up the desertification process, bringing up issues of water and food security.

Our story is the local manifestation of a global phenomenon of environmental degradation that takes place in every single region of the planet at different speed and intensity, and calls for local action, adapted to the abilities and the particularities of local communities and ecosystems. In order to ensure our survival and well being as a species we have to actively engage in restoring our local ecosystems, bringing them back to their natural state of lush and abundance. We need sets of conceptual tools and effective techniques for integrating human activity into natural ecosystems, converting it into a revitalizing and stabilizing factor that can promote complexity and diversity.

Recognizing the urge to act in this direction, we set up the Mediterranean Permaschool at Nea Guinea Farm in Nea Makri, in the North East region of Attica. This project consists of educational activities aiming at conveying Permaculture design methods and practices, with a special focus on applications relevant to the Mediterranean climate. The Mediterranean Permaschool’s educational activities aim at offering solutions to sustainability issues related to the arrangement of human activity and the management of natural resources on a farm scale, in order to meet a wide range of basic daily needs in food, water, energy and housing. They run on a weekly basis for a period of 2 1/2 months and cover the core modules of a Permaculture Design Course. The Mediterranean Permaschool aims at empowering participants to make positive changes that will benefit both their communities and the natural ecosystems that surround them. The first period of educational activities took place this spring, with the collaboration of 10 different Permaculture teachers from all over the country and it was very successful!

We are now asking for your support to continue with this amazing project and give the opportunity to 40 more young people to acquire this knowledge and support them in using it in existing and future land based projects that will reinforce the development of the Greek Permaculture network. The next period of educational activities is planned for September – November 2018. Help us keep up this valuable work and develop the project further! The money gathered in this campaign will cover teaching fees and transport as well as material costs.

story:
Through the Looking Glass (TLG) is a nationally recognized center that has pioneered research, training and services for parents and grandparents with disabilities.  One of our programs that has helped more than 1,000 parents and grandparents is providing Adaptive Baby Care services.  TLG has been the primary organization in the U.S. and internationally that is focused on baby care adaptations for parents with disabilities and their young children. 

TLG provides Adaptive Baby Care services to expectant parents, parents or parenting grandparents who have issues that restrict their ability to care for an infant or young child.  This includes parents with physical disabilities (such as wheelchair users, parents with back, hand or shoulder injuries, or who have had strokes) as well as those with pain such as repetitive stress, fatigue or visual impairment. 

Our occupational therapists assess what the parent or grandparent needs to do specific babycare tasks (such as feeding, bathing, holding or diapering), and then brings specially adapted equipment to the home.  This equipment enables a parent or grandparent with disabilities to more easily care for their child.  These services are home-based and free of cost to eligible families in Alameda and Contra Costa counties.

TLG has conducted 3 national studies on the effectiveness of adaptive babycare equipment and found that such equipment can have a positive impact on parent/baby interaction, in addition to reducing difficulty, pain, and fatigue and  preventing secondary disability complications.  Babycare equipment also can substantially affect positive outcomes in custody and adoption situations.

Although our staff occupational therapists are available to work with parents and grandparents, TLG currently no longer has funds to purchase equipment or to cover the costs of having equipment modified to fit the particular needs of a parent or grandparent with a disability.  We want to raise funds so that we will be able to purchase or adapt babycare equipment that can be loaned to parents and grandparents with disabilities in Alameda and Contra Costa Counties. 

Without appropriate adaptive equipment, many parents and grandparents with disabilities face increased pain, fatigue and often significant difficulties caring for their young children. In the most extreme cases, parents may lose custody of their children because they do not have access to such equipment that can help them care for their child.  Our goal is to raise at least $2,000 so that parents and grandparents with disabilities can get the adaptive equipment they need to care for their child.  Your donation is tax-deductible.

Anyone contributing $250 or more will have the option of having their name inscribed on a donor leaf on Through the Looking Glass' Donor Tree.  We will contact you for your preferred wording (your name, or perhaps in memory or honor of someone else).  You can see our Donor Tree on our website www.lookingglass.org.

story:
We are an organization designed around flag football.  Our vision is to provide communities with a fun, fresh, and cost effective option for youth and adults to learn, grow, and excel through sports.  With the community being our main focus, our priority is just that, the community.  A portion of our proceeds will be divided between a liking of our charities that reach multiple communities.  We are not a private charity.  Donations, fund raising, and investors is where our main source of income will come from.  We do not discriminate based on race, religion, or gender.


     We are two guys that hail from Aurora, CO attempting to do something great, something useful to our community and other like communities nationwide. This is our passion!


      I believe the main risk is failing, There is a lot involved with running a business, Even more once our vision travels out of our home state. We've always loved the saying without risk there is no reward, our reward being able to provide a fun safe atmosphere where people can compete or participate in one of Americas's favorite sports (Flag-Football).

      Our challenges are many, including locating parks/sporting complexes in safe active areas to hold our events, sponsors, fair referees, Cost, fees, trash, recycling, security and more. Not to mention that our businesses success lies in the hands and hearts of those to love to compete and have fun. So without others contributions to our cause the possibility of failure increases. 


        We also Specialize in youth developmental camps. In these camps we provide a positive atmosphere where kids from ages 8 to 14 can come and learn about the game of flag-football. Activities ranging from controlled foot and hand working drills to 7 on 7 in camp Flag Football tournaments! All at no cost to the participant. Registration is on first come first serve bases.

story:
Brain Bit: Language Enhancement Tracker - A Wearable Device for Families



Brain Bit is an enchanting, electronic device that allows families to measure your child's brain training by counting the words in their language environment. Brain Bit provides parents with real time feedback about how stimulating your child's environment is by glowing to indicate when you reach various language milestones throughout your day, in real time. 

                           

To track your brain training Brain Bit syncs with the app on your device so you can track and measure brain stimulation over time. 

                                                   

You and your family can set your own brain training goals or follow the "daily recommended" goals that are based on research. It's like Fitbit, but for your brain!  

       



You can wear Brain Bit as a wrist piece or as a pendant. 

                                

                           

You can now track your brain training the same way you track your physical fitness training.

How does Brain Bit do this? 

By leveraging sophisticated technology.

 Brain Bit technology available for ALL families.

                



Benefits for all, with a focus on the family.

Brain Bit is designed for and effective for users of all ages. No matter your age, tracking your brain training can strengthen under-used neural connections and help build new neural pathways (in neuroscience this is called brain plasticity). This is true throughout life - for newborns, teenagers, adults and seniors. However, our focus is on moms, dads, kids, sitters, nannies and early childhood caregivers. Our focus is on the family!

Why Brain Bit?

Brain Bit tracks language and helps you measure your brain training. Why do you need a Brain Bit? Because tracking language can help you build a stronger brain for you and your child! 

Frankenstein prototypes
Early on we wanted to prove out some of the speech recognition software using some basic, off the shelf hardware and software.

                

These images show a breadboard with a simplified schematic for getting the Brain Bit prototype to blink or glow as it counts the voice (word) inputs. 


    Why is this campaign important to us?

    Ninety percent of brain development occurs during the first five years of life. Research shows that kindergarteners who start school more than 18 months behind their peers never catch up. We believe, based on copious research and professional and personal experience, that the early years of life are the most critical time for learners. These years determine the trajectory of a life. 

    For the better half of a decade we have been committed to empowering families by putting the tools in their hands to help them put their child on the right track for success in life. 

    By contributing to this campaign your are not only acquiring a tool that will empower you and your family, but you will be helping us further our mission of empowering every family to be their child's best teacher - starting from birth!


    Contributors to our Phase I fundraising will receive vouchers to receive a Brain Bit. Once we achieve our Phase II fundraising goals contributors in Phase I will receive their Brain Bit. 

    If we don't reach our entire goal the funds will go 100% to the continued development of Brain Bit. 

    If we do not reach our goal some perks will not be able to be claimed. The most obvious one is that if we do not reach our goal we won't be able to send you the Brain Bit that we've previewed here. Even if we do not reach our campaign goal, though, there is still a chance that we may be able to deliver on a more modest version of the Brain Bit previewed here. Our mission and our passion is to provide a device that supports brain training and development at all ages. Even if we do not reach our goal we believe we will be able to progress with this mission and that our supporters will benefit. 

    The Brain Bit timeline.

    Prototypes: Currently we do not have a fully functioning prototype. The photos in the campaign are engineered renderings of what we envision Brain Bit to look like. The Brain Bit system is based on existing speech recognition software and wearable technology capabilities. As a team of experts with experience in wearable technology production based here in the USA we will do our best to deliver on the ideal presented in this campaign. At all stages of development we will keep you posted, remain transparent, and, at times, seek out your input along the way. 

    Production: We are employing technologies that currently exist. Some of the technologies have not been used in the combinations or with the modifications that we have designed. However, the engineering, production and manufacturing processes are overseen by experts who have successfully delivered on projects more complex than Bran Bit. 

    Delivery times: We are excited that you have chosen to support us in our mission to help make early childhood brain training a more measurable reality for all families. With your support we believe that we will be able to deliver on our proposed timeline. 

    Risks and challenges

    There are always risks when moving from prototype to full scale manufacturing. Some of those risks include a jump in the cost of components, increased manufacturing costs, unforeseen technical challenges in the microprocessors or circuit boards. 

    We have experience manufacturing other products both overseas and in the US. Our team has always been able to manufacture our products within our researched cost analyses and budgets.

    Other risks are our estimated retail pricing. For some resellers being able to make a certain margin is important to their bottom line. It is also important that we are able to make a sustainable profit. We have done our best to estimate the retail prices beyond this campaign, but we can't guarantee they will hold. Prices may go up, or prices may go down. 

    We want to be very clear: if we do not reach our full goal of $175,000 you may not receive a Brain Bit within the time frame, and possibly not ever. By pledging your contribution you are showing your support for further development of Brain Bit. And at this phase we need all the support you can muster so we can do 2 things: (1) prove there is demand for Brain Bit and (2) continue the development of Brain Bit. 

    As well, because of the nature of this campaign, there will be no refunds available for any of the perks. 

    Other ways you can contribute to Brain Bit.

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Call your group of mommy friends and tell them to blog or Tweet about Brain Bit
    • Is there a store where you would love to see Brain Bit? Tell us about it!
    • Don't have the money to pay for one of the perks above? You can be an affiliate campaigner!
    • Of course, remember: share, share, share! 
    • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
    • Give $1! Each dollar we raise is like a vote. It's proving demand for this idea.

    All it takes is a Tweet! Help us change the world measuring one word at a time!

    Thanks,

    Team Brain Bit

Other ways you can contribute to Brain Bit.
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Call your group of mommy friends and tell them to blog or Tweet about Brain Bit
Is there a store where you would love to see Brain Bit? Tell us about it!
Don't have the money to pay for one of the perks above? You can be an affiliate campaigner!
Of course, remember: share, share, share! 
Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
Give $1! Each dollar we raise is like a vote. It's proving demand for this idea.


All it takes is a Tweet! Help us change the world measuring one word at a time!
Thanks,
Team Brain Bit

story:
I am from Durbar Square, Kathmandu, and have lived in UK for the last 18 years. The earthquake in Nepal was horrific. Luckily most of my family survived, and are now working to help others there by setting up food stations in Durbar Square. There are many people in the area who are invisible to the aid agencies. For example, people who have come from the villages to sell vegetables each day in Durbar Square to scratch a living each day. Now there are no vegetables to sell and many of them are homeless, others cannot stay in their houses as they have been badly damaged so they living rough.

Other people have crowded together in remaining houses and food is scarce. There are so many people in this small area who really need simple help - food, water, shelter. There is no benefits system at all in Nepal so people are left to their own devices. There are lots and lots of people in Nepal at the moment who need help, but we are focusing on this area where we can feed people each day and provide money for medical assistance, or whatever is needed. As my brothers live here, they can see exactly who is in need. The photograph is of my brothers and their wives providing food to needy Nepalese people in the Durbar Square area. We fed around 200 people this day. I will add photos to this site as we help more people. This is what we can do to help. We need your help them. I am heartbroken by what has happened to my country and I am far away, but at least I can help from here. I will be going to Nepal soon, and will be a more 'hands on' helper. I would really appreciate any small amount you could donate to help our team support our fellow countrymen. Every small amount will help. Thank-you.
