story:
What We're Doing

In the wake of the tragedy at Sandy Hook Elementary School, Newtown has found that its greatest source of healing has been in helping. Ben's Lighthouse, a non-profit youth support organization named for named for 6-year-old victim Ben Wheeler and his love of lighthouses, was founded on that mission: to bring joy back into the lives and smiles back onto the faces of Newtown's children.

The purpose of a lighthouse is to guide and protect, and that is how we see our role. We will establish programs, events and activities that enlighten and affirm each child in a safe environment: we will encourage conversation to gain understanding of how each child is coping; we will provide counsel and support when needed; we will recruit and utilize experts to deal with life’s events and circumstances that could be particularly troublesome for our kids; we will generate activities that promote a positive self-image and, for the older youth, that encourage community service. Throughout all these activities, we will always nurture an environment of non-violence and caring towards self and others.

Now, Ben's Lighthouse wants to send 40 of Newtown's kids (aged 14-18) on a mission trip (through the Group Workcamps organization) to Oklahoma to work on the restoration of homes destroyed in the tornadoes. This trip will provide Newtown's kids with the oppurtunity to meet and help those whose lives have been completely disrupted, and to experience the healing power that comes from helping others.

What We Need and What You Get

Including airfare, food, and lodging, it will cost about $1000 to send one kid on this trip. We're running this campaign because the more we can bring that cost down, the more kids we can support to go heal by helping.

$1 gets you the insanely good feeling that you've contributed to something amazing.

$20 gets you a sticker featuring the Newtown logo and ribbon that you can put on your car, laptop, water bottle, etc. and the insanely good feeling that you've contributed to something amazing.

$100 gets you a Ben's Lighthouse t-shirt and the insanely good feeling that you've contributed to something amazing.

$1000 makes you the official sponsor of a young adult on the Group Workcamps trip. You will receieve a letter from an attendee of the trip about their experiences. You'll also get a Ben's Lighthouse t-shirt and the insanely good feeling that you've contributed to something amazing.

$20000...let's  face it: You're not looking for a tshirt...you're just looking to help. We love you. You're welcome in Newtown any time. We'll have a nice dinner. (And don't worry, you can still have that t-shirt if you want it!)

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with anyone and everyone.

Help a child today, even if it's in a small way.

 

(Participants will be added to the trip based on funds raised through this site and other fundraising efforts, subject to availability of flights and an appropriate chaperone-to-youth ratio.  Any excess funds raised through this campaign which cannot be spent specifically for this trip will be applied to future Ben's Lighthouse initiatives.)
story_txt:
What We're Doing
In the wake of the tragedy at Sandy Hook Elementary School, Newtown has found that its greatest source of healing has been in helping. Ben's Lighthouse, a non-profit youth support organization named for named for 6-year-old victim Ben Wheeler and his love of lighthouses, was founded on that mission: to bring joy back into the lives and smiles back onto the faces of Newtown's children.

The purpose of a lighthouse is to guide and protect, and that is how we see our role. We will establish programs, events and activities that enlighten and affirm each child in a safe environment: we will encourage conversation to gain understanding of how each child is coping; we will provide counsel and support when needed; we will recruit and utilize experts to deal with life’s events and circumstances that could be particularly troublesome for our kids; we will generate activities that promote a positive self-image and, for the older youth, that encourage community service. Throughout all these activities, we will always nurture an environment of non-violence and caring towards self and others.
Now, Ben's Lighthouse wants to send 40 of Newtown's kids (aged 14-18) on a mission trip (through the Group Workcamps organization) to Oklahoma to work on the restoration of homes destroyed in the tornadoes. This trip will provide Newtown's kids with the oppurtunity to meet and help those whose lives have been completely disrupted, and to experience the healing power that comes from helping others.
What We Need and What You Get


Including airfare, food, and lodging, it will cost about $1000 to send one kid on this trip. We're running this campaign because the more we can bring that cost down, the more kids we can support to go heal by helping.
$1 gets you the insanely good feeling that you've contributed to something amazing.
$20 gets you a sticker featuring the Newtown logo and ribbon that you can put on your car, laptop, water bottle, etc. and the insanely good feeling that you've contributed to something amazing.
$100 gets you a Ben's Lighthouse t-shirt and the insanely good feeling that you've contributed to something amazing.
$1000 makes you the official sponsor of a young adult on the Group Workcamps trip. You will receieve a letter from an attendee of the trip about their experiences. You'll also get a Ben's Lighthouse t-shirt and the insanely good feeling that you've contributed to something amazing.
$20000...let's  face it: You're not looking for a tshirt...you're just looking to help. We love you. You're welcome in Newtown any time. We'll have a nice dinner. (And don't worry, you can still have that t-shirt if you want it!)


Other Ways You Can Help
Share this campaign with anyone and everyone.
Help a child today, even if it's in a small way.
 
(Participants will be added to the trip based on funds raised through this site and other fundraising efforts, subject to availability of flights and an appropriate chaperone-to-youth ratio.  Any excess funds raised through this campaign which cannot be spent specifically for this trip will be applied to future Ben's Lighthouse initiatives.)

story:
The Long and Short of It

Greetings from Kuala Terengganu, Malaysia! My name is Zack Wiener, and I am an American teaching English under the auspice of the Fulbright English Teaching Assistant program. I teach at Sekolah Kebangsaan Seberang Takir, a small primary school (years 4 - 12) in a fishing village outside of Kuala Terengganu, on the east coast of Malaysia. As a part of my job, I am committed to making English a living language for the students. In many cases, the Malaysian English language curriculum fails to instill a sense of vibrancy that the language has to offer. I seek to get students excited about speaking English through the use of media in the classroom. Primarily, I try my best to expose students to people around the world speaking English, whether through YouTube clips, short films, student-produced videos, and other media. However, there is rarely a way for me to show media to a whole class; many times, I have thirty-eight students crowd around my 13-inch laptop to show movies. My school's English department is in desperate need of an LCD projector, and I am turning to indiegogo for help!

 

The Shopping List

Since teachers in Malaysia move between classes (rather than students), I envision a “media cart” that I (or another teacher, of course) can roll from class to class. This cart would have an LCD projector, but many other components are necessary for the equipment to be successful. Namely:

  • A case for the electronic equipment – most of the classroom are exposed to the elements (due to the heat), and humidity and rain could damage the equipment

  • High-Quality Speakers – the classrooms at SKST are semi-enclosed and acoustically challenging

  • Surge-protected extension cord – many of the outlets in the classrooms are located high on the wall and far from the board.

  • Low-cost mobile projecting screen – for classrooms that do not have a screen or a clean wall.

  • A durable cart – to facilitate the mobility of the whole apparatus

 

Many of the materials here (the cart, the extension cords, and perhaps the speakers) are made here in Malaysia and therefore do not have a high tariff markup. The other goods (the LCD projector, case, and speakers) generally are imported from China, Japan, or Korea, making them subject to high import taxes and adding cost to the project. Therefore, what might seem like a cheap project in America is in practice much more expensive in Malaysia. Nevertheless, if I do not receive funding to my goal, I plan on using the funds foremost to buy the projector.

 

The Impact

Malaysian students—certainly my students—unfortunately are not exposed to much English outside of their classrooms. My students live in a fishing village outside of a town that gets little tourists passing through. Without exposure to English as a living language, I fear the students will never see a point to using English outside of their classroom. Furthermore, English opens up students to a world much larger than their community. I hope the media startup will impact the children by showing them examples of how to us English and live in a global society. I also hope that the media startup will show students that there are other people around the world learning English just like them. Overall, I hope that the program will broaden my students' horizons and help them become citizens of the English-speaking world.

 

Short On Ringgit?

No ringgit? No problem! If you don't have the means to help monetarily, please feel free to spread the word or to point me to other sources of funding. Though I intend this to be a short-term fundraising project, it's good to know about other opportunities in the future.

 

Thank you, and terima kasih!

 

Zack Wiener

Fulbright English Teaching Assistant

Sekolah Kebangsaan Seberang Takir

Kuala Terengganu, Malaysia

story:
THE SCHOOL

 

Good Shepherd Montessori School in South Bend, Indiana, was founded in 2002, opening its doors with a starting class of 16 elementary school children. Since then, weâ€™ve grown to over 100 students, but the mission of the school remains the same: education based on the work of Maria Montessori that fosters peace in a socio-economically, racially and ethnically diverse environment.

 

Roughly a third of our students depend on scholarship money. We partner with the Center for the Homeless, a local organization, to enroll kids transitioning out of homelessness in our school at no cost to their families, from first grade through eighth. We have a disproportionally large number of children who are on the Aspergerâ€™s/Autism. Children who often donâ€™t â€œfitâ€ in traditional school settings frequently find the support to succeed at Good Shepherd.

 

Good Shepherd is about celebrating the miracle of every child.

 

 

THE MUSIC PROGRAM

 

Music is a unique opportunity for children to hone technical, creative and communication skills. In an age when most schools are downsizing arts programs, we continue to see regular musical exposure and practice as an invaluable part of child development and growth.

 

Our Orff music program offers children some of the best instruction available in the area. Similar to the Montessori method of teaching, the Orff Method of music education, developed by German composer and educator Carl Orff, follows the natural musical responses of children and incorporates them into satisfying musical experiences created and performed by the children themselves.

 

Directed by teacher Kathy Oyer, D.M.A., children routinely practice the basics, such as learning to stay with the beat, and playing with others. In addition, they all learn about and practice improvisation. Orff allows them the joy of performing together and sounding great while still in the early stages of musical training.

 

Watch the video to learn more about what the program does, and see the kids in action!

 

 

THE FACTS

 

As a school, we are largely focused on raising money for scholarships and pressing building renovation and maintenance issues. Weâ€™ve had success raising fundsâ€”we received over $250,000 last year from private donors alone, and continue to expand partnerships critical for our long-term stabilityâ€”but these achievements have not touched on the music program, a separate budget item.

 

Weâ€™ve seen how the music program has benefited our students. From the shy student who begins to feel comfortable with herself as she hammers out a tune, to the higher level of trust among kids after theyâ€™ve found a groove together in the music room, the outcomes are real. There is a certain learning that comes from music and no other place. Itâ€™s become integral to how our children learn at Good Shepherd.

 

Music education is a unique medium for developing creativity, cooperation, and self-expression in children. It just doesnâ€™t pay the billsâ€”but it does much more!

 

 

YOU

 

Why contribute to the music program at a private school? The simple answer is that youâ€™re not just helping children, youâ€™re taking part in a successful, whole-child model of education.

 

At Good Shepherd, teachers evaluate student growth on factors from emotional growth to abstract thinking, not standardized testing. They teach conflict resolution. Each class partners with a local farm, works on it throughout the year, then eats, sells, and gives away their harvest. Thereâ€™s sledding during recess in the winter. Younger students volunteer at an Alzheimerâ€™s Day Center and older students work at Our Lady of the Road, a Catholic Worker Day Shelter. Thereâ€™s a nutrition curriculum. The Junior High class runs a coffee shop mornings in the school to raise money for their end of the year trip to a destination of their choosing, which they plan and present to their teachers and parents. Itâ€™s truly a unique place where children can come into their own power to create. And they do this with the guiding partnership and care of the teachers at the school, a group of enthusiastic creators themselves. Music is a part of our culture as art, skill development, joy, and creative exploration.

 

Jonathan Larsen wrote that â€œPeace isnâ€™t the opposite of war, creation is.â€ At Good Shepherd kids are learning math and reading and all thatâ€”and learning it quite well. But at the heart of how they learn it and what they learn it for is this central lesson of creating something with their knowledge and work that fulfills them and others, and leads them even one step furtherâ€”to love.

 

Our IndieGoGo goal is $8,000. Though this doesnâ€™t cover the cost of the music program for the school year of 2012, we could leverage it for matching funds in addition to the media attention that a successful IndieGoGo campaign provides. We want lots of contributors, big and small, all saying, with their dollars, that quality music education deserves to be a part of childhood.

 

We plan to maximize both the process and results of our campaign through local media outlets and funding circles to show that not only can we effectively raise money for this project, but that the process of trying itself helps build awareness of the importance of the cause.

 

Join us and the kids! Many instruments together are more than the sum of their parts.

 

Thanks for your contribution to keep the music playing at Good Shepherd.

story:
For some, it was last year, for other it was perhaps 10 years and for others 20; no matter how long it has been since you last walked the halls at INSEAD, we’re pretty sure you still refer to INSEAD as one of the best years of your life. 

But, whilst we can imagine what made your year so amazing, the people, the parties, the trips, the classes; we can only think of one week that summarizes why INSEAD is and always will be the best year of our lives:

The National Weeks

This is an unique opportunity to experience a different culture, new food, discover traditional dances, sports and of course, the drinks and how the locals party!!! And who best knows how to party but the Latinos. This year, we are  Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Guatemala, Mexico, Peru, El Salvador, Venezuela and for the first time ever Haitians launching the best Latin-American Week ever! But we cannot do it without YOUR help…Any donation is welcome! 

So, please help us bring the Latin American to life; we want our INSEAD classmates to truly experience the best we have to offer:

-          Culture: our warmth, our carnival our music

-          History: from slavery to modern growth region

-          Economic development: the current investment opportunities

The food, the music, the drinks, the party, the warmth and the culture of Latin America is awaiting to be unleashed and we hope you’ll support us.

Our goal is to reach 5,000 euros so please donate and help us make this National Week a success!

story:
Our Story

Hello, my name is Paul Herve. I'm the Producer of this documentary: The Mystery of the Mansoor Amarna Collection


ANY CONTRIBUTION ARE WELCOME: $10 - $20 - $30 - $50 what ever you can....


The Cursed Treasure is an archaeological detective story.



The Impact: 


       Inside the depths of a Beverly Hills bank vault reside 33 pieces from one of the most controversial collections of ancient Egyptian art in history. Virtually unknown to all but a handful of Egyptologists and archaeologists, this collection of antiquities from the Amarna period, owned by the Mansoor family, has been at the heart of an unprecedented dispute between scientists and art historians for over fifty years.


     The Collection was once insured for $200 million. If genuine, it could be worth a billion dollars, but if the collection is a forgery, it would be the biggest scandal of the century. With unprecedented access to each of the exquisite pieces and exclusive interviews with several world-renowned authorities, the film exposes the intriguing history of both the collection and the fierce, almost conspiratorial, controversy surrounding it. 


Could the Mansoor Amarna collection be subject to the same curse as Akhenaton? Who was this visionary pharaoh who commited the crime to believe in only one God? 


From the USA to Egypt via France, Italy, Britain and Germany, this investigative documentary travels across the globe to museums such as the Boston Fine Arts Museum, the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, the Louvre, the Vatican, the Berlin Museum, as well as other captivating places such as the ruins of Akhenaton's capital in Tel-El-Amarna, Egypt. It will consist of  a judicious combination of video sequences, interviews, archival footage and photographs. 


A true detective investigation in the murky waters of the art world, The Show will recount the incredible story of the Mansoor collection through the testimonies of all of those - - who have, directly or indirectly, been linked to the polemic: Egyptologists, scientists, museum curators and art historians. 


"When all the logical conjectures have been set aside, the one that remains, as improbable as it may seem, is likely to be true." 
Sir Arthur Conan Doyle A.K.A- Sherlock Holmes -


What We Need: 
    I'm seeking funding to hire a Video Editor for 5 months.I found a great person for $1000 a month and a back-end deal. The production of the documentary is done. We now have more than 100 hours of footage to edit. We went to Egypt twice with the collection's owner. We are ready to edit now...


Other Ways You Can Help
Please make sure to ask folks around you to get the word out and make some noise about this fund-raising campaign. Please use the share tools!

story:
Visit us at: www.grenelabs.com

Donate Now- Together We Can Open Up Diagnostics!

Our lab-on-a-chip will be affordable to developing countries. Period. We working very hard to find novel ways to manufacture our lab-on-a-chip in a way that maintains its affordability, reproducibility, and most importantly their accuracy. This way outbreaks of HIV, HSV, and other such diseases plaguing the developing world can be contained and treated quickly. There are many diseases which we wish to be able to find via our lab-on-the-chips by completing our stretch goals. This will allow us to automate the data collection and reveal diseases and infections which require further steps to diagnose. 

Help Propel Research.

Starting up a lab can be costly. It leaves the researcher, despite his or her goals, to take up research which will receive grants. Our lab-on-a-chip reduces the amount of reagents and other materials needed to do testing. Not to mention saving thousands on the actual machines needed to perform testing. Making gene research, and diagnostics, more attainable opens researchers to follow aspirations of cures and discovery. It should be noted that capillary electrophoresis, which is utilized on one of our prototype lab-on-a-chips, is used frequently for pharmaceutical development. It is a relevant, but less important goal to us with this project. 

Our Roots

Grenelabs was founded on a simple idea; the idea that we can make science open and affordable. We were able to do this with our electrophoresis systems- which we offer as a high incentive for this Indiegogo. These sytems allow you to sequence DNA traditionally by size and mass, and are used in foresnics, diagnostics, and research.

I realized soon enough that I wanted Grenelabs to not only make affordable systems, but novel ones as well. We work(ed) late nights with the goal of making diagnostics open and affordable. We went through many prototypes- inspired by new studies on the science of microfluidics. 

After months of hustle and exhausting work we've achieved what we consider a huge step in diagnostics; the ability to perform diagnostics away from labs, and on something half the size of a credit card. In doing so, we exhausted our funding to finish the project and now turn to the community to help us produce these revolutionary bio-microchips.



Consolidating Designs

There are three designs which we hope to consolidate, or at least run in a modular fashion, together.


Prototype 1: Capillary Electrophoresis (CE) Chip

Capillary Electrophoresis is the ability to separate samples based on their ionic charge. Much like traditional electrophoresis, a conductive medium is used for species to travel from the negative to the positive electrode. Separating DNA by size and mass, in capillary electrophoresis, allows the ability to detect genetic mutations. This can be done by eye in some cases, while in other cases it requires extra hardware and software.

             


This is a common T channel microfluidic chip. For the time being this design propels the sample electrokenetically, and uses droplet tension to retrieve the sample via the Pump Port. The CE chip is first filled with TBE buffer (the conductive medium). Afterwards, the buffer is removed from the sample reservoir which is replaced with the sample via pipette. Once the sample is loaded, we use the electrodes (~70-80V) to start the separation of the sample. The separation occurs at about (1cm/min) at this voltage. Running a higher voltage can risk the broadening and breaking of bands. Once the sample reaches the the intersection, the voltage is cut and the process of retrieval begins. For retrieval, we have three options: electrokenetically, pumps, and passive pumping. Passive pumping is the most ideal for our purposes as we want to take steps to make this chip in as autonomous as possible (goo.gl/VuSnjs). Passive pumping, in this case, involves using a micropipette to deliver a fixed ratio of fluid between the pumping and retrieval port with hydrophobic surfaces. On this scale, smaller liquid droplets flow into larger droplets creating displacement towards the retrieval port. Eventually through this process, the totality of the sample is displaced towards, and extracted via, the retrieval port.
story_txt:
Visit us at: www.grenelabs.com


Donate Now- Together We Can Open Up Diagnostics!
Our lab-on-a-chip will be affordable to developing countries. Period. We working very hard to find novel ways to manufacture our lab-on-a-chip in a way that maintains its affordability, reproducibility, and most importantly their accuracy. This way outbreaks of HIV, HSV, and other such diseases plaguing the developing world can be contained and treated quickly. There are many diseases which we wish to be able to find via our lab-on-the-chips by completing our stretch goals. This will allow us to automate the data collection and reveal diseases and infections which require further steps to diagnose. 

Help Propel Research.
Starting up a lab can be costly. It leaves the researcher, despite his or her goals, to take up research which will receive grants. Our lab-on-a-chip reduces the amount of reagents and other materials needed to do testing. Not to mention saving thousands on the actual machines needed to perform testing. Making gene research, and diagnostics, more attainable opens researchers to follow aspirations of cures and discovery. It should be noted that capillary electrophoresis, which is utilized on one of our prototype lab-on-a-chips, is used frequently for pharmaceutical development. It is a relevant, but less important goal to us with this project. 

Our Roots
Grenelabs was founded on a simple idea; the idea that we can make science open and affordable. We were able to do this with our electrophoresis systems- which we offer as a high incentive for this Indiegogo. These sytems allow you to sequence DNA traditionally by size and mass, and are used in foresnics, diagnostics, and research.
I realized soon enough that I wanted Grenelabs to not only make affordable systems, but novel ones as well. We work(ed) late nights with the goal of making diagnostics open and affordable. We went through many prototypes- inspired by new studies on the science of microfluidics. 
After months of hustle and exhausting work we've achieved what we consider a huge step in diagnostics; the ability to perform diagnostics away from labs, and on something half the size of a credit card. In doing so, we exhausted our funding to finish the project and now turn to the community to help us produce these revolutionary bio-microchips.















Consolidating Designs
There are three designs which we hope to consolidate, or at least run in a modular fashion, together.


Prototype 1: Capillary Electrophoresis (CE) ChipCapillary Electrophoresis is the ability to separate samples based on their ionic charge. Much like traditional electrophoresis, a conductive medium is used for species to travel from the negative to the positive electrode. Separating DNA by size and mass, in capillary electrophoresis, allows the ability to detect genetic mutations. This can be done by eye in some cases, while in other cases it requires extra hardware and software.

             
This is a common T channel microfluidic chip. For the time being this design propels the sample electrokenetically, and uses droplet tension to retrieve the sample via the Pump Port. The CE chip is first filled with TBE buffer (the conductive medium). Afterwards, the buffer is removed from the sample reservoir which is replaced with the sample via pipette. Once the sample is loaded, we use the electrodes (~70-80V) to start the separation of the sample. The separation occurs at about (1cm/min) at this voltage. Running a higher voltage can risk the broadening and breaking of bands. Once the sample reaches the the intersection, the voltage is cut and the process of retrieval begins. For retrieval, we have three options: electrokenetically, pumps, and passive pumping. Passive pumping is the most ideal for our purposes as we want to take steps to make this chip in as autonomous as possible (goo.gl/VuSnjs). Passive pumping, in this case, involves using a micropipette to deliver a fixed ratio of fluid between the pumping and retrieval port with hydrophobic surfaces. On this scale, smaller liquid droplets flow into larger droplets creating displacement towards the retrieval port. Eventually through this process, the totality of the sample is displaced towards, and extracted via, the retrieval port.

story:
Hello and Thanks


In January, I will be setting off for a 3 month assignment in Ecuador to bring the children of Banos de Agua Santa the joy of art! 

As you can see by the video, Fundacion Arte del Mundo is a program for children in this small Ecuadoran community to enhance imagination and creativity in the children.  It receives no government funding, is not affiliated with any organization or church, and is funded solely by donations and run by volunteers.  

I have totally funded my personal travel and living expenses from my savings.  All donations made to this campaign will be directly spent on art supplies for the children of FAM.  I want to make clear that 100% of any amount you donate will go to the children of Banos de Agua Santa.

Everything you see in the video is because of generous people like you.  Without this generosity, FAM would not exist.
You might also notice in the video that beyond the tireless efforts of the volunteers and the support of key benefactors, most of the current art programs have little in the way of the tools and supplies needed to create art past the point of crayons, paint, paper, and string.
I would like to change that and hope to introduce these children to art created from other resources, while keeping the focus on found, re-purposed, and recycled items as our main source of "art supplies". 
I'm asking for your help in bringing more substantial supplies, such as inks for screen printing, tools for jewelry making, raw materials for making fun dough, polymer clay substitutes, paints, wire and metal for jewelry making, and household items used to create a variety of art supplies.  I also intend to introduce the children (and the volunteers) to some of the culinary experience I have acquired while teaching basic food preparation skills.

My name is Stephen Lacroix, my friends call me Steve.

I'm am retiring at the end of the year from my 3rd and final professional "career" position.  Most recently, I have held a position with the State of Montana Department of Labor and Industry as an employment analyst.  Prior to this "career" I worked for Waldenbooks supervising store operations in the states of the Western US, from Montana to Las Vegas.  In my early professional life, I served as a Regional Director for a multinational food service company, where I ran company operations for 5 western states, including Alaska. 

Now with the confidence of my life experience, and the skills I've acquired over 40 plus years in business and government, I want to give back something to people less fortunate than myself or my family.

I've always had a talent as a "maker of things" and always an adventurous traveler.  I have lived in 10 states and have visited almost all 50.  I have traveled on several occasions into the interior of Mexico and into the wild of the Canadian and Alaskan wilderness.

I have always enjoyed the creative aspects of any business I've been involved in, the creative part of creating something from nothing and leaving a mark.

I fix things, remodel homes,  I paint, I craft, I build furniture, I build bicycles, I create art from nature and especially I enjoy creating from what others have discarded or from items whose original purpose is far removed from anything faintly resembling art.  If I have sticks, stones, string, plastic bottles, old wire, nails, rags, newspapers, magazines, etc, I have art! And if I can show others how to see my vision, I can accomplish my goal.  With your generous contributions, I can take their understanding and skills beyond the elementary, and to a higher level of skill and appreciation.
This is the passion I want to share with the children of Ecuador.  And this is why I need your help. 

I have already sent 2 shipments of supplies (one of art supplies, and one of 1st aid supplies).  Unfortunately,  the cost of supplies and tools is high in Ecuador, and the cost of shipping even discount purchases from the US to Ecuador is very expensive.  And unfortunately, the reduced expense of supplies versus savings is almost a wash.  By funding this campaign, you will help me accumulate supplies and tools in Ecuador for the ongoing needs of the school.  My intention is to raise funds and as I travel through the capital city of Quito and the provincial city of Ambato, to make purchases which I can then easily ship or carry to the Fundacion in Banos de Aqua Santa. In some cases, the supplies will consist of ordinary household items and products such as corn starch, flour, vinegar, rubbing alcohol, etc.  In other cases, the supplies will be a bit more formal, such as canvas for stretching, screens and vinyl for screen printing, paint brushes, a heat gun, an iron, a toaster oven (for dedicated clay projects), tools for jewelry making, a dremel type rotary tool, a drill, bits, some jewelers saws, blades, a drill, files, and perhaps a sewing machine.  Ideally, by the time my assignment is over, the school will be supplied with enough raw materials and tools to last many months and perhaps years into the future.
I have totally funded my travel and living expenses from my savings.  All donations made to this campaign will go for the express purpose of supplying the school as mentioned above.  I want to make clear, that 100% of any amount you donate will go to the children of Banos de Agua Santa. 
I've set a goal of $3000 to fund this project.  Naturally, more contributions mean more supplies and tools.  I intend to use every donation for the children.  Who knows, you may be helping the next Picasso, Renoir, La Trec, Dale Chihuly, or Martha Stewart!
I have a track record of funding  programs through Kiva since 2007.  I haven't set the world on fire, but I've loaned almost $500 to 18 people in countries from Ecuador, to Lebanon to Togo, to Peru.  Most of these loans have been made to hard working people in a number of endeavors, but all have been "producers" of some sort.  I continue to support these people and look for people who are "doers".
I have funded a few projects at Kickstarter and Indigogo.  One project is developing a unique light for under developed communities, a couple of game developers, and a guy in Montana who makes wallets from recycled inner tubes.  I've donated to campaigns to help reduce the infant mortality rate on the Lakota Sioux Reservation, and helped a campaign to give aid and comfort to blind animals (Ray has been rescued!)
I know the type of people who donate to projects on crowd funding sites and micro lending sites and I'm appealing to you because if you've read to here, you are one of those people.
Please donate.  I will keep you posted on what your donations are doing and post pictures of the children and their projects.  If you choose not to donate, that's OK, but please spread the word through Indiegogo's share tools and via your own social networking pages (and tweets).
Thanks for your interest.  I'm going to Ecuador in January.  My ability to complete this effort is strong.  Help me make it stronger.

Regards,
Steve

story:
Background

Santa Maria Community Services' International Welcome Center (IWC) provides English as a Second Language (ESL) classes for adult immigrants in Price Hill and beyond. English language learned in the ESL classes, helps individuals become more acclimated to the life and customs in their new home country, as well as improve their marketability for jobs. The IWC also provides free childcare for the children of ESL students during the class time, where the children receive tutoring and participate in enrichment activities.

We would like to provide a Mad Science class and expose the children to the wonderful world of science. We think that this is a great program to enrich and expose students to the science field early on. The field of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) field desires an increase in diversity, and we believe that this exposure to science early on can motivate, give students of diverse backgrounds the confidence to experience and pursue science in the future. 

What We Need

In order to provide this Mad Science program twice a year to the children of ESL students, we need $500.00 to cover the class registration and materials. We have every belief that we can reach our goal of $500.00 with your support, however in the event that we do not reach the goal we will offer one Mad Science class and continue to fundraise in other ways to reach the goal for two classes. 

You will get personalized updates on progress and success of the Mad Science class, acknowledgement from the children benefiting from the class, and most importantly you will know that your contribution has made a positive impact and has helped families help themselves. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about the campaign, share the link through your E-mail, Facebook, Twitter, and other social media outlets. The more people we reach, the greater the chance that these children will have a chance to experience the wonderful world of science.

story:
OUR CURRENT PROJECT

108 Lives Australia is currently working on "Bringing Computer Literacy to Underprivileged Students" at Mt Summit Boarding School. This work is a continuation of the 108 lives Project, a pilot project originating in Nepal.

"My personal connection with these students is what helps to drive me to do better for them. It is astounding to see how they cope when you hear of their personal backgrounds and circumstances. They are so beautiful and so precious, loving and giving. I cherish them and want the best for them."  Bev Carter

This project will be providing a dedicated study space, allowing the students regular access to hands on learning vital to their computer based subjects. The school has only two computers, the office administration computers which the students also share. Students currently do the majority of their computer based lessons from a text book with an hour access rostered  once a month in which to complete assignments. 

Ashbury Public School in Sydney, Australia has helped to kick-start our project with a generous donation being approved by the P&C assoc. The backing from Ashbury staff, parents and students will enable the purchase of several of the 8 computers that Mt Summit are hoping to be able to install for the students use.

With your help, completion of our Project target will be the purchase and installlation of 8 new computers and the transition of a dedicated study space will help to serve these children with a diverse and enriched learning environment. 

 HOW YOUR DONATION WILL BE USED

Our target amount of $5,500 will help to complete this project.

  • Our minimum goal of $2000 will help our volunteers in getting to Nepal. This will help to subsidise travel and accommodation expenses.
  • $3,500 has been targeted towards the cost of remaining computers, cabling, internet connectivity and software, online training and teaching resources.

Any amount raised beyond our Project scope will go directly towards further improvements to the school. Have you seen our gallery photos???

Every little bit helps! 

 

WHO WE ARE

108 Lives Australia is a humanitarian not for profit organisation managed and run by Australian volunteers. As a branch the 108lives Project globally, our aim is to address areas of suffering and poverty, to connect with communities in order to help facilitate change for the better, 108 Lives at a time.

Meet the team currently working on this campaign. 

Bev Carter (Coordinator and Communication Liaison) and Jo Grant (Management and Implementation of Technical Logistics) are both volunteers for 108 lives Australia.

108 lives Australia are working in close partnership with the head staff at Mt Summit Boarding School in identifying and addressing the needs of the school. 108 lives Australia is also acting as liason and connection between Mt Summit Boarding School and Ashbury Public School for further planned educational opportunities between the schools.

  

BACKGROUND

Mt Summit Boarding School is based in the Boudha region of Kathmandu, Nepal. 108 Lives Australia and Mt Summit began working in partnership with the pilot project, the 108 lives Project in 2012. It was during this first phase that the needs of Mt Summit were identified. 

Mt Summit Boarding School regularly accept students from poor families or regions, supporting them in gaining the life changing benefit of education. Some of these children both live and learn at the school as their families struggle, often great distances away to make their meager livings. Due to the unfortunate loss of a long time sponsor in 2012, the school were left in dire financial need.

The funds the school currently operate on are barely enough to cover the most basic supplies and learning materials. The executive members of staff take no wage from the school. They earn their living at other teaching jobs at night and work within the school during the day, helping to subsidise the needs of the school and students from their own personal finances.

Of the 400+ enrolments for this school year (2013), 150 students are now directly supported and funded by the school.This includes 10 students from a new orphanage close by also in need of help in supporting their children.

  

THE IMPACT

These beautiful, generous and talented students are dedicated learners and wish to continue further studies to obtain and secure good jobs in order to be able to help  support their families. They are fortunate in being abled to attend a school that works hard in supporting them.

In providing the tools to educate and prepare these students for success in the wider business world, we allow them the opportunity of a better, brighter future.  Their success will help break the cycle of poverty for themselves, their families and their extended communities.

108 Lives Australia are proud to be part of this change; wholeheartedly supporting this school in the belief that education is paramount to affecting social and economic change, and in helping to break the cycle of poverty.

Give…. Share… and be the change!

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

  • Drop by and get to know us better...
  • http://108livesaustralia.org.au/
  • https://www.facebook.com/108livesAustralia?ref=hl
  • Please help to Share this campaign.
  • The Indiegogo share tools are another great way to help us spread the word!
  • You too can Be the Change.

 

WHERE IT ALL BEGAN ?

The 108 lives Project were successful in raising funds before arriving in Nepal in late October 2012. A team of 14 volunteers worked across a series of Project areas including 2 schools, 2 orphanages, Indian camp, and with an organisation providing soup kitchens and medical support to beggars and homeless on the streets.

Bev Carter and Evan Shapiro were head of liason and work with Mt Summit Boarding School. Valuable time spent in discussion with the head of staff provided the opportunity to exchange ideas, as well as learning about the needs of the school and students.

Funds dedicated to Mt Summit Boarding School saw three new storage cupboards and twenty new school benches ordered, which were made locally and helped to provide needed seating for growing student numbers.

The provision of creative learning experiences for the children brought much joy, engagement and expressive opportunities. Play is an integral and important part of learning and development for children and creative expression has emotional and therapeutic benefits. The children participated in painting and drawing, water colours, finger painting, chalk drawing, playdough, bubbles and balloons.

The outcome for the children, who get few opportunities for creative exploration, were delighted with these new experiences, participating with great joy and enthusiasm. The activities and time spent in discussion also helped in identifying focus areas for future work.

http://www.youtube.com/user/108livesproject

 

MEET THE TEAM

Bev Carter is a passionate advocate for the Humanitarian Cause.  She believes we are all of one family, that human connectedness is essential to the well-being for us all and that we can make a difference in this world.

 
Bev has previous experience working in Nepal having been involved with the 108lives original Project in 2012.
 
"I came to 108 lives by serendipity, or perhaps it was something more. But it came at a time in my life when I was wanting that very thing... the opportunity to be able to reach out and touch the lives of others, to make a real difference in the world."
 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f6ruLKMyFVw

 

Jo Grant has been a major driving force in the planning and preparation of this Project. She is a highly motivated, resourceful and task focused individual who is bringing her knowledge and expertise in managing Technical Logistics and Implementation.

Jo's own personal values of equality, fairness, compassion and social justice are what drive her on this path of change. In Jo's own words ...
 
"Everyone deserves a chance. No act of kindness is too small. The gift of kindness and giving may start as a small ripple that over time can turn into a tidal wave affecting the lives of many."

You too can Be the Change.
 
WHERE IT ALL BEGAN ?
The 108 lives Project were successful in raising funds before arriving in Nepal in late October 2012. A team of 14 volunteers worked across a series of Project areas including 2 schools, 2 orphanages, Indian camp, and with an organisation providing soup kitchens and medical support to beggars and homeless on the streets.
Bev Carter and Evan Shapiro were head of liason and work with Mt Summit Boarding School. Valuable time spent in discussion with the head of staff provided the opportunity to exchange ideas, as well as learning about the needs of the school and students.
Funds dedicated to Mt Summit Boarding School saw three new storage cupboards and twenty new school benches ordered, which were made locally and helped to provide needed seating for growing student numbers.
The provision of creative learning experiences for the children brought much joy, engagement and expressive opportunities. Play is an integral and important part of learning and development for children and creative expression has emotional and therapeutic benefits. The children participated in painting and drawing, water colours, finger painting, chalk drawing, playdough, bubbles and balloons.
The outcome for the children, who get few opportunities for creative exploration, were delighted with these new experiences, participating with great joy and enthusiasm. The activities and time spent in discussion also helped in identifying focus areas for future work.
http://www.youtube.com/user/108livesproject
 
MEET THE TEAM
Bev Carter is a passionate advocate for the Humanitarian Cause.  She believes we are all of one family, that human connectedness is essential to the well-being for us all and that we can make a difference in this world. 

 
Bev has previous experience working in Nepal having been involved with the 108lives original Project in 2012. 
 
"I came to 108 lives by serendipity, or perhaps it was something more. But it came at a time in my life when I was wanting that very thing... the opportunity to be able to reach out and touch the lives of others, to make a real difference in the world."
 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f6ruLKMyFVw

 
Jo Grant has been a major driving force in the planning and preparation of this Project. She is a highly motivated, resourceful and task focused individual who is bringing her knowledge and expertise in managing Technical Logistics and Implementation.
Jo's own personal values of equality, fairness, compassion and social justice are what drive her on this path of change. In Jo's own words ...
 

"Everyone deserves a chance. No act of kindness is too small. The gift of kindness and giving may start as a small ripple that over time can turn into a tidal wave affecting the lives of many."

story:
Send me to Africa

German text below

Hi! My name is Miriam Rauth. For a long time, I’m interested in a country called Ethiopia and how people live there. After school I’d like to spend a year as volunteer and work there. To get the projects known I’d like to travel to Ethiopia in fall for two weeks.

One of the projects is the Onesimus Drop-in-Centre for street children in the capital of Ethiopia Addis Ababa. I’d like to see where I would spend this year and who the people are I would work with and for. I want to see how the children live there and what their everyday problems are. This would help me to plan my volunteer year in 2015. Of course this is not for free. For flight, transport and nights at hostels I need 1000€. I can’t afford that much money and this is why I ask for your help. A donation from your side could help me to make this journey for real. I would be grateful if you would share this site. I know together we can do it! Thanks…

 

German:

Hi! Ich heiße Miriam Rauth. Seit einiger Zeit beschäftigt mich das Land Äthiopien und wie die Menschen dort leben. Ich könnte mir vorstellen nach meiner Schulzeit für ein Jahr als Freiwillige nach Äthiopien zu gehen. Aus diesem Grund möchte ich mich im Herbst zwei Wochen lang mit einigen Projekten vertraut machen.

Ein Projekt wäre das Onesimus Drop-in-Centre für Straßenkinder in der Hauptstadt Äthiopiens Addis Abeba. Ich würde herausfinden, wo ich das Jahr nach meiner Schule verbringen werde und Kontakte zu den Projektverantwortlichen und Mitarbeitern knüpfen. Ich möchte die Lebensverhältnisse der Straßenkinder kennenlernen und mit welchen Problemen sie jeden Tag leben müssen. Diese zweiwöchige Reise würde mir helfen mein freiwilliges Jahr 2015 zu planen. Kalkuliert habe ich für Flug, Transport und Übernachtungen im Hostel ungefähr 1000€. Ich bitte Euch um eine kleine Spende um mir dies alles zu ermöglichen. Zusammen ist das möglich! Danke...

story:
Help Us Send Books to Our First School Library in Zambia, Africa

“For everyone, everywhere, literacy is, along with education in general, a basic human right.... the road to human progress and the means through which every man, woman and child can realize his or her full potential.”

~ Kofi Annan, former United Nations Secretary-General

Who We Are

14+ Foundation (www.14plusfoundation.org) is a USA-based 501(c)(3) charitable organization that was founded in June 2012 to develop and build schools and orphanages for African children in rural communities.

Our first project is the Chipakata Children’s Academy (www.chipakata.org), created to serve as a community-based, multifunctional facility that includes a primary school for grades 1 to 7.  The student population of the school will include local orphans and vulnerable children from the Chipakata community, whose nearest school is currently more than 7 km away.  

It is a proven fact that higher levels of literacy are associated with the availability of classroom libraries with a sufficient quantity of books, providing children with the opportunity to read.  14+ Foundation has a committee dedicated to developing a library for the Chipakata Children’s Academy.  Our goal is to obtain approximately 2,400 books, purchase a shipping container and transport these books to Zambia, Africa.

To oversee the development and operation of the Chipakata Children’s Academy, the directors of 14+ Foundation created the Chipakata Children’s Academy Foundation, a Zambian-based NGO, who will ensure that the finances provided by 14+ Foundation are used for the intended purpose.

How You Can Help

Please make a donation and help us raise the funds needed to purchase books for the Chipakata Children’s Academy Library and to cover the shipping costs to send these books to Zambia, Africa.  Spread the word to your friends, family and colleagues about our campaign.

Your donation is critical and your support will play an integral part in transforming the lives of children through education and improved literacy.

story:
What is PPR?

Patient Privacy Rights Foundation is a nonprofit, mostly volunteer-run, bi-partisan organization that needs your help.

Historically, PPR has provided services to individuals and worked with privacy, consumer, civil and human rights, and social justice organizations worldwide to prevent government and corporations from controlling and using patients’ sensitive personal health data.   


Since this summer’s revelations about NSA’s massive spying programs, PPR has been busier than ever.  Those who oppose the NSA’s actions are now discovering PPR’s critical work in exposing the surveillance and use of personal health data.


This is great!  Yet, PPR is struggling to keep up with the increased demand on our limited resoources.  PPR, this small group of activists, needs more hands and more support.  We need funds to help build an app to help educate to public and bring awareness to a much larger audience.  Our PRIVACY APP will list the privacy policies of different hospitals, health care plans - including Healthcare.gov, mobile health sites, and pharmacies.  We will list the pros and cons of these privacy policies and rank them for the public to have a better understanding, letting everyone know who they can trust and if their data is really safe.

What does PPR do?

PPR is a different nature of service provider.  What we believe is simple: “Individuals should be in control of their own health information.”


Currently, there are no limits to the types of organizations that can gain access to your sensitive health information—employers, advertisers, insurers, you name it. It’s important that we act now to preserve our right to privacy.  We must take steps to regain control over our personal information.  At PPR, we believe it should always be up to you to decide what happens to your sensitive information.  You should be able to know and control who sees it, where it goes, and why.


PPR is the largest non-profit advocating for health privacy.  PPR and its coalition host the nation’s largest and most unique privacy event, The Health Privacy Summit.  It is an inclusive event; it offers the best forum in the world for high-level, thoughtful discussions covering the most urgent national and international health privacy issues; and more importantly, it recommends solutions.  Further, PPR contributes heavily to a number of different conferences and privacy projects.  We accomplish our work largely with volunteers and relying completely on donations.


***Protecting health privacy isn’t just important for your own health and well-being today, but what we do now affects our future generations.  PPR cares deeply about protecting personal privacy; we believe that people should be measured by who they are and what they are capable of doing, not their medical history.***


Click here to watch a video and listen to Dr. Deborah Peel, Founder and Chair of PPR, talk about why health privacy is important to all of us.

 

Okay, brilliant.  Bottom line is PPR is fighting for us...what else? This is what you really need to know:


Here and now, having Patient Privacy Rights existing and growing is more important than ever. Here’s an example why:


In response to the leaks about the NSA’s blanket surveillance programs, more and more people are becoming concerned about their data – and that includes sensitive health data.


Predictive analytics is the use of big data to predict trends and behavior patterns; it can be used to increase profits and to potentially improve healthcare.  However, predictive analytics can also be defined as involuntary data collection and surveillance that may lead to unintended consequences such as discrimination. It is this key result of predictive analytics that most people don’t comprehend. PPR serves as an effective key in helping educate people about the dangers and prevalence of data surveillance, and how that correlates to their health information.


Yet, PPR is a small organization.  Our volunteers donate their time and efforts to educate the public about what they can do to protect their privacy and prevent things like discrimination.


Your medical records are your business.  

Help us build our app and protect your privacy by contributing to PPR today!


Where your money goes: 

Specifically, PPR is planning on developing educational tools like videos and apps to help educate the public about health privacy.  We need $10,000 to cover these costs:

  • privacy-friendly technology and technical support
  • beginning phases of developing educational materials (for app development)
  • public outreach and collaboration
  • wages for dedicated human staff to plan and organize
  • other miscellaneous expenses

Campaign seeks $10,000 total


Other ways you can help:

We understand that not all people can contribute, but that doesn't mean that you can't help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.  Visit our website, patientprivacyrights.org, and share with your friends.  Join PPR today and sign a petition asking Congress to put you in control of your information.
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!  Share using your favorite social media sites and tell your friends on Facebook and Twitter.

DONORS: Please read the Indiegogo Privacy Policy prior to donating.  We acknowledge that Indiegogo supports tracking on their site and therefore some of your information will be shared.  If you are concerned about this particular tracking you can still donate at our secure donation page on PPR's website.

story:
Scroll down for English Version


Español

Saludos, somos el equipo de Olimpiadas de Matemática de la Universidad de Costa Rica y nos gustaria participar en la V Competencia Iberoamericana Interuniversitaria de Matemáticas (CIIM) a realizarse en Armenia, Colombia del 15 al 20 de octubre.

Nuestra corta historia:

El equipo de Olimpiadas de la Universidad de Costa Rica nace como una iniciativa del estudiante Daniel Campos quien en el 2009 decide participar en la primera CIIM donde obtiene una medalla de plata.

De izquierda a derecha: Daniel Campos, Daniel Barrantes, Javier Rodriguez y William Alvarado, durante la CIIM del 2011 en Ecuador.

Desde ese momento, con el apoyo del profesor William Alvarado, el movimiento empieza a crecer, actualmente contamos con mas de 10 estudiantes, quienes motivados por el deseo de profundizar sus estudios y compartir sus conocimientos con el mundo, nos reunimos todos los sábados para resolver problemas y discutir temas que nos interesen.

Sobre la competencia:

"La I Competencia Iberoamericana Interuniversitaria de Matemáticas nace con el ánimo de incentivar el estudio de las matemáticas y la excelencia académica en nuestra comunidad universitaria iberoamericana, mejorando las capacidades científicas a través de la motivación y de la competitividad internacional aportando así al desarrollo social, cultural y económico de nuestros países." - Tomado de la página oficial de la CIIM

En realidad la importancia de esta competencia trasciende sus objetivos principales, desde sus inicios la competencia ha sido un ambiente donde matemáticos jóvenes latinoamericanos pueden compartir y convivir, básicamente conectando esta área geográfica que es ya bastante uniforme pero se encuentra separada por líneas imaginarias. Estas conexiones son vitales para el desarrollo matemático de la región.

Participantes de la IV CIIM en Guanajuato Mexico.

Como si fuera poco, el prestigioso Instituto de Matemática Pura y Aplicada (IMPA), localizado en Rio de Janeiro, recompensa a los medallistas de esta competencia con becas para asistir al instituto durante el verano.

Por qué necesitamos su ayuda:

Debido a que este movimiento es una iniciativa completamente estudiantil contamos únicamente con nuestros propios recursos que, podrán imaginarse, no son muchos. Contamos por supuesto con ayuda por parte de algunas instituciones de la universidad sin embargo debido a ciertos reglamentos internos y otras limitaciones la universidad no cubre completamente nuestra participación.

El año pasado fue el primer año que logramos llevar un equipo entero a participar. Esto se logró gracias a una intensiva campaña de recolección de fondos organizada por nosotros mismos la cual incluyó una exitosa campaña en Indiegogo.

Este año nuestra meta es llevar 2 equipos completos a Colombia esto es 8 estudiantes: Jorge Arce, Oscar Arguedas, Santiago Chaves, Edward Coto, Jennifer Loria, Hector Mendez, Oscar Quesada, Oscar Zamora y Daniel Barrantes como tutor.

Los tiquetes aéreos  a Bogotá Colombia desde Costa Rica se encuentran entre $500 y $650, además los costos de estadía son de $50 por noche. Elevando el costo total a un poco más de $6000 (sin incluir el costo de llevar al tutor), calculamos que si recaudamos $4000 seremos capaces de cubrir la diferencia y llevar a competir a los 8 estudiantes.

Fila superior, de izquierda a derecha: Esteban Arreaga, Daniel Barrantes, Oscar Zamora, Jorge Arce. Fila inferior, de izquierda a derecha: Hector Mendez, Edward Coto, Jennifer Loria, Oscar Arguedas, Santiago Chaves, Oscar Quesada.


Qué resultados esperamos:

Como explicamos anteriormente el solo hecho de participar en la olimpiada ya es de gran importancia para nosotros, sin embargo, desde su primera participación el equipo de La Universidad de Costa Rica ha ganado premios consistemente, a continuación un listado de ellos:

  • 2009, Daniel Campos, medalla de plata
  • 2011, Daniel Campos, medalla de oro
  • 2011, Daniel Barrantes, medalla de bronce
  • 2012, Daniel Barrantes, medalla de bronce
  • 2012, Oscar Zamora, medalla de bronce

¡Pueden esperar grandes resultados de nuestro equipo actual!

Equipos de Costa Rica y Guatemala después de la premiacion de la IV CIIM 2012.


English

Greetings, we are the Math Olympics team from the University of Costa Rica and we would like to participate on the V Iberoamerican Interuniversitary Math Competition (CIIM because of its initials in Spanish) to be held in Armenia, Colombia from October 15 to October 20.


Our Short story:

The Math Olympics team was born as an initiative by the student Daniel Campos who in 2009 decided to participate in the first CIIM, winning a silver medal.

From left to right: Daniel Campos, Daniel Barrantes, Javier Rodriguez and William Alvarado, during the CIIM, 2011 in Ecuador.


Since then, with the support of Professor William Alvarado,  the movement has been growing, nowadays we have over 10 students, who, motivated by the desire to deepen their studies and share their knowledge, get together every Saturday to solve problems and discuss subjects they are interested in. 

About the competition:

"The I Iberoamerican Interuniversitary Math Competition was born with the desire to promote the study of mathematics and the academic excellence in our Iberoamerican universitary community, improving the scientific skills trough the motivation and the competitiveness, thus helping the social, cultural and economic development of our countries." - Taken from the CIIM official site

Truthfully the importance of this competition transcends its principal objectives. From its start the competition has been an opportunity for young Latinamerican mathematicians to get together and share, basically connecting this already homogeneous geographic zone separated only by imaginary lines. These connections are vital for the region's mathematical development.

Participants of the IV CIIM in Guanajuato Mexico.

If that weren't enough, the prestigious Institute of Pure and Applied Math (IMPA because of its initials in Portuguese) located in Rio de Janeiro, rewards the medalists with scholarships to attend the Institute during summer.

Why we need your help:

Given that this movement is completely managed by students, we can only count on our own resources. Which, being students, aren't many. Of course we can depend on some support from our university; however, due to some internal rules and other limitations, the university won't finance our participation completely.

Last year was the first time we managed to bring a full team to compete. This was achieved thanks to an intensive fundraising effort organized by ourselves, which included a successful Indiegogo campaign.

Our goal this year is to take 2 full teams to Colombia, that is 8 students: Jorge Arce, Oscar Arguedas, Santiago Chaves, Edward Coto, Jennifer Loria, Hector Mendez, Oscar Quesada, Oscar Zamora, and Daniel Barrantes as tutor.

The airfare from Costa Rica to Bogota, Colombia is between $500 and $650. On top of that we need to pay $50 per night for the stay. This makes the total cost a little over $6000 (this is without the cost of bringing the tutor). We think that if we raise $4000 we could cover the difference and take the 8 students to the competition.

Top row, from left to right: Esteban Arreaga, Daniel Barrantes, Oscar Zamora, Jorge Arce. Bottom row from left to right: Hector Mendez, Edward Coto, Jennifer Loria, Oscar Arguedas, Santiago Chaves, Oscar Quesada.


What results can we expect?

As explained earlier, just participating in the competition is of great importance to us, still, since its first participation the University of Costa Rica has won medals consistently:

  • 2009, Daniel Campos, silver medal
  • 2011, Daniel Campos, gold medal
  • 2011, Daniel Barrantes, bronze medal
  • 2012, Daniel Barrantes, bronze medal
  • 2012, Oscar Zamora, bronze medal

You can expect great things from this year's team!

 The teams from Costa Rica and Guatemala after the IV CIIM medal ceremony, 2012.

Debido a que este movimiento es una iniciativa completamente estudiantil contamos únicamente con nuestros propios recursos que, podrán imaginarse, no son muchos. Contamos por supuesto con ayuda por parte de algunas instituciones de la universidad sin embargo debido a ciertos reglamentos internos y otras limitaciones la universidad no cubre completamente nuestra participación.
El año pasado fue el primer año que logramos llevar un equipo entero a participar. Esto se logró gracias a una intensiva campaña de recolección de fondos organizada por nosotros mismos la cual incluyó una exitosa campaña en Indiegogo.
Este año nuestra meta es llevar 2 equipos completos a Colombia esto es 8 estudiantes: Jorge Arce, Oscar Arguedas, Santiago Chaves, Edward Coto, Jennifer Loria, Hector Mendez, Oscar Quesada, Oscar Zamora y Daniel Barrantes como tutor.
Los tiquetes aéreos  a Bogotá Colombia desde Costa Rica se encuentran entre $500 y $650, además los costos de estadía son de $50 por noche. Elevando el costo total a un poco más de $6000 (sin incluir el costo de llevar al tutor), calculamos que si recaudamos $4000 seremos capaces de cubrir la diferencia y llevar a competir a los 8 estudiantes.


Fila superior, de izquierda a derecha: Esteban Arreaga, Daniel Barrantes, Oscar Zamora, Jorge Arce. Fila inferior, de izquierda a derecha: Hector Mendez, Edward Coto, Jennifer Loria, Oscar Arguedas, Santiago Chaves, Oscar Quesada.

Qué resultados esperamos:
Como explicamos anteriormente el solo hecho de participar en la olimpiada ya es de gran importancia para nosotros, sin embargo, desde su primera participación el equipo de La Universidad de Costa Rica ha ganado premios consistemente, a continuación un listado de ellos:

2009, Daniel Campos, medalla de plata
2011, Daniel Campos, medalla de oro
2011, Daniel Barrantes, medalla de bronce
2012, Daniel Barrantes, medalla de bronce
2012, Oscar Zamora, medalla de bronce

¡Pueden esperar grandes resultados de nuestro equipo actual!


Equipos de Costa Rica y Guatemala después de la premiacion de la IV CIIM 2012.
English
Greetings, we are the Math Olympics team from the University of Costa Rica and we would like to participate on the V Iberoamerican Interuniversitary Math Competition (CIIM because of its initials in Spanish) to be held in Armenia, Colombia from October 15 to October 20.

Our Short story:
The Math Olympics team was born as an initiative by the student Daniel Campos who in 2009 decided to participate in the first CIIM, winning a silver medal.


From left to right: Daniel Campos, Daniel Barrantes, Javier Rodriguez and William Alvarado, during the CIIM, 2011 in Ecuador.

Since then, with the support of Professor William Alvarado,  the movement has been growing, nowadays we have over 10 students, who, motivated by the desire to deepen their studies and share their knowledge, get together every Saturday to solve problems and discuss subjects they are interested in. 
About the competition:
"The I Iberoamerican Interuniversitary Math Competition was born with the desire to promote the study of mathematics and the academic excellence in our Iberoamerican universitary community, improving the scientific skills trough the motivation and the competitiveness, thus helping the social, cultural and economic development of our countries." - Taken from the CIIM official site
Truthfully the importance of this competition transcends its principal objectives. From its start the competition has been an opportunity for young Latinamerican mathematicians to get together and share, basically connecting this already homogeneous geographic zone separated only by imaginary lines. These connections are vital for the region's mathematical development.


Participants of the IV CIIM in Guanajuato Mexico. 

If that weren't enough, the prestigious Institute of Pure and Applied Math (IMPA because of its initials in Portuguese) located in Rio de Janeiro, rewards the medalists with scholarships to attend the Institute during summer.
Why we need your help:
Given that this movement is completely managed by students, we can only count on our own resources. Which, being students, aren't many. Of course we can depend on some support from our university; however, due to some internal rules and other limitations, the university won't finance our participation completely.
Last year was the first time we managed to bring a full team to compete. This was achieved thanks to an intensive fundraising effort organized by ourselves, which included a successful Indiegogo campaign.
Our goal this year is to take 2 full teams to Colombia, that is 8 students: Jorge Arce, Oscar Arguedas, Santiago Chaves, Edward Coto, Jennifer Loria, Hector Mendez, Oscar Quesada, Oscar Zamora, and Daniel Barrantes as tutor.
The airfare from Costa Rica to Bogota, Colombia is between $500 and $650. On top of that we need to pay $50 per night for the stay. This makes the total cost a little over $6000 (this is without the cost of bringing the tutor). We think that if we raise $4000 we could cover the difference and take the 8 students to the competition.


Top row, from left to right: Esteban Arreaga, Daniel Barrantes, 
Oscar Zamora, Jorge Arce. Bottom row from left to right: Hector 
Mendez, Edward Coto, Jennifer Loria, Oscar Arguedas, Santiago Chaves, 
Oscar Quesada.

What results can we expect?

As explained earlier, just participating in the competition is of great importance to us, still, since its first participation the University of Costa Rica has won medals consistently:

2009, Daniel Campos, silver medal

2011, Daniel Campos, gold medal

2011, Daniel Barrantes, bronze medal

2012, Daniel Barrantes, bronze medal

2012, Oscar Zamora, bronze medal

You can expect great things from this year's team!


 The teams from Costa Rica and Guatemala after the IV CIIM medal ceremony, 2012.

story:
I am a passionate advocate for human rights, and have spent the last six years focused on the rights of persons with an intellectual disability. I envision governments, community groups and organizations including all diverse populations in conversations and planning when improving education, employment, and housing options and when working to reduce poverty. There is a role to play to ensure all voices are heard and all rights are equally respected, and I've got that fire in my belly to be a part of it.

In recognition of my work in the disability field and community, I was named one of 21inc’s Top 50 Emerging Leaders in Atlantic Canada. You can learn more about my work and vision in the video above :) 21inc is, in their own words, a nonprofit action tank committed to developing high performance leaders in Atlantic Canada’s most promising young people, aged 20 to 35. Since its founding, many of Atlantic Canada’s top leaders under age 35 have used 21inc leadership experiences to start new economic and community ventures and propel careers, making a significant impact in the economic and social wellbeing of the region. It is inspiring and a true honor to be selected, and I need your support!

Please consider contributing to support the leadership development of young change makers in Atlantic Canada. Believe in us, we're passionate about doing good!

Now that we've made the goal!

Your financial support will allow me to take part in 21inc's 2013 Emerging Leaders’ Summit, being held in Nova Scotia in late October. As one of the top 50 emerging leaders, I am required to fundraise $500 for 21inc. Donations will be used by 21inc to support the alumni network of young leaders and to ensure the organization’s sustainability. Their work is important - to me, to our region, and to future young people striving for excellence. Let's make sure young leaders are given these incredible learning opportunities for years to come!

All donations made to $500 will be given to 21inc to support their commitment to the leadership development of young persons in Atlantic Canada. Any additional donations will then go toward the cost of indiegogo fundraising (4% of total dollars raised, currently around $30). After that, any additional donations will go to 21inc.  

All donors will receive my immense gratitude for your support, and that good feeling in your belly that happens when you've lent a helping hand.

Just like actions that make a difference, your donations will work together to help me reach my goal - every little bit counts, and every little bit makes a difference!

The Impact

21inc is built on the philosophy that leaders don't just appear; they are developed by others, who, seeing something special, reach out and draw them into a support system to harness a person's leadership potential and convert it into action. 21inc builds learning networks between diverse and inspiring groups of emerging and established provincial and regional leaders. By facilitating "creative collisions" between the people who can propel new models of leadership and action, our communities, provinces, and region will thrive in the 21st century.

Supporting my participation in the 2013 Emerging Leaders Summit, and thereby supporting 21inc, is a way to show your commitment to the leadership development of passionate young people. We WILL make you proud!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word! I would be delighted if you would share this campaign with your networks and on social media.

story:
GRATITUDE to all who have helped us achieve our campaign goal. Three of the four family members have agreed to enroll in the TLC experience during the weekend of April 25 - 27, 2014. We are working hard on getting the fourth family member to commit. We trust that whoever is meant to be there will be there. Stay tuned for more updates, and your perks will be shipping out in a couple weeks!

***

1/9/14 UPDATE: We have now raised enough funds to get ALL FOUR family members into TLC!!! We are so touched by everybody's generosity.

***

We are still accepting donations, and all extra money will go toward the next TLC students. We have much more time on this campaign - let's do this and continue to Help Others Heal!!!

***

1/7/14 UPDATE: We have now raised enough funds to get TWO of the FOUR family members into TLC!!! Just TWO more to go!!! Thank you so much to all who have contributed, from the bottom of our hearts!!!

***

1/6/14 UPDATE: We have now raised enough funds to get ONE of the FOUR family members into The Living Course!!! Just THREE more to go!!! Thank you so much to all who have contributed so far!!!

 

Our Dream: Help Us Help Others

  • A family we hold dear to our hearts has lost their youngest son. We love them very much and we want to help them find peace.
  • The Living Course is a 30-hour personal development weekend that has changed our lives for the better.
  • Please help us help others! With your contribution, a grieving family will have a powerful chance to come together. They need this more than anything right now!

TLC Changed Our Lives

  • Our family came to TLC and together discovered the things that block us from having the closeness we say we want.
  • As a result, we are more patient with each other. We love and talk to each other on a deeper level. 
  • TLC has changed our whole family’s interactions and perspectives. We are now more understanding, more supportive of each other, and happier in our relationships because of the TLC experience.
  • We so badly want others to have this extraordinary gift of peace and healing!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are incredibly appreciative of any funding you are able to contribute to this project. The $2500 raised will go toward:

  • Tuition
  • Accomodations
  • Meals
  • Indiegogo commission ( ? )
Your contribution will get you a cool perk, atop of the priceless feeling that you've done something kind for others in need this holiday season!
  • What you receive depends on the amount you give.
  • Any extra money raised will go to the next TLC students we want to send.
  • If we don't reach our goal of $2500, we will set the funds aside until we are able to raise the amount needed to send this particular family to TLC.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are truly unable to contribute, that's okay! There are other ways to help us out:

  • Keep this family in your thoughts and prayers.
  • Please share this campaign with your networks - email, Facebook, Twitter, etc.
  • Tell your friends about what we are doing and get them excited about this opportunity to help a family in need!
  • Indiegogo has sharing tools as well - give us a "like" or post to various social media sites.

Sending out big love and hugs!

In Gratitude,

Maria & Angela

story:
Summer time is an important time for the development of young musicians as schools, universities, teachers, and summer camps offer a plethora of musically enriching experiences. These experiences are often very expensive and inaccessible to students whose families are not able to afford the cost of application fees, tuition, or travel, among other things.

MYCincinnati is building a Summer Scholarship Fund to support MYCincinnati musicians who are self-motivated and accepted into competitive summer music-related programs.

The MYCincinnati Summer Scholarship Fund will support fees and expenses associated with:

  • Music-related camp and program tuitions
  • Travel expenses
  • Applications
  • Instrumental and music accessory necessities
  • Private lessons
  • Audition recordings

Some of the programs our students have been accepted to include:

  • The National Take A Stand Festival Youth Orchestra
  • Camp Encore/Coda, a month-long music camp in western Maine
  • Red Cross Leadership Summer Camp
  • Local Cincinnati music camps
  • Private instrumental studios
