story:
Orphanage in Vilnius "Gile"

We visited an orphanage in Vilnius, Lithuania. It is called “Gile”. 50 kids, taken away from asocial parents, who are addicted to drugs and alcohol, live here. The orphanage’s mission is providing the kids with food, shelter, education and creating a healthy environment for them. The biggest joy these kids have, is the summers, when they get to go to the summer camps. The orphanage’s administration managed to find summer camps willing to take in the kids this summer, however, there is one big problem: the old, minibus made in Russia, which was used to take the kids to said camps has rusted beyond repair and stopped working. The government refuses to help in buying new transport. This situation strongly restricts the freedom of moving the kids, which means they are basically confined to their orphanage.

What We Need & What You Get

Their only chance to meet new friends in the summer camps is with your help. If we can manage to get 7000 USD (6500 eur), the orphanage can buy a used minibus that is still in working condition. A dollar, ten dollars or more from you will be a big step to improving the lives of these kids and creating a more positive environment. You will get karma points.

Risks & Challenges

If we don't receive the full sum, the orphanage will buy a cheaper, smaller used vehicle. If we get lucky and receive more donations, the orphanage will buy a newer minibus that will serve longer.

story:
The immense earthquakes that shook Nepal in April and May 2015 deeply devastated the country and the people. Despite international disaster relief and aid, the path in rebuilding homes, restoring infrastructure, and regenerating livelihoods has been and will continue to be a long one.

Three of my good friends - Allen, Orion, and Juliette - were traveling just outside the Everest basecamp when the first earthquake hit on April 25. After receiving news of their safety, they told me that they will stay in the country to assist in the emergency relief efforts, distribution of supplies, and anything else they can give a lending hand. They partnered with local organizations and visited a number of villages outside the capital city where access was difficult or impossible by vehicle due to damaged roads to assess the needs of the communities and distribute essential items.

In the weeks that followed, they formed Conscious Impact (www.consciousimpact.org) and launched an Indiegogo fundraiser to collect donations from their friends and family to directly help the work on the ground. At the time, they had already formed a great partnership with Abari (www.abari.org), a Nepali organization with the mission to build homes made of local resources such as bamboo and adobe that are earthquake resistant and more environmentally and socially sustainable than conventional practices. See this video for an example and explanation filmed by the team. Over the course of 3 months, they were able to raise enough money to fund their day-to-day operations, capacity building, gather supplies and resources for current and upcoming builds, as well as investing it in the form of knowledge.

In June it became clear to me that my friends and I should join forces. I requested personal time off from work and soon booked round trip tickets for Kathmandu. Between September 5 and October 17, I will be working alongside the team plus dozens of other volunteers from around the world to learn, build, and document the process and life as it is for the Nepali people. The Conscious Impact team have partnered up with another non-governmental organization named YUWA Unity Nepal (www.yuwaunitynepal.org) and have been working closely with community leaders and families in the village of Takure, Sindhapocuk. The main builds will take place between September 17-26 and October 5-14. These dates were set as the region transitions out of the monsoon season, ie: the rainy months between June - early September. I will also be joined by Luke Namer and Sebastian Buffa, 2 videographers from Redefined Films (www.redefinedfilms.org) from New York to co-create a series of stills, video shorts, and written pieces to be published on our social media networks and websites.

The preparations up to this point has been entirely self-funded, and I humbly ask for your financial contribution. This to me is an incredible intersection of my passions in photography and videography to raise awareness and do social as well as environmental good. I need your support in this journey. The intensity of and damages from this natural disaster is on a scale beyond most of our full comprehension. It frustrates me that mainstream media and other news channels have turned their attention away from the persistence and resilience of the Nepali people. There is joy amidst the chaos, beauty besides the fallen structures, and strong human spirit to be shared and inspire further. I believe that it is crucial to share this essential work and the stories of the people whose lives and voices would otherwise never reach a global audience. Through your financial support, I am confident that we can give back to our global community to create a positive, conscious impact together.

As my friends say it best:

"... we understand that we gain peace, harmony and happiness through serving others."

Thank you!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Who is Jonathan?

I am a photographer, social and environmental activist, adventure-seeker, and earth steward.

I am captivated by the sheer natural beauty of our planet in its finest moments. I seek to capture the genuine expressions in people and the human element of our built environment. I am fascinated by indigenous peoples and their intrinsic connections to the land, flora, and fauna.

During my university days, I became actively involved with grassroots, student coalitions to raise awareness on and act upon issues surrounding social and environmental sustainability. The involvement led to my belief for urgent climate action and in forming resilient, interdependent communities worldwide. After graduating, I had the opportunity to live and work in Panama, where I coordinated environmental development projects alongside empowered student volunteers and indigenous Guna and Emberá villagers. This was a pivotal period of my life as I learned the immensely complex realm of sustainable development while refining my art to expose global issues that matter, unique cultures worth learning about, environments needing preservation, and adventures that inspire.

I am humbled and honored to have had my work published on Viajes National Geographic, Grist.org, Gaiacraft, United Indians of All Tribes Foundation, Global Brigades, Earth Train, GROW Worldwide, Beacon Food Forest, Great March for Climate Action, La Prensa Panamá, and more. In autumn 2012, I hosted a photo exhibit in Panama City and attracted hundreds of Panamanians and travelers on an evening where I shared my adventures and human experiences throughout the country. Through my photographs and stories, I was able to inspire others to respect as well as admire the places, cultures, and beauty our world unrelentingly offers. The experience brought tremendous joy, and I intend to continue the path of socially and environmentally impactful photography.

One of my latest passions is in sustainable food systems. In the growing season of 2013, I ventured on a 8 and a half-month bicycle journey across the Pacific Northwest and U.S. west coast to intersect learning, service, and art by being immersed in and capturing the intricacies of organic food production on various family-run farms. During my southbound journey towards (then-)home in southern California, I leveraged social media and photography to raise money via Indiegogo to support myself as well as the great work of 350.org and Conservacion Patagonica for the incredible work they have been doing on climate action and land regeneration.

Since the summer of 2014, I have been situated in Seattle, Washington and have continued my involvement with the local food system and permaculture transition alongside the great individuals behind the Beacon Food Forest, exploring the magical Olympic/Cascade mountains, while living a simple, low-carbon footprint lifestyle.

On August 13, 2015, I hosted a presentation and talk on the work that the Conscious Impact team has been doing since the earthquake. Over 30 people attended the event to hear about and take part in learning about the efforts, stay connected, and pitch in to the work. I am so very grateful for everyone's support and plan to host a post-trip event in Seattle upon my return in the fall (last couple weeks of October and/or November).


Liz giving an Nepali well-wishing



Funding Breakdown

I really value transparency, and wish for you to know that the $3000 goal was set based on the following costs and needs. The additional camera equipment include: a second camera body, an extra travel tripod, a microphone, and a portable photo printer (for the postcard perks and printing images for our partners + families we'll be working with and getting to know).

I was tipped by a friend to fly in and out of Vancouver, Canada instead of Seattle, Washington due to lower costs (~$240). So I thought even with the additional travel time and bus fare, this is ultimately savings that can keep the budget as low as possible.


Timeline

My speculation as to how the following 5 months and beyond will look like with this project. I hope to be able to get the photos from Nepal up for viewing and selection between late October and November of this year, while photo (perks, see below!) deliveries will commence late November and be wrapped up by the first month of 2016. Depending on the progress the Redefined Films crew and I make while in-country and the remote collaboration to follow post-October, we have discussed launching a short film by the end of 2015. I will do my best to keep everyone posted!


Perks

Besides my (our) sincere gratitude for your support, I would love for you to have something memorable in return.

My photographs from the 6 weeks in Nepal will be organized, edited, and uploaded into a gallery for you to view, read, and learn the context & story. If you are able to pitch in at the $70 level or higher, please choose your favorite photograph(s) to be printed and mail to you. The matting will be custom cut by yours truly to the next popular size, e.g. 16"x24" matte for the 12"x18" print, for easy (and beautiful) display and/or framing.

For the 12"x18" and 16"x24"-sized prints, you'd have the opportunity to choose a single or multiple images to be made into a collage.

Perhaps the most exciting perk I am offering is the Photo Book, which is going to be a layflat, flush mount, hard cover photo book that's going to have approximately 20 pages filled with my very best, hand-picked images from Nepal. The Photo Book measures 6"x8".

Shipping cost for the enlargements and photo book depends on your location, e.g. US least, Canada a bit higher, rest of the world most.



A sneak peek - Elliese and Naomi with my matted prints at my Panama City photo gallery. I truly, truly enjoy sharing my vision of the world with others.


About Conscious Impact

Conscious Impact's approach is unique in that they are a community and volunteer-led organization. This means that what they do "depends on the interests, desires, and passions of our (their) partners." This includes community members, partner organizations, and volunteers, like myself and others I'll be joined with.

My friends have had 7 years of experience working in rural development and international service in Latin America (through where we met) and Africa. They have taken the experience and knowledge and distilled it into their current mission "to inspire, mobilize, and train volunteers to compassionately and selflessly service those in need." The team is in it for international, cross-cultural collaborations, and it is not their intention, like certain big names in the development world, to be in it for the long-run. In my opinion, this should never be the case.

Plan B?

There really isn't. It's not what I am aiming for. I am (we are) absolutely committed to this project. The trip to Nepal is still happening and the documentation will still take place, even in the event the goal of $3000 is not reached. Thanks to the flexible funding option of Indiegogo, the raised funds will still come through to make this project a reality. The lower funding and with it the potential financial stress would have a negative impact on my ability to bring forth our experiences in-country to their maximum potential and reach. I believe we can collectively make this happen, and in fact surpass the goal!

Connect / Spread the Word!

If you have any questions about the work that I'll be doing with the Conscious Impact team, please don't hesitate to contact me directly. This fundraiser has made possible thanks to the superb support that so many of my family and friends have given me. It is curiously difficult to ask for monetary support from those you love and cherish. I absolutely understand if a financial contribution is not possible at this moment, and would be equally thankful if you could share this fundraiser and the work being done. Awareness-raising is invaluable.

With gratitude,
Jonathan

story_txt:
The immense earthquakes that shook Nepal in April and May 2015 deeply devastated the country and the people. Despite international disaster relief and aid, the path in rebuilding homes, restoring infrastructure, and regenerating livelihoods has been and will continue to be a long one.Three of my good friends - Allen, Orion, and Juliette - were traveling just outside the Everest basecamp when the first earthquake hit on April 25. After receiving news of their safety, they told me that they will stay in the country to assist in the emergency relief efforts, distribution of supplies, and anything else they can give a lending hand. They partnered with local organizations and visited a number of villages outside the capital city where access was difficult or impossible by vehicle due to damaged roads to assess the needs of the communities and distribute essential items.In the weeks that followed, they formed Conscious Impact (www.consciousimpact.org) and launched an Indiegogo fundraiser to collect donations from their friends and family to directly help the work on the ground. At the time, they had already formed a great partnership with Abari (www.abari.org), a Nepali organization with the mission to build homes made of local resources such as bamboo and adobe that are earthquake resistant and more environmentally and socially sustainable than conventional practices. See this video for an example and explanation filmed by the team. Over the course of 3 months, they were able to raise enough money to fund their day-to-day operations, capacity building, gather supplies and resources for current and upcoming builds, as well as investing it in the form of knowledge.In June it became clear to me that my friends and I should join forces. I requested personal time off from work and soon booked round trip tickets for Kathmandu. Between September 5 and October 17, I will be working alongside the team plus dozens of other volunteers from around the world to learn, build, and document the process and life as it is for the Nepali people. The Conscious Impact team have partnered up with another non-governmental organization named YUWA Unity Nepal (www.yuwaunitynepal.org) and have been working closely with community leaders and families in the village of Takure, Sindhapocuk. The main builds will take place between September 17-26 and October 5-14. These dates were set as the region transitions out of the monsoon season, ie: the rainy months between June - early September. I will also be joined by Luke Namer and Sebastian Buffa, 2 videographers from Redefined Films (www.redefinedfilms.org) from New York to co-create a series of stills, video shorts, and written pieces to be published on our social media networks and websites.The preparations up to this point has been entirely self-funded, and I humbly ask for your financial contribution. This to me is an incredible intersection of my passions in photography and videography to raise awareness and do social as well as environmental good. I need your support in this journey. The intensity of and damages from this natural disaster is on a scale beyond most of our full comprehension. It frustrates me that mainstream media and other news channels have turned their attention away from the persistence and resilience of the Nepali people. There is joy amidst the chaos, beauty besides the fallen structures, and strong human spirit to be shared and inspire further. I believe that it is crucial to share this essential work and the stories of the people whose lives and voices would otherwise never reach a global audience. Through your financial support, I am confident that we can give back to our global community to create a positive, conscious impact together.As my friends say it best:
"... we understand that we gain peace, harmony and happiness through serving others."Thank you!------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Who is Jonathan?I am a photographer, social and environmental activist, adventure-seeker, and earth steward.I am captivated by the sheer natural beauty of our planet in its finest moments. I seek to capture the genuine expressions in people and the human element of our built environment. I am fascinated by indigenous peoples and their intrinsic connections to the land, flora, and fauna.During my university days, I became actively involved with grassroots, student coalitions to raise awareness on and act upon issues surrounding social and environmental sustainability. The involvement led to my belief for urgent climate action and in forming resilient, interdependent communities worldwide. After graduating, I had the opportunity to live and work in Panama, where I coordinated environmental development projects alongside empowered student volunteers and indigenous Guna and Emberá villagers. This was a pivotal period of my life as I learned the immensely complex realm of sustainable development while refining my art to expose global issues that matter, unique cultures worth learning about, environments needing preservation, and adventures that inspire.I am humbled and honored to have had my work published on Viajes National Geographic, Grist.org, Gaiacraft, United Indians of All Tribes Foundation, Global Brigades, Earth Train, GROW Worldwide, Beacon Food Forest, Great March for Climate Action, La Prensa Panamá, and more. In autumn 2012, I hosted a photo exhibit in Panama City and attracted hundreds of Panamanians and travelers on an evening where I shared my adventures and human experiences throughout the country. Through my photographs and stories, I was able to inspire others to respect as well as admire the places, cultures, and beauty our world unrelentingly offers. The experience brought tremendous joy, and I intend to continue the path of socially and environmentally impactful photography.One of my latest passions is in sustainable food systems. In the growing season of 2013, I ventured on a 8 and a half-month bicycle journey across the Pacific Northwest and U.S. west coast to intersect learning, service, and art by being immersed in and capturing the intricacies of organic food production on various family-run farms. During my southbound journey towards (then-)home in southern California, I leveraged social media and photography to raise money via Indiegogo to support myself as well as the great work of 350.org and Conservacion Patagonica for the incredible work they have been doing on climate action and land regeneration.Since the summer of 2014, I have been situated in Seattle, Washington and have continued my involvement with the local food system and permaculture transition alongside the great individuals behind the Beacon Food Forest, exploring the magical Olympic/Cascade mountains, while living a simple, low-carbon footprint lifestyle.On August 13, 2015, I hosted a presentation and talk on the work that
 the Conscious Impact team has been doing since the earthquake. Over 30 people attended the event to 
hear about and take part in learning about the efforts, stay connected, 
and pitch in to the work. I am so very grateful for everyone's support 
and plan to host a post-trip event in Seattle upon my return in the fall (last couple weeks of October and/or November).Liz giving an Nepali well-wishingFunding BreakdownI really value transparency, and wish for you to know that the $3000 goal was set based on the following costs and needs. The additional camera equipment include: a second camera body, an extra travel tripod, a microphone, and a portable photo printer (for the postcard perks and printing images for our partners + families we'll be working with and getting to know). I was tipped by a friend to fly in and out of Vancouver, Canada instead of Seattle, Washington due to lower costs (~$240). So I thought even with the additional travel time and bus fare, this is ultimately savings that can keep the budget as low as possible.TimelineMy speculation as to how the following 5 months and beyond will look like with this project. I hope to be able to get the photos from Nepal up for viewing and selection between late October and November of this year, while photo (perks, see below!) deliveries will commence late November and be wrapped up by the first month of 2016. Depending on the progress the Redefined Films crew and I make while in-country and the remote collaboration to follow post-October, we have discussed launching a short film by the end of 2015. I will do my best to keep everyone posted!PerksBesides my (our) sincere gratitude for your support, I would love for you to have something memorable in return.My
 photographs from the 6 weeks in Nepal will be organized, edited, and 
uploaded into a gallery for you to view, read, and learn the context 
& story. If you are able to pitch in at the $70 level or higher, 
please choose your favorite photograph(s) to be printed and mail to you.
 The matting will be custom cut by yours truly to the next popular size,
 e.g. 16"x24" matte for the 12"x18" print, for easy (and beautiful) 
display and/or framing. For the 12"x18" and 16"x24"-sized 
prints, you'd have the opportunity to choose a single or multiple images
 to be made into a collage. Perhaps the most exciting perk I am offering is the 
Photo Book, which is going to be a layflat, flush mount, hard cover 
photo book that's going to have approximately 20 pages filled with my very 
best, hand-picked images from Nepal. The Photo Book measures 6"x8".Shipping
 cost for the enlargements and photo book depends on your location, e.g.
 US least, Canada a bit higher, rest of the world most. A sneak peek - Elliese and Naomi with my matted prints at my Panama 
City photo gallery. I truly, truly enjoy sharing my vision of the world 
with others.About Conscious ImpactConscious Impact's approach is unique in that they are a community and volunteer-led organization. This means that what they do "depends on the interests, desires, and passions of our (their) partners." This includes community members, partner organizations, and volunteers, like myself and others I'll be joined with. My friends have had 7 years of experience working in rural development and international service in Latin America (through where we met) and Africa. They have taken the experience and knowledge and distilled it into their current mission "to inspire, mobilize, and train volunteers to compassionately and selflessly service those in need." The team is in it for international, cross-cultural collaborations, and it is not their intention, like certain big names in the development world, to be in it for the long-run. In my opinion, this should never be the case. Plan B?There really isn't. It's not what I am aiming for. I am (we are) absolutely committed to this project. The
 trip to Nepal is still happening and the 
documentation will still take place, even in the event the goal of $3000 is not reached. Thanks to the flexible funding option of Indiegogo, the raised funds will still come through to make this project a reality. The lower funding and with it the potential financial stress would have a negative impact on my ability to bring forth our experiences in-country to their maximum potential and reach. I believe we can collectively make this happen, and in fact surpass the goal!Connect / Spread the Word!If you have any questions about the work that I'll be doing with the Conscious Impact team, please don't hesitate to contact me directly. This fundraiser has made possible thanks to the superb support that so many of my family and friends have given me. It is curiously difficult to ask for monetary support from those you love and cherish. I absolutely understand if a financial contribution is not possible at this moment, and would be equally thankful if you could share this fundraiser and the work being done. Awareness-raising is invaluable.With gratitude,Jonathan------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Conscious Impact www.consciousimpact.org Facebook: facebook.com/consciousimpact Instagram: @consciousimpactYUWA Unity Nepalwww.yuwaunitynepal.orgABARI www.abari.orgFacebook: facebook.com/abari.nepalInstagram: @abari_nepalRedefined Filmswww.redefinedfilms.orgFacebook: facebook.com/redefined.orgJonathan H. Leewww.subtledream.com Facebook: facebook.com/subtledream Instagram: @subtledreamPhoto creditsImages and video footage from Nepal: Allen Gula, Orion Haas, and Juliette MaasImages of the presentation at the Beacon Food Forest: Caroline GuentherImage of Elliese, Naomi, and I: Laura Solia

story:
"e" inc. Summer Science Camp is just around the corner! We've got 2 action-packed, fun-filled weeks planned and can't wait to get started. Thanks to generous donations from our previous campaign we were able to accept 4 youth from the Charlestown neighborhood on a full scholarship to our program. We have 2 more kids who have applied to the program and are in need of financial assistance. Help us shape their summer by getting these kids to camp for free! 


Growing up in a busy city like Boston, Massachusetts, it is often difficult for urban youth to make the connections between their daily lives and the natural world around them. Many are unfamiliar with the marine species living just under the surface of the Boston Harbor, or have never thought about how their usage of a plastic bag could affect a sea turtle swimming in the Atlantic Ocean.

That’s where “e” inc. comes in! “e” inc. – the environment science learning and action center is a community-based non-profit whose mission is to create scientifically-confident environmental citizens committed to understanding and protecting the Earth. In 2013-2014 alone, “e” inc. provided civics and science sessions to well over 6,000 children and teens in school year residencies and summer intensives at over 20 Greater Boston schools, community centers and other educational institutions.

Our Project

This year, “e” inc. is running its own Summer Science Discovery Program. The program will be based at the “e” inc. Discovery & Action Center in the Charlestown Navy Yard and is open to children ages 6-12. The program is comprised of two 1-week sessions with a different theme each week (Week 1: Our Ocean; Week 2: New England Habitat). Each day will have a hands-on science lesson, exploration of the HarborWalk (fishing and crabbing, planting in raised beds, etc.), and an art project related to the day’s theme. Through a partnership with the Boston Rowing Center, participants will also have the opportunity to learn rowing techniques before setting off to explore the Little Mystic and Boston Harbor by boat. 


How can you help? 

To cover the costs of this program, we must charge $400/week per child. However, it is very important to us that our participant group represents the diversity of the city. We are seeking funding to help subsidize the fee and make the camp more accessible to all families and we need your help! Any donations will go directly to a scholarship fund that will offset costs for low-income families. Our goal of raising $3200 will cover the cost for 8 Boston youth to attend our summer program and have the opportunity to explore the natural side of their city.

Who is "e" inc.?

“e” inc. brings in-depth science investigation programs to low-income communities throughout Greater Boston and has succeeded in capturing the interest of children who face academic, social, and economic challenges.  Our programs engage young people in hands-on science and, as their understanding grows, helps them build skills to make a difference.  It is this particular coupling of academics with community involvement that helps our children make, not just academic gains, but social growth, as well.

Past youth-led action projects have included: school-wide campaigns to save energy by turning off lights, making reusable bags, gardening and composting and writing letters to companies involved in deforestation. 

Our educators come with a wide range of experiences and talents. From mentoring at-risk youth to international work, "e" inc. educators' passion for the environment is only outmatched by their enthusiasm for working with youth. 

Find out more about our staff here: http://www.einc-action.org/our-educators.html


Why environment science? 

At “e” inc. we strongly believe that we are at a critical point in determining the future of our planet’s health. We are all aware of the environmental changes happening around the globe, from climate change to dwindling fish stocks; however, at “e” inc., the conversation doesn’t stop there. In addition to understanding the science behind these changes, we feel it is crucial to teach children that they have the power to make a difference. What may seem like a simple action has the power to inspire others and make change. Through hands-on experiences, “e” inc. kids learn to appreciate nature and are motivated to make a difference for the planet, all the while discovering their valuable place in the ecosystem. 

But, don't just take it from us...


“I just wanted to tell you that today was the best. I faced two fears in one day – I held a crab AND got into a boat and rowed!”
–Dorian, 11 year old from Dorchester, MA


“This is the best day ever! When I get home I’m going to tell my mom all about the sun’s energy!” 
– Kindergartner at Harvard-Kent Elementary School, Charlestown MA

"[The squid dissection and calamari lab] was the most delicious lesson
I’ve ever had!"
– 4th grade student from Jackson Mann Community Center, Boston, MA


"Thanks to "e" inc., our school is now salvaging buckets of untouched, packaged food, that was headed for the barrel and redistributing it to students in need of snacks." 
- Anthony Sharp, John F. Kennedy School Science Teacher, Somerville, MA

“"e" inc. is one of our most prized partnerships and I recommend their program to other schools with no reservations!” 
– Nicole Young, Josiah Quincy Elementary School, Community Partnership Coordinator, Boston, MA

For more information on “e” inc., check out our website: www.einc-action.org

"[The squid dissection and calamari lab] was the most delicious lessonI’ve ever had!"– 4th grade student from Jackson Mann Community Center, Boston, MA
"Thanks to "e" inc., our school is now salvaging buckets of untouched, packaged food, that was headed for the barrel and redistributing it to students in need of snacks." - Anthony Sharp, John F. Kennedy School Science Teacher, Somerville, MA

For more information on “e” inc., check out our website: www.einc-action.org

story:
A Quick Background

Hello everyone!  Megan here.

I'm writing today because I need a favor. But, it's a really good favor.  I promise! As many of you know (and if you don't know you are about to find out), I recently accepted a position as a program associate with an organization called Exponential Education in Ghana, west Africa. Expo is honestly one of the coolest initiatives I have come across and I am so thrilled to be working for them! 

Essentially, in Ghana children have to pay to attend high school.  While the fees may seem small, many children cannot afford it.  Additionally, middle school students have to pass an entrance exam to get into high school, and currently 60% of students don't pass this exam.  Expo has found a way to help these students.  Through their peer-tutoring program, they work with schools to find high school students who are struggling to pay their school fees.  They give those students a stipend to cover their fees, and in return those students tutor five middle school students to help them pass their entrance exam into high school.  Then at the end, the most dedicated high school student receives a scholarship to go to university. Pretty cool huh?! They also offer a girls leadership program, teacher training, college prep, and other things.  It's all pretty wonderful.

The Impact

As you read this summary, over 150 Ghanaian students that used to be at-risk of dropping out of school or failing school entrance exams are now studying, teaching and receiving free tutoring and scholarships this week in order to build themselves a better future.

To date, Exponential Education has successfully completed over 45 Exponential Education programs. That means that the organization has provided over 45 college scholarships for high school students, 225 high school assistance stipends to keep students financially at risk of dropping out enrolled in school, and provided free tutoring in basic Math and English to over 1350 students. 

Here's where you come in.  Expo is a very small organization.  And each program only costs $500 to run.  $500=5 high school students staying in high school+25 middle school students receiving tutoring+1 student receiving a university scholarship. So, $500 goes a long way, but it needs to come from somewhere.  So please pretty please, donate a little (or if you can, donate a lot!)

As it will be my job as a program associate to run one of these tutoring programs in one high school and one middle school, $500 can ensure that an group of students I work with can reach their full potential.  However, there are other program associates and other schools that need funding too, so I’m aiming to raise $1500!

Ways You Can Help

After donating, if you want, dump a bucket of ice cold water over your head to encourage others to donate, share this link on facebook, tell your coworker or your mom or your neighbor about it and ask them to donate, donate again.  The options are endless!  Go ahead, get creative, but please help me spread the word!

Check out Expo’s website for more details! http://www.exponentialeducationprogram.org/

story:
This program has the capacity for me to build upon and transcend my knowledge base, giving me the confidence and professionalism in moving forward with my practice.  My goal in 2019 is to start my Ayurvedic Nutrition Therapy practice.

I started with massage therapy, then continued my studies at the California School of Herbal studies.  In addition, I have also completed two Ayurvedic courses.  The first course was at the Dhyana Center, and the second was through the American Institute of Vedic studies.  I then sought to learn more about the business side of my practice which led me to the discovery of Mercy Corp Northwest.  There I took many helpful business classes, wrote up my business proposal, and was awarded a small business grant.

I deeply regard the health of the body, but also the well being of one's spirit and heart.  Along side I have been on the path of meditation and mystical priestess work, currently in my fifth year with Blue Iris Mystery School.

As you can see, I have invested my time, energy and money into my dreams and passions.  Now I feel ready to dive in deeper with this nutrition program. 

I am applying for the nutrition practitioner program offered by the well renowned Nutritional Therapy Association: https://www.nutritionaltherapy.com/service/nutritional-therapy-programs/nutritional-therapy-practitioner-ntp 

The course costs $5,900, including books.  

Join me in this awakening of health, and help me raise the money for tuition!

Donate any amount, your gift is appreciated!

Energetic donations are just as powerful and needed.  I would love 'well wishes' with getting the scholarship if it's in the highest good of all living things.

All the money I raise will go towards tuition.  I hope to get a scholarship to pay for the rest.
story_txt: This program has the capacity for me to build upon and transcend my knowledge base, giving me the confidence and professionalism in moving forward with my practice.  My goal in 2019 is to start my Ayurvedic Nutrition Therapy practice.I started with massage therapy, then continued my studies at the California School of Herbal studies.  In addition, I have also completed two Ayurvedic courses.  The first course was at the Dhyana Center, and the second was through the American Institute of Vedic studies.  I then sought to learn more about the business side of my practice which led me to the discovery of Mercy Corp Northwest.  There I took many helpful business classes, wrote up my business proposal, and was awarded a small business grant.I deeply regard the health of the body, but also the well being of one's spirit and heart.  Along side I have been on the path of meditation and mystical priestess work, currently in my fifth year with Blue Iris Mystery School.As you can see, I have invested my time, energy and money into my dreams and passions.  Now I feel ready to dive in deeper with this nutrition program. I am applying for the nutrition practitioner program offered by the well renowned Nutritional Therapy Association: https://www.nutritionaltherapy.com/service/nutritional-therapy-programs/nutritional-therapy-practitioner-ntp The course costs $5,900, including books.  Join me in this awakening of health, and help me raise the money for tuition!Donate any amount, your gift is appreciated!Energetic donations are just as powerful and needed.  I would love 'well wishes' with getting the scholarship if it's in the highest good of all living things.All the money I raise will go towards tuition.  I hope to get a scholarship to pay for the rest.

story:
What Is REBEL VERSES?

REBEL VERSES is a two-week festival of performances by some of the best youth companies in the region. Unlike any other theatre festival, REBEL VERSES provides an opportunity for high school students to perform their own original work and to celebrate the work of their peers, and gives audiences a platform for open dialogue with emerging young artists from New York City and around the region.

Now in its 13th year, the festival was born out of the need for a platform where young artists can express themselves honestly and in an environment that recognizes the legitimacy of all stories and backgrounds. With a mission to journey into the unapologetic and unrestrained creativity of the next generation, REBEL VERSES values diverse stories ranging across age, sex, race and time.

REBEL VERSES 2015. Photo by Bobby Rodriguez. Featuring Sydney Steward (left), Jaryd Jones (right).

The 2017 Festival spans two weekends with six performances from July 27 through August 5. The performances feature original work from eight high school student ensembles: MCC Theatre, PRY SAFE Lutheran, The Door, Alumni Theatre Company of Pittsburgh,  Epic Theatre Ensemble, Savage Squad, and Developing Artists with The Vineyard's own Vineyard Theatre Student Ensemble. During the Festival, students participate in several workshops with guest artists, including two-time Tony Award nominee Daphne Rubin-Vega. For the first time, Developing Artists is partnering with Vineyard Theatre to produce the event, giving over 70 students a chance to perform their original work on an Off-Broadway stage at The Vineyard’s home in the heart of Union Square.

 

The Festival's Impact In Numbers

 

Here's Where You Come In

REBEL VERSES is constantly growing and evolving. This year, the Festival’s relocation to The Vineyard means an opportunity for larger audiences, more technical support, and a bigger, better festival. For the first time students will perform in an Off-Broadway theatre, a larger venue than ever before. This expansion also means higher costs to ensure the festival runs smoothly and successfully. Since The Vineyard and Developing Artists are also committed to ensuring the Festival is affordable to the student’s family, each participating student receives two complimentary tickets, leaving the expenses of the Festival covered primarily by donations rather than ticket sales.

Vineyard Theatre is inviting you to partner with us in producing REBEL VERSES. The goal is to raise $7,500 towards supporting new voices in the arts.

 

Where Your Money Is Going

Contributions will support free tickets for friends and family of student artists, low cost tickets for students and educators, Vineyard’s front- and back-of-house staff working directly on the Festival, and audio equipment so the voices of our young artists can be heard loud and clear. All gifts up to our goal of $7,500 will go directly towards the Festival’s budget. Any funds raised beyond the budget will support The Vineyard’s growing education programs, which partners with New York City public high schools in the Union Square neighborhood to provide professional training and arts education experiences to over 650 high school students every year at no cost.

 

Rebel Perks

To thank you for supporting young artists, The Vineyard has arranged a collection of exciting perks. From VIP tickets for REBEL VERSES Opening Night, to a playwriting bootcamp with Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Paula Vogel, to Vineyard Theatre swag, your donation will not go unnoticed! To donate, click on the desired perk above or type in your own donation level. Perks can be picked up at the Festival or will be sent in August.

 

Can't Get Enough of REBEL VERSES ?

Here’s how else you can help!

  1. Purchase tickets to REBEL VERSES , starting at just $20!
  2. Continue to support Vineyard's Education or Artistic programming by contacting Jessie Pitluk, Vineyard Theatre's Director of Development, at jpitluk@vineyardtheatre.org or 212-353-3366 x1227
  3. Learn more about Developing Artists.
  4. See The Vineyard’s other work or get involved with the theatre's educational programming at vineyardtheatre.org.

 

Thank You!

Thank you so much for your donation to The Vineyard's campaign and for your support of new student work. We are excited you are part of REBEL VERSES !
 
For more information or with questions about perks contact Jessie Pitluk, Director of Development, at jpitluk@vineyardtheatre.org or 212-353-3366 x1227.

story:
Short Summary

Our names are Juan Pablo Jiménez-Caicedo and María Eugenia Lozano Lenis and we are educators in Language, Literacy and Culture at Columbia University and Barnard College in New York City.

We were born, raised and earned our undergraduate education in the midst of the Colombian internal armed conflict (Guerrilla and paramilitary warfare, drug trafficking, political violence, etc.). In addition, we both know first-hand what poverty, inequality, racism and discrimination, political, physical, verbal and symbolic violence are. Therefore, we deeply believe that WE ALL SHOULD ACT NOW AND STAND AGAINST ALL THOSE ILLS THAT OUR  COUNTRY  -AND THE WHOLE WORLD BY EXTENSION- HAVE EXPERIENCE THROUGH OUR LONG HISTORY.

For instance,  we strongly believe that in order to have the long awaited peace in OUR HOME COUNTRY COLOMBIA, every Colombian citizen and their allies need to contribute what they can. Thus, we are starting this our first fundraising campaign to secure the necessary funds to establishing a non-for-profit and nongovernmental international organization entitled:

CON PALABRAS

“TOWARD A MORE PEACEFUL AND HUMANE SOCIETY ONE WORD AND ONE ACT AT TIME: Changing a word as an act of consciousness, changing the world as an act of consciousness”

(The Jiménez-Lozano Family, NYC May 5, 2014)

As seasoned educators ourselves both in Colombia and in The United States, our main goal is to contribute our two cents in the efforts of making our home country of Colombia a more peaceful and humane place through ACCESS TO HIGH QUALITY K-16 PUBLIC EDUCATION FOR ALL COLOMBIANS IN EVERY SINGLE CORNER OF OUR COUNTRY. We believe that our two children -Samuelito and Nicolás- and the children of all Colombians deserve a better and more peaceful and just future in our nation and elsewhere. We in our family have made this our life-long project and we welcome with open arms anyone who shares our beliefs.

Every dollar and act of individual capacity will be used towards our grassroots efforts to educate children and adults in Colombia and overseas, as well as the general public, about and with concrete ways for making Colombia a more humane and peaceful country. The very first instance of this is already ongoing. We have being running a campaign over Facebook and social media entitled "LET'S BRING PEACE TO COLOMBIA ONE WORD AT A TIME / CONSTRUYAMOS LA PAZ EN COLOMBIA PALABRA POR PALABRA".  It consists of an awareness raising operation concerning the realization and removal of racist and discriminatory language (words, expressions and sayings) engraved in Colombia’s every day oral and written discourse. 

What We Need & What You Get

The initial goal is to raise $3,000.00 towards the attorney and legal fees for establishing our non-for-profit and non-governmental international organization both in New York, USA and in Cali, Colombia.

  • The funds raised through this initial campaign via Indiegogo will be used toward legally establishing our non-for-profit and non-governmental international organization in the United States and in Colombia.  The remaining funds -if any- will be used toward the cost of promotional materials (bookmarks, pencils, pens, fliers, posters, and related literature and inexpensive perks) to let our local communities both in NYC and in Cali, Colombia about our nascent organization (www.conpalabras.org). These items will benefit the very first grassroots teach-ins, workshops and related campaigns in New York city and in Cali Colombia in the summer and fall of 2014.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Remember that in addition to financial contributions we accept the contributions of an individual’s knowledge, time or capabilities. If you’d like to help in any capacity, please email conpalabras14@gmail.com, we’d love to hear from you. And of course, if all you can give is a moment of your time to pass this information along then you have our utmost and eternal gratitude.

story:
Hi my name is Geoffrey Zehner, I'm 27 years old. I currently work in Texas and I am also taking Courses through flight school to hopefully one day be a pilot!
To this point I have used my own money every payday to try and support my family (Wife and Child) and also pay for my courses to finally have a career! However I am now at the point where I could use some help so after looking online found this site and thought to myself "I've made it this far why give up now!? I'm giving it a shot"
I'm coming to you today with one question, Can you help me Soar? Many of you who have been so close to your dream that you could almost grab it know exactly how I feel right now!
I currently need right at $7,000 to finish my courses for flight school. Please don't let that number shock you! I am not asking just one person to hand me $7,000, instead I want to ask 1,400 friends/family/and strangers to help with just $5.00 each, or 700 for $10.00 each or maybe 350 for $20.00 each! However you want to donate, even just encouraging messages to not give up will really help, and if you donate money how much is up to you! Even if 2,800 friends/family/and strangers donate just $2.50 I would be so thankful!
Life offers so many dreams for so many people, you are helping fulfill my dream with either donations or encouraging comments! You may ask, Will my flying change the world? It could! One day I could be flying and think of a way to make flying safer for future generations! Anything is possible! So could you possibly help my dream come true?
If my goal is met I will be so thankful to all who donated, both those who donated time to write and those who donated the funds I need! If my goal is not met I will still be thankful for those who donated! I will not give up and I will continue to find a way to make my dream come true! If my goal is exceeded, I will donate the extra funds to the other (hopeful) future pilots at the flight school that I know are also struggling to make a career! They will also know it was due to all of you on here that helped make a difference in my life that it also helped with theirs!

story:
Support Green School Debate!

The Green School of Baltimore is a small, innovative charter school in Baltimore City, focused on environmental education.  For the past four years, we've had an award-winning debate team participating in the Baltimore Urban Debate League. The experience has been rich for the students, complimenting their literacy and science education in the classroom with authentic opportunities to do research and create arguments about topics such as whether Baltimore should install solar panels on all Baltimore City Public Schools or whether Baltimore should continue to fund its Bikeshare program. 

Decreased funding for charter schools, however, has left the Debate Team with a funding deficit. The community is banding together to reduce costs; but, we are still shy of what we need to participate.

We have a team of 20 kids ready to work hard at learning the finer points of debate -- thinking on their toes, supporting their arguments with evidence, asking insightful and probing questions in cross-examination, and reiterating their points through their rebuttals. All we need is your support to make it happen!

If you are not in position to help, even with a small donation, please consider sharing this request with your friends. Every little bit helps!

story:
I am not only honored but extremely pleased to support this project. It is an important contribution to the work of scholars and to the survival of phenomenology.

Rudolf Bernet, Husserl Archives Leuven


What We Want To Do


We have been building the Open Commons for a year already. As you can judge for yourself from our website, we are making solid progress. Now is the time to accelerate the project's development and turn it into a truly comprehensive and sustainable resource. To achieve this, we have set ourselves three great objectives - to be completed with your generous support in the next 12 months:


 1. Input the full bibliographies of at least 10 major authors

We've selected Brentano, Scheler, Stein, Patočka, Ingarden, Fink, Sartre, Levinas, Derrida and Henry. Write to us to add others!


2. Digitise Edmund Husserl's complete work in German

All digitised texts will be made available immediately in open access under a CC-BY license. In other words, you can access AND use them completely for free.

3. Translate parts of Husserl's correspondence into English

Letters to Brentano, Frege, Stumpf, Dilthey, Scheler, Cassirer, Heidegger, Fink, Patočka, Jaspers. All translations will also be made available immediately under a CC-BY license.


This initiative will surely strengthen and improve the ongoing work of scholars of various brands of phenomenological philosophy all over the world.
Sonja Rinofner-Kreidl, Graz University


Who We Are


The Open Commons of Phenomenology is an international, not-for-profit project with a clear mission: we want to provide open access to the entire corpus of phenomenology and to develop the best tools for anyone interested in using or working scientifically with these texts.

We are proud to be supported by a string of prominent scholars in phenomenology such as Natalja Avtonomova, Renaud Barbaras, Simon Critchley, Shaun Gallagher, Sara Heinämaa, Bernard Stiegler, Toru Tani, Bernhard Waldenfels, Roberto Walton, and Dan Zahavi.


You can get regular updates and insider information on all aspects of the Open Commons by subscribing to our blog "Backstage"

The Open Commons project strikes me as a very important and rich undertaking that will not only bring phenomenology's history to the larger public but will also orient future research in significant ways.
Antonio Calcagno, Western University 


What You Get


Easy Search
Because its content is highly-structured and focused, the Open Commons makes it ultra easy to find authors and references. No more endless crawling through Google! You can even find re-editions, translations and reviews of most references with a single extra click.

Access to Texts

Once you have found a reference, instead of having to rely on your library or navigate through archive.org, you can quickly access and download it from the repository. The Open Commons already contains many hard to find sources, and will soon include many many more.

Exhaustive Overviews

Want to know what Husserl published between 1925 and 1930? Need an overview of phenomenological literature on the topic of inter-subjectivity or social norm? Have to check what Merleau-Ponty wrote on memory? There will be no better to place to find an authoritative answer than the Open Commons.

Automated Bibliographies & Citations

The Open Commons allows to create specific bibliographies simply be selecting references from the database. You can then format them in the style you need and export them to your computer. Soon, it'll also allow you to copy/paste quotes, with the citation reference!

Collaborative, Incremental Research

Many researchers will be contributing to the Open Commons. This means it will be kept constantly up-to-date, that errors will be corrected incrementally, and that annotations can be organised and shared. The Open Commons will also favour the visibility and dissemination of phenomenological research, benefiting both you individually and phenomenology as a whole.

story:
CONFUCIUS (551-479 BC) | "If your plan is for one year plant rice. If your plan is for ten years plant trees. If your plan is for one hundred years educate children. "

My name is Daniel Hagadorn and I have loved every minute of teaching high school history, government, and economics for the last twelve years. As an educational "insider", those experiences convinced me that our government school system long-ago charted a dark path designed to incrementally deepen our ignorance. In fact, this system has been useful only as a method for mass producing kids into mindless consumers and low-information voters.

Although it is not exactly breaking news that our public school system is failing--and badly--very few know just how bad it is. Why is it that although the problems of government schooling have been painfully obvious for quite some time now...yet year after year...nothing changes?

All of the "eduspeak" floating around about helping kids achieve their fullest potential is just so much paper posted on a classroom wall.

Think back over your own school experiences. Do you remember your potential being cultivated and developed...or simply ignored and cast aside?

Of all the questions I have heard during my professional career as an educator, the one question that has haunted me most is this: "What if our government school system is actually succeeding beyond all expectation...because it was intentionally designed to fail our children?" [After you read the book, you may wish you never heard the question either].

Of course, change can never happen until people first become informed about the problem. That is why I wrote this book. To give the reader easy access to the maximum of information in the minimum of space.

To put this vital information into the hands of parents and concerned citizens, I am attempting to raise $3,500 to fund two specific objectives: (1) self-publication and (2) marketing of the book. The first 500 to donate $5 or more will receive an official Neo Maxi Zoom Dweebie replica (see Breakfast Club for reference), the first 50 people to donate $25 or more will receive a signed copy of the book, and the first 20 to donate $150 or more will also enjoy a meet-and-greet at a local coffeehouse.

I am grateful for anything you can do to get this information out.....prayers, "happy thoughts", contributions of any size, or simply sharing this information with anyone who wants to make a difference.

Thank you for your time and consideration!
story_txt:
CONFUCIUS (551-479 BC) | "If your plan is for one year plant rice. If your plan is for ten years plant trees. If your plan is for one hundred years educate children. "
My name is Daniel Hagadorn and I have loved every minute of teaching high school history, government, and economics for the last twelve years. As an educational "insider", those experiences convinced me that our government school system long-ago charted a dark path designed to incrementally deepen our ignorance. In fact, this system has been useful only as a method for mass producing kids into mindless consumers and low-information voters.

Although it is not exactly breaking news that our public school system is failing--and badly--very few know just how bad it is. Of course, change can never happen until people first become informed about the problem. That is why I wrote this book. To give the reader easy access to the maximum of information in the minimum of space.

story:
Alternative Spring Break is a program that is coordinated out of Arizona State University at Changemaker Central. The goal of the program is to teach students about a particular social issue, such as poverty, education reform, refugee resettlement, and the environment. Alternative Spring Break challenges ASU students to become immersed in diverse environments and enables participants to experience, discuss, and understand social issues in a significant way. ASB shows college students invaluable experiences, and motivates them to contribute and improve their surrounding communities.

Last year, ASB successfully coordinated three trips; Camp Cambell Science Camp, Habitat for Humanity in Los Angeles, and Special Delivery, Habitat for Humanity, and St. Vincent de Paul in San Diego. This year, we hope to create four trips to new communities across the United States. To do this, we have to raise the money ourselves to afford parts of the trip such as flight, shelter, food, and other accommodations to make the trip as fun and exciting for the students as possible! Specifically, we have to raise $4,500 by March 2014!

On November 20th, 2013, we will be hosting an event at the Trunk Space in Downtown Phoenix. At the event, we will have live music, a photo booth, and cupcakes, all affordable for the students and friends that will be attending. After this event, we will be fundraising any way that we can to earn the money to make these four trips happen! 

No amount is too small for our goal; we are determined to make our financial goal and to have the best, most successful Alternative Spring Break possible! And if you can't donate, please feel free to share the word about this cause if you are as passionate about this cause as we are! No matter what, we are grateful for the contributions the community has provided us with! Thank you for helping us to make this year the best Alternative Spring Break EVER!

 

With Gratitude, 

The ASB Student Leadership Team

story:
A Tribute to Melat’s Life

November 23 will forever be seared in our mind as the day we lost our dearest friend and sister Melat Woldearegay. She was planning for her dreams and happiness when she unexpectedly passed from this world in a tragic car accident. Her sudden departure has shaken us to the core and left a gaping hole in our hearts. Regret has engulfed our hearts as we thought we had plenty of time to tell Melat what an extraordinary human being she was or how so loved and admired she was and STILL IS.

We so love Melat’s: bigger than life personality that lit up a room; excessive loyalty, sometimes to a fault, to her friends and family;  relentless support to those she loved no matter what they do or where they are in life; ability to instantly connect with people from all walks of life – Melat never met a stranger; and her amazing sense of humor and contagious enthusiasm.

We admire Melat’s: boundless generosity and kindness that extended beyond family and friends; intelligence and unmatched eloquence that left a lasting impression on anyone that crossed her path; innate leadership that made her the defacto chief in any circumstance; ability to put on a brave face even amidst the most trying of circumstances; and ability to be the queen bee and worker bee all at once during parties (we  fondly remember the countless times Melat bossed us around at parties, while she also worked tirelessly in the kitchen, leading the cleanup crew after weddings/events).

Melat was many things to many people. We will always remember her boundless energy, and love for life, family and friends. Her passing 90 days ago has made our world colder and the sun dimmer. As we grapple with the loss of Melat, her friends and classmates want to honor her life and all that she embodied. Those who knew Melat closely remember how much she loved books; since childhood,  she was a voracious reader, who continually strived to stretch her mind by reading all types of books. 

As a tribute to Melat’s legacy and her love for books, we want to raise fund to refurbish Nazareth School’s library – the school where Melat spent 12 years of her childhood. The donation will be used to physically expand the library and create a better system that would provide better reading facility for the girls.  We have $570 leftover from her memorial service but we want to raise at least 100,000 birr.   We kindly ask anyone who has been touched by Melat’s life and wants to honor her to contribute to this cause and help us exceed this goal.  No contribution is too small so please donate whatever you can.

Please free to write how you know Melat and what she means to you…

The school would place a plaque (with Melat's picture,etc) in the Library in memory of Melat.

God bless you!!

Nazareth School Class of 1991

story:
Dear family and friends:
I have been honored with the opportunity to go on our Sandia High School DECA New York Experience Conference that is being held in New York City November 19- November 24th. Our flight, hotel, transportation, conference fees and tours are some of the fee's we need to cover. Some of the places we will be touring include Wall Street, The Garment District, The Empire State Building, The Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, The Metropolitan Museum, The Museum of Natural History, NBC Studios, Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum, Good Morning America, Central Park, Rockefeller Center, a Broadway production and the Christmas Spectacular  at Radio City Hall. This trip will give me an inside prospective into marketing techniques that are unique to New York.
The total trip will cost approximately $1,200. We are working on putting together a T-Shirt to recognize our business partners that we will wear during our travels, and we can include your name or business on the back for a recommended $100 donation. Our first deposit of $450 is due by October 14. The second deposit of $400 is due October 28, and the final deposit of $350 is due November 8.
Thank you so much for any donation towards helping me make it to The Big Apple. I know I will never forget this trip. Donations towards my trip may be tax deductible, please make your check or money order payable to Sandia High School DECA, and you may send them to me, or mail them to: SHS DECA,7801 Candelaria NE, Albuquerque, New Mexico 87110. Also please include my name in the memo section of your check so the money goes to my set of donations. Once again thank you so much for your support! If you have any questions for my teacher (Linda WIlson) you can call her at 294-1511 extension number 30316 or email her atwilson_l2aps.edu

With lots of love and thanks,
Alyssa Sisneros

story:
Intro

Hello there! 

My name is Iris Veldwijk and I'm currently a student at Maastricht University, the Netherlands. My friends who have participated in the Mongol Rally 2013 (http://www.theadventurists.com/the-adventures/mongol-rally) inspired me to rally along in 2014, after my graduation. I'll drive from Maastricht to London - where the official start is - and from London to Ulan Baatar, Mongolia! A 15.555 kilometer journey for...

CHARITY!

I feel lucky to have grown up in a country where I got the same educational opportunities as my male peers, but this is unfortunately not the case for every girl who grows up. If girls in the developing world receive education at all, it often ends before they become adolescents. It will be your and my gift to impact and empower these girls to become who they want to become and be on the forefront of ending the perpetual cycle of poverty. The charity I'm running for is The Girl Effect (www.girleffect.org/), because it suits the ideas described above. Updated will be on my Facebook page: www.facebook.com/MR2014IrisVeldwijk

Here's what's going to happen:

I'm going to drive a car with a short life-span for European standards to Mongolia, where it will be donated and live on for another couple of decades. In the mean time, you and I will raise a load of money for the charity, which will end up at the individuals who need it (girls). I'll make a video diary of the 4-6 week trip, driving through approximately 22 countries, taping all the happiness and hardship that the car is going through, while rocking to YOUR MUSIC! (see Perks!)

What We Need & What You Get

There are three ways in which you can help: donating physical materials (see "other ways you can help"), donating money (see "perks") and sharing this project on social media and to people you know who might be willing to donate. If you know a company that might want to sponsor big time and get advertising on the car, you can send me an e-mail.

The funding I need at the very least is:

€1200 raised for charity (of course I hope to way go over this, and if I raise a lot, I'll announce a second charity to divide the money over)

€540 entry fee (This is approximately 1/3 of last year's Mongol Rally entry fee, without it I won't even start)

€900 fuel costs (16.000 km/14[km/L] × 0.80 [Average diesel price/L])

€800 Visas (10 visas in total)

Once this campaign is finished I'll start another one that focuses solely on charity, but first I need to get this started. Because I love transparent accounting, I'll keep a detailed log - published online - of all the money that comes in to console all donors that the money is going where they wanted it to go. Before and after Mongol Rally.

See the Perks for what your donation will get YOU!

ALL DONORS will get a shout-out from the Facebook page!

The Impact

This project is one very close to my heart and mind: I'm writing my Bachelor's Thesis currently on girl's education. As much as I love the academic, I only think my research is relevant if it has a real world application. That's exactly why I'm raising the money for this project. Come on board and let's impact and empower girls together!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute money, there are other ways to contribute to this project; donating stuff. Here's a list of stuff you might have lying around and don't really use or might just want to donate:

Duct tape

WB-40

Puncture seal cans

Metal jerry cans

Ratchet straps

Tow rope

Elastic cords

Roof rack (big enough to do yoga on)

Standard car tool kit

Air filters

Fan belt

Epoxy gas tank sealer

Small speakers for music

Jumper leads

Collapsible water container 6-10 L

Water treatment tablets

Camp stove (1 person)

Camp cook set (1 person)

Emergency Blanket

Battery operated lantern

Medical kit

Rehydration tablets

Tarpaulin

Emergency food kit 72 hrs

Lonely Planets: Iran, Kazachstan, Russia, Mongolia

Maps of Central Asia

Solar power panel to charge devices

Walkie Talkies

Mongolian phrase book

Bribes for police and customs: cigarettes, energy drinks and small bottles of alcohol

story:
My name is Nic Burgess and for the past 4 years I have been a horror photographer and photomanipulation artist. I have been featured in many magazines across the world and have a pretty awesome fan base. Enough about me, we are here because I would have never been able to even attempt my photography dream if it was not for all the hard work my amazing fiance Jennifer Zimmerman put into me following my dream. 
Jenn really wants to go to Norquest Collage here in Edmonton and attend the Health Care Aide program in SEPT. I am asking for your help in helping me send her there, so she can live out one of her dreams!

I need your help!

I do not make enough money to pay for this alone. But I can do lots of other awesome things and if you are willing to help. Then you are in for some awesome stuff.

Quick Facts

Credential Outcome: Certificate

Length: 21 weeks (full-time), 32 weeks (part-time), 12

months (workplace) 

Term Start: Fall Start (September),Winter Start

(January),Spring Start (May),Varies

Fees & Expenses

Canadian Students

Total Tuition: $2,800.00

Total Fees: $973.50



Please share this if you can not donate.
Thank you.
