My name is Nic Burgess and for the past 4 years I have been a horror photographer and photomanipulation artist. I have been featured in many magazines across the world and have a pretty awesome fan base. Enough about me, we are here because I would have never been able to even attempt my photography dream if it was not for all the hard work my amazing fiance Jennifer Zimmerman put into me following my dream. Jenn really wants to go to Norquest Collage here in Edmonton and attend the Health Care Aide program in SEPT. I am asking for your help in helping me send her there, so she can live out one of her dreams!I need your help!I do not make enough money to pay for this alone. But I can do lots of other awesome things and if you are willing to help. Then you are in for some awesome stuff.
Quick Facts
Credential Outcome: Certificate
Length: 21 weeks (full-time), 32 weeks (part-time), 12
months (workplace) 
Term Start: Fall Start (September),Winter Start
(January),Spring Start (May),Varies

Fees & Expenses
Canadian Students
Total Tuition: $2,800.00
Total Fees: $973.50

Please share this if you can not donate.Thank you.

story:
Background

My name is Patrick Dane Carson and I am a pre-service Peace Corps Volunteer.  I am from Santa Cruz, California, and have a BA in International Studies with a specialization in Central American Studies, and a Master of Arts in Communications with a specialization in Intercultural Communications, from Hawai'i Pacific University (HPU). To learn more about me and my endeavors visit my blog: http://englishforbeachpurposes.blogspot.com/

Currently, I am enrolled in the Peace Corps Master International program of Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages (PCMI TESOL)  at the Monterey Institute of International Studies  (MIIS), a graduate school of Middlebury College, located in Monterey, California.  As a PCMI TESOL candidate, I depart January 23, of 2014 for Port Vila, Vanuatu, to begin my volunteer service with Project VITEL (Vanuatu Information Technology and English Literacy), eventually returning to Monterey in March of 2016.

As a Peace Corps Volunteer, my primary role will be English Literacy Trainer/Teacher, and I will be assigned to a primary school to support the Ministry of Education's Literacy Project with the intent "of improving the quality of basic education by promoting the enhancement of teaching skills and methodologies, resulting in higher literacy levels and effective learning by students" (Peace Corps, 2013).  Furthermore, Project VITEL aims to "build up a strong literacy foundation in primary schools in order to improve dropping literacy rates throughout the country" by providing training and support for professional and untrained teachers alike (ibid.).

As an English Literacy Trainer/Teacher, my focus will be to combine the teaching of phonics, and beginning reading/writing, to rural primary teachers and their students by hopefully integrating a CALL based approach (computer assisted language learning) where/when contextually appropriate, as more computers gradually find their way into the rural communities and schools of Vanuatu. 

On the note of appropriateness, the implementation of such materials can be problematized from a critical discursive point of view. If you are interested in learning more about education in the colonial context, I highly recommend Paulo Freire's (1970) Pedagogy of the Oppressed.  With this in mind, the materials I will bring to Vanuatu are primarily for my discrete/discreet personal .  Thereafter, communal implementation is contingent upon the expressed desire of the community I will serve.  As such, when and if these materials will be integrated very prudently as my objective is not to provide "hand outs" to communities with limited resources, rather to teach them sustainable skills that can be enhanced or better facilitated by technologies when relevant and appropriate.

To see one of my related projects, visit http://sites.miis.edu/eflhaiti/ for more information on how technology can be integrated into the rural classroom using technologies.

The Campaign

As a pre-service Peace Corps Volunteer, Alphabet Soup Vanuatu: A campaign to feed the hunger of the literate mind, is my personal fundraising campaign intended to raise money to acquire pedagogical tools that will support my endeavors as a language educator volunteering with Project VITEL in rural Vanuatu. 

According to Peace Corps, "virtually all primary schools in Vanuatu lack financial and material resources, which can be very challenging.  For example, you might arrive at school only to find that you have no text books, or that what you do have is in poor condition or out of date" (2013, p. 9).  Additionally, the lack of resources such as paper, writing utensils, electricity, and internet pose a challenge to volunteers. 

Best put in Peace Corps' Project VITEL assignment handbook, "regardless of your assignment you will undoubtedly experience some hardships and perhaps some frustration.  You will have to tap into your own creative and problem solving abilities in order to find your place in the school community and make a positive contribution" (2013, p. 9).

With a little foresight as a pre-service volunteer, this campaign is an attempt to creatively solve the problems posed by the lack of pedagogical resources.  As such, I have come up with a wish-list of useful resources for rural education that will mitigate some of the infrastructural/geographic challenges faced by educators in rural communities.  With this in mind, I hope to raise money so that I can acquire useful teaching tools that will allow me to better serve my future students and community.

The Wish List

 The following list provides information about each resource that I will purchase will the funds raised by this campaign, their intended use, and the approximate cost.  I have inserted links that provide more information about each item.  Furthermore, I will document the implementation of these tools on my blog (which is almost ready to launch).

1) 2 XO Laptop's: "The XO laptop was designed especially for children. It has a rugged plastic exterior, built-in wireless, a unique dual mode display that is readable under direct sunlight and software designed for children to encourage exploration, creativity, and collaboration"

Use: To teach phonics, reading, and computer literacies.  See http://sites.miis.edu/eflhaiti/ for information pertaining to my involvement with the XO laptop, OLPC, St. Andre's Episcopal School in Hinche, Haiti, and the Monterey Institute of International Studies (MIIS).

Cost: under $200 each - whatever the eBay XO market will bear

http://www.olpcnews.com/laptops/xo1/how_to_buy_xo_laptop_olpc.html

http://www.amazon.com/b?ie=UTF8&node=721521011

2) Goal Zero Sherpa 120 Adventure Kit: A 27-watt foldable solar panel and a battery pack to store energy converted from sunlight. Running at 17-18% efficiency, this solar charger can bring the battery pack to full within 5-10 hours, depending on the strength of sunlight.

Use: One of the challenges faced by educators in rural Vanuatu is that it lacks infrastructure.  With that said, the solar kit will be used to charge electronic devices in communities with no electricity.

cost: $676.00

http://www.impactbattery.com/sherpa-120-explorer-kit.html?gclid=COnmjIrfsbsCFQbl7AodexAAUA

or Goal Zero Yeti 150 Solar Generator Kit:

Cost: $399.98

http://www.goalzero.com/p/166/goal-zero-yeti-150-solar-generator-kit

or....

Voltaic Generator Solar Laptop Charger: This waterproof laptop case from Voltaic Systems fits up to a 17" MacBook Pro, and features a 15 watt solar panel and a 50Wh battery that can be charged in roughly 8 hours of direct sunlight

Cost: $459.00

3) DreamPlug: A low power plug computer that can act as any type of network server.

Use: DreamPlug will be used to host Pathagar which is a book server that can host up to 40,000 texts that facilitates networking: http://www.slideshare.net/sverma/pathagar-a-book-server

-Cost: $168.04 on Amazon

http://www.amazon.com/Globalscale-DreamPlug-036000291452-Class-Server/dp/B0053GBB5Y

https://www.globalscaletechnologies.com/t-dreamplugdetails.aspx

 

4) InFocus IN114 Portable DLP Projector

Cost: $438.93 (includes soft carry case/SVGA monitor cable 25ft)

Use: To provide visual support of lesson materials for students (texts, movies, photographs, student projects, teacher training materials, etc.) in settings that might not have resources such as chalk/chalkboard.

 http://www.amazon.com/InFocus-IN114-Portable-Projector-Lumens/dp/B004YRUDN4%3FSubscriptionId%3DAKIAICE7LOAJMK3SSLPA%26tag%3Dp00935-20%26linkCode%3Dxm2%26camp%3D2025%26creative%3D165953%26creativeASIN%3DB004YRUDN4

 5) LaCie Rugged USB 3.0

Cost: $299.00

Use: To store and transfer copious amounts of teaching materials data (movies, books, music, etc.)

http://www.lacie.com/products/product.htm?id=10599

 

6) HERO3+ Black Edition GoPro

Cost: $399.99

Use: Document teaching activities, document learning activities, to record audio/video project based tasks (students can make movies, take pictures, etc.) - the projector will allow students and teachers to enjoy what the GoPro captures

http://gopro.com/cameras/hd-hero3-black-edition

7) GoPro Wrist Housing

Cost: $49.99

Use: Cameras are expensive...strapping it to the wrist allows the user to keep track of it at all times

http://gopro.com/camera-mounts/hero3-wrist-housing

8) 3 Micro Innovations - Microphones

Cost: $6.18

Use: Learning activities: e.g., student's can record their voice in addition to  innumerable other applications.  This is useful for teachers as a pedagogical and assessment tool (e.g. record speech sample at beginner of term and then play back at end of term so students can recognize their progress).

http://www.bestbuy.com/site/microphone-black/1306923499.p?id=mp1306923499&skuId=1306923499&st=categoryid$abcat0515041&cp=1&lp=9 

9) Grace Digital ECOXGEAR ECOXBT Rugged and Waterproof Wireless Bluetooth Speaker

Cost: $89.95

Use: Play audio produced by learners and teachers using the GoPro, XO, and microphone; play music that can be used as authentic teaching materials; general entertainment.

http://www.amazon.com/Grace-Digital-ECOXGEAR-Waterproof-Bluetooth/dp/B005D91G38/ref=sr_1_5?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1387097170&sr=1-5&keywords=speakers+waterproof

The Why

According to UNICEF (2014) the GNI per capita is $2,870 US dollars (274,515 Vatus).  With this in mind, school fees in Vanuatu are 27,000 Vatus (the local currency) per child, per year.  Although this might not sound like much, the average family income in Vanuatu is $20,000 VT, and the average family has three children (81,000 Vatus), which means that a family could pay up to four months of their salary ($956.66 US) in school fees alone. 

As well, schools in Vanuatu have limited resources, yet students are hungry for education.  In terms of human progress, societies at large are short-changed when capable and motivated learners miss out on learning opportunities.  In taking a view key resources to Vanuatu, I hope that I can afford learners opportunities that promote/enhance literacy and general education (e.g. DreamPlug with pathagar).  Furthermore, by supporting Alphabet Soup Vanuatu: A campaign to feed the hunger of the literate mind, your contribution will not only enhance general education in Vanuatu, but also help realize my dream of realizing children's' dreams by expanding their educational and literary opportunities, which, ultimately contributes to the creation of a more just, harmonious, sustainable, and literate existence.

How You Can Take Action

The students and communities of rural Vanuatu will benefit from your support!  A few helpful steps you could take might be:

1) Recruit 20 friends to make a modest contribution of $20 each.

2) Spread the word through Facebook, Twitter, Linked In, text, email, etc.

3) Learn more about Vanuatu and global educational/literacy needs.

As they say in Bislama... TANGKYU!

story:
P.S. 261 has a large amount of students who are English Language Learners. Many of these students come to P.S. 261 mid-year. We are trying to raise funds for programs to support these students.

One way that we are trying to raise money is by throwing an awesome benefit concert at Littlefield in Brooklyn featuring D.O.T.S.  C.O.N.F.U.S.E. M.I.N.D.S and The Gowanus Reggae and  Ska Society.

Please help us raise money to rent the venue and to print posters/t-shirts.

M.I.N.D.S and The Gowanus Reggae and  Ska Society.Please help us raise money to rent the venue and to print posters/t-shirts.

story:
Short Summary

For years, I dreamt of becoming a doctor. I was convinced that I would achieve a series of firsts for my family- attending a 4 year University, moving out of North Carolina, and attaining my doctorate- all this, culminating in a move to India where I would care for the less fortunate and sick.

This dream came to a screeching halt when I found that I am less than talented when it comes to the sciences. I realized that I wasn't interested in the money or prestige that being the family doctor offered, I was interested in leading my life doing something that I am truly passionate about. For me, this passion is and always has been a life in Theatre.

I was born into a family with its fair share of obstacles, most notably: severe financial problems. Because of this, there was very little money available to me when I decided to attend Elon University for my Bachelor of Arts. Through days, weeks, and months of hard work, I funded my undergraduate degree, graduating in May of 2012.

As a Stage Manager, I have completed several meaningful and rewarding experiences including an internship with Broadway's Wicked and Cirque du Soleil's KA. For the past year, I have worked as a Stage Manager for Cirque du Soleil's LIGHT Nightclub. This is to say that I have been very fortunate and successful, professionally speaking, for someone my age.

In April of this year, I accepted the opportunity to join Columbia University's MFA Stage Management program as a member of the class of 2016. Unfortunately, I find myself in the same situation that I was in with my undergraduate degree...lacking the funds to make this happen.

Participating in the Master's program at Columbia would give me the ability to study under leading industry professionals such as Michael Passaro, Production Stage Manager for Broadway's Pippin, and Marybeth Abel, Production Stage Manager for Broadway's Wicked. It would give me a leg up with respect to securing jobs after graduation and gaining membership to the Stage Management union, Actor's Equity of America (AEA). Most importantly, a Master's degree would allow me to teach at a University and give me the ability to share my passion with others.

What We Need & What You Get

Here are the cold, hard facts.

I currently have raised $40,500 for the year.

The estimated cost of attendance breaks down like this:

Tuition: $53,484
Fees: $4,759
Living Expenses: $17,874
Books and Supplies: $2,484
Transportation: $1,512
Personal Expenses: $4,032

For a grand total of $84,145 for the year.

Woof.

I have selected a "flexible funding" campaign, meaning that I will get to keep whatever money I raise, even if it's not the full $40,000 I need. I do not, at all, anticipate raising the full $40,000 here and I am still actively searching for scholarships, grants, etc every day. Every little bit helps, though, and that's where you all come in.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand, obviously,  that everyone cannot afford to fund my goal of going to Columbia. If that's you, please share this page! Every extra eye that sees this page is one more person that may be able to help.

Also, please, if you have any information that could help me to secure more funding through scholarships, grants, etc...pass it my way! pdcarter.sm@gmail.com

story:
In October 2013 the only Girls’ dormitory of the Gomoa Senior High and Technical School in Gomoa- West, Central Region  which housed 190 girls was tragically destroyed in a fire. 

It's been 9 months since the incident and the government has yet to address the situation. Consequently, the Gomoa Secondary School is fundraising to rebuild and refurnish the Girls' Dormitory. 

Currently, classrooms are being used as dormitories  and this has meant that the girls scarcely have access to the amenities, privacy and protection that they should otherwise have. So far there have been over 200 cases of Malaria reported at the Apam District Hospital and some of these have been hospitalised.

Our goal is to raise funds and provide them with the resources that they need to complete this project. You'll also find a list of items that the school needs to purchase which you can donate instead of money. 

Otherwise, help the young girls at Gomoa out with whatever you can spare. 



PHOTOS FROM THE INCIDENT

Front view of burnt girls’ dorm


Burnt corridor


Burnt cubicle

OUR GOALS

·  Refurbish the Girls’ dormitory 

·  Provide the girls with suitable living conditions ASAP!


How YOU can help?

·  DONATE money or any of the materials listed below

story_txt:
In October 2013
the only Girls’ dormitory of the Gomoa Senior High and Technical School in Gomoa- West, Central Region  which housed 190 girls was tragically destroyed in a fire. It's been 9 months since the incident and the government has yet to address the situation. Consequently, the Gomoa Secondary School is fundraising to rebuild and refurnish the Girls' Dormitory. Currently, classrooms are being used as dormitories  and this has meant that the girls scarcely have access to the amenities, privacy and protection that they should otherwise have. So far there have been over 200 cases of Malaria reported at the Apam District Hospital and some of these have been hospitalised.Our goal is to raise funds and provide them with the resources that they need to complete this project. You'll also find a list of items that the school needs to purchase which you can donate instead of money. Otherwise, help the young girls at Gomoa out with whatever you can spare. PHOTOS FROM THE INCIDENT
Front view
of burnt girls’ dormBurnt corridorBurnt cubicleOUR GOALS

story:
Intro

In 2010, recent St.Olaf graduate Subhash Ghimere returned to his home in Arupokhari, Nepal, with the intention of building a Peace School. After a decade of civil war, his village had lost leaders, educators, health and police posts, and the existing government schools lacked the support structure to properly help children directly affected by the war (e.g. single/zero parent households, disability-stricken families, etc.) 

Subhash initially founded a summer camp to create such a support structure, but after receiving overwhelmingly positive feedback, took a further step and raised further money (including a $10,000 grant from Davis Projects for Peace) to build both a library and a primary school- more information can be found here.

Unfortunately this was four years ago, and while the initial grant helped found an amazing school with a strong infrastructure and many resources (e.g. a computer lab, projectors, a sports field, etc.) that one would not expect to find on a rural hilltop- the school is having issues sustaining itself, and the money has run out. 

While the school was intended to be entirely self-sufficient, the school board quickly found that many of the students from war-afflicted families literally could not pay a single cent towards their tuition, as they have no income themselves. Instead of turning away the very students that the school was designed to help, the board instead began to offer full scholarships, which are now offered to around two thirds of all students (school size is currently 197 students total). 

What We Need (And What You Get)

Currently the school is over $10,000 in debt to local banks, and around $2,000 in debt to teachers (via unpaid salary). With the $15,000 that we are asking for, we hope to remove the debt entirely, pay all the teachers their owed money (plus some interest), and simultaneously work on re-organizing the school's structure to increase it's financial sustainability (the current plan is to buy a small area of farmland adjacent to the school, with which we can grow and sell cash crops- bananas, sugar cane, etc., and which will also serve as an educational experience for the kids!)
Perks: While we don't have a lot to give back at the current time, our students have offered to create original artwork (examples in the photos section) for our donors. Given that we have 200 students, and are trying to raise $15,000, we're limiting this reward to donors of $50 and above. Feel free to make requests/commissions in terms of the art you receive, but no promises- the kids can be a little erratic. 
All donors of $5 and above will be included on our big wall of donors, which will be hung in our main office for years to come!

    Risks & Challenges

    So, the big risk is- what happens if we raise the money, but the school doesn't fix it's sustainability problem and we're in this boat again next year? This obviously is a possibility, but with our new brood of volunteers working hard to make a difference, we hope to have everything in order (for the next year) within the next months. We'll post updates here as we accomplish this. 

    In any case, the worst case scenario is that we fix the debt for this year, which will go a long way towards improving the plight of the school. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Come visit! We'd love to have you volunteer at the school, and need new teachers all the time. While we can't help with flight and visa costs, we can give free room and board! Shoot me an email at coateswelsh@gmail.com if you're interested. 


      Thanks!

story:
There is an upcoming Birthright trip *leaves MONDAY* that is in need of a leader and I'm trying to raise money to cover the cost of the plane ticket to New York (the program cannot fund domestic flights, even for trip leaders). 

I am incredibly proud that these programs are still running, even when the rest of the world refuses to fly to Israel. Now, more than ever, It is important that Jews who are experiencing Israel for the first time have leaders to help them foster a relationship with the country. I am an experienced Birthright leader and can give these participants the trip that they deserve.

Over the past weeks I have seen you all rally behind Israel and I have been searching for my own way to show support. This is short notice and unideal timing, but it is of the upmost importance. Lets show Israel and the world that we will not be deterred by Hamas. Am Yisrael chai!

“We Jews have a secret weapon in our conflict with the Arabs: We have no place else to go."  - Golda Meir

story:
Amaro Kher = our house

The Project

Amaro Kher is a project of three non-profit-organisations from Germany. It all started with a school project in Kriva Palanka. One of the organisations rent a house to give the people in the poor Romani neighborhood in Macedonia the chance to bring their kids to kindergarden and to help them prepare for school. The goal of the project Amaro Kher is assistance for self-help . The house is supposed to be a community center, where the neighborhood can organize themselves, learn something, build something. In the end the Roma shall administrate it by themselves independently from the german supporters. The architecture is not convential but more a modern one with recycling techniques. We use clay and recycling materials such as plastic bottles and car tires for the construction. People of the neighborhood can also learn these recycling building techniques for repairing their own houses.


We work closely together with a group of the neighborhood (picture), which we call the „AmaroKher- Contact-group“. They are like the representatives for the neighborhood and will administrate the house in the future.


The house could be bought because we had one big donator who paid for it. The first construction episode last summer was financed with money which we collected from concerts, school donations and asking and asking and asking people to give something.We have almost enough money now to build the rest of the house but when the house is done we will need more money.


For what do we need money ?

Most urgently we need money for the furniture and for things in the house. The contact group would like to build a workshop room downstairs where people can fix their things and use tools. We also want to buy some computers for work and education. Also toys for the kids are a big subject: they dont really have toys to play with. Also we would like to hire a teacher for the kids in school to help them with their homework. The kids have a lot of problems in school because at home they speak Romani and do not learn the national language. So they urgently need help to stay in school and get an exam.

We could realize a lot there, but it all costs money. Therefore, I did not do a fix goal with the money. We will do what we can with what we have. And if we had enough money at the end we even could provide some jobs for the people there... but that are really future dreams


Who am I

My name is Hanna, i am a lawyer in training and mediator and became part of the project at the beginning of 2013. My mother is the initiator of the project and so I found my way to this special project. When my mom became cancer last year I took over some dutys for the project and was in Kriva Palanka two times last year. Mostly for the contact group to help them organize themselves and prepare them for their administrative duties in the future.


(my mom )

(me)

The children

Most important for me personally are the perspectives (even if its small) we can give to the children and the young people in Kriva Palanka. They have got a troubled start in life and its just not fair. Some of them are so poor that even a broken arm cant be fixed because they have no health insurance and no money. And in school and public they are treated very racially sometimes (we could not even get in to the open air pool with the kids: „No Romas“ they said). But the kids are willing, they are strong, intelligent and eager to learn things... that we saw at the construction. They want to be part of the project so much that they even fight for a hammer even if the work was only to pull nails out of the wood from the old house.


We and the contact group want to give them the opportunity to learn and build something. For that we want to give them space, things and help for homework. We want to give them the opportunity to do sport things (by buying theme some toys like skateboards and books to borrow for free) and music instruments (there are some talented ones I think).


The german group

The group of the German volunteers is very... individual I would say. We're a big group with about 40 people, Age between 14- 60 years, very different backgrounds, jobs and opinions...Last summer it was a coming and going of Germans all along. But as a network we work together very well. Even if its not easy sometimes. All members in all the german groups, the contact group, the kids and the rest of the neighborhood became one big crazy family.

(part of the crazy family)

(german group and roma-contact-group at planning)


(the big boys are our architects)

The movie

http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x1ikcg3_amaro-kher-in-kriva-palanka-impressionen_news?start=3

… is unfortunately in German. But if you watch it you will get an impression on what we did last year. We filmed the first episode of the construction. Whats explained in German you ll find in this description also.

In the end...

I would say this project is not only a project to build a house it is more about building something together, respect and understanding each other, friendships for life and just a thing that makes all of us feel a little better because it is just something positive :-)

story:
Short Summary

Home of the Phoenix! The school was established as Pitts Middle School in 1960. Our diverse student population is an accurate reflection of the city of Pueblo. Our staff is committed to making a positive difference in the lives of our students. We are dedicated. We are united. We believe in the potential of our students. 

We need your help!

The 6th grade Phoenix at PAA has been working long and hard all year year to fulfill the legacy of our mascot and RISE from the ashes. Each student is striving daily to be the change and reach their goals. We believe they deserve a reward for their hard work and excellence.
Our goal is to raise money for our Denver trip to Eliches Mad Scientist days. Our students will have the chance to uncover the secrets of science as mad scientists performing numerous interactive science experiments throughout the park. Hands-on tables will tie in the science behind Amusement park rides and activities. Demonstrations will help the students understand the science behind amusement parks while still having fun. 

School Vision 

At the Pueblo Academy for Arts, we believe all students can achieve excellence.

Our vision will be accomplished by cultivating a safe student-centered learning environment that fosters academic achievement, creativity, character development, a passion for learning, and a sense of belonging through teamwork, high expectations, meaningful and challenging academic instruction, continuous improvement, and a commitment to our school values.

What We Need & What You Get

We need money for three things:

1. TICKETS: We need to be able to purchase the tickets. The tickets are $25 per student who is eligible to go. At this point there are 52 6th graders ready to go.

2. FOOD: The park is offering us lunch tickets at $11 a person. Coming from a school with over 90% free and reduced lunch qualifying families, packing a sack lunch is not always an option.

3. BUS: Of course, even if we have enough money for tickets and food, if we can't afford a bus we'll have no way of getting their. The bus itself will cost anywhere from $300-$400 depending on the time it takes considering traffic, and current gas prices on the day of the trip.


The Impact

The students are very well deserving and could use your help. PAA has over 90% of families qualifying for free and reduced lunch which means they are living in poverty or near to. The opportunity to go to an amusement park is rarely if ever available.

Many of my students had never even heard of this park and have never been to another like it. 

Our students have made a pledge to help get us there. Each student going MUST have a 3.0 or higher GPA (which at this point is nearly 80% of the 6th grade and the rest are well on their way to improving). They may not have ANY office referrals or disciplinary problems. All students must help fund raise, which they've been working hard at all semester with a current total of $440. AND each student must be actively working on earning their wings as a PHOENIX. Wings are earned by doing things to prove they are a Phoenix RISEing from the ashes. (Being Respecful & Responsible, showing true Integrity, Speaking, acting, and dressing like a phoenix at all times, and giving 100% Effort in all they do)

story:
The Project

Samuel R. Delany is one of the most brilliant, stimulating, and uncompromising writers on the contemporary American literary scene.  As a gay African-American author who has produced exuberantly innovative work in a variety of genres -- science fiction preeminent among them -- Delany has won the admiration of legions of readers.  Over the course of his half-century career, Delany's writing has garnered numerous awards and honors, including four Nebula Awards and two Hugo Awards, a Lambda Literary Award, the Bill Whitehead Memorial Award for a Lifetime Contribution to Lesbian and Gay Literature, and inclusion in the prestigious Norton Anthology of African American Literature.  

Currently I am compiling and editing Delany’s personal journals.  The journals will be published by Wesleyan University Press in what is projected to be a series of at least five volumes, with each volume covering approximately one decade’s worth of material.  I have recently completed the first volume, In Search of Silence; this volume is now in the final stages of production at Wesleyan and is slated to appear at the end of this year. It covers the period from Delany’s teenage years in the late 1950s to the end of the 1960s, during which time Delany established himself as a major figure in what came to be called New Wave science fiction.  The second volume, Autumnal City, will present Delany’s journals from the 1970s, during which time he wrote the bulk of what many consider the pivotal work of his career, Dhalgren (1975), as well as Trouble on Triton (1976), the first volume of the Nevèrÿon tetralogy (Tales of Nevèrÿon [1979]), and many works of criticism.

In this campaign I am seeking funding to produce the second volume.  If I secure this funding, the project – which involves researching, compiling, transcribing, editing, and annotating the text – will take two years to complete.  The total amount I am seeking, for two years of full-time work on the project, is $60,000.  This will cover three areas: personal expenses, expenses associated with the project (travel, office expenses, and so on), and expenses associated with this campaign (fees and percentages, cost and shipping of rewards, and so on).

Funds raised in this campaign will not go to Wesleyan University Press, but rather directly to me, in support of my scholarly labor.  In academic publishing, the primary income of the author comes not from the publisher through book advances or sales, but rather from a university paycheck (and usually the author and publisher are affiliated with different universities).  If the author is an independent scholar, as I am, then that primary income is understood to come from some other external source.  For this project, you will be that source.


Why You Should Sponsor This Project

It's important.

The release of Delany’s personal journals will add thousands of pages to Delany’s published work and reveal a major new dimension of his writing.  The journals will be of great interest to Delany’s readers in particular, and to all readers concerned with the personal development of a writer and thinker whose work has focused on issues of sexuality, race, and social marginality.  By supporting this project you will contribute directly to the important project of getting Delany’s journals out into the world.

I'm qualified.

I graduated summa cum laude from Cornell University and received my MFA in Film and Media Arts from Temple University and my Ph.D. in English from SUNY Buffalo.  I have published five scholarly essays on Delany’s work, including introductions to two of his books: Longer Views (1995) – also from Wesleyan – and 1984: Selected Letters (1999).  In 2005 I organized the first international conference devoted to Delany’s work, several papers from which were later published in a special “Delany” issue of the academic quarterly Annals of Scholarship, for which I served as Guest Editor.  I also contributed an essay to Wesleyan’s recent critical edition of Delany’s novel Phallos (2013).   In short, having made a life project of studying and explicating Delany’s writing, I am uniquely qualified to carry out this project.  

It's a sure thing.

As I said above, I’ve already completed the first volume. It’s done! (And I should mention that the folks at Wesleyan, and Delany himself, are very satisfied with my work, and support this campaign wholeheartedly.) The completion of the first volume means that there are no major unknowns involved in the process of completing the second: all key questions about archival sources, editorial methods, and the organization and presentation of material have now been answered.  (Indeed, one reason I didn't run a crowdfunding campaign for the first volume was that I wanted to be sure, in running such a campaign, that I was making a promise I knew I could keep.  And now I am sure.)  Thus, donating to Autumnal City requires no special leap of faith on your part: if you fund it, it will get done.

Time is of the essence.

My ability to work full-time on Autumnal City will directly enhance the quality of the volume, and for a specific reason.  While compiling the first volume I was fortunate to have Delany himself on hand to answer my countless questions on matters not covered by his own autobiographical work or other secondary sources.  This enriched the volume hugely, and needless to say, I want to preserve this working relationship for future volumes. But – to be blunt – Delany is not getting any younger. Producing these volumes as quickly as is practicable will help ensure Delany’s continued participation.  Thus, by supporting full-time work on the second volume, you will help improve the volume – and, with luck, improve the quality of volumes to come.


Perks

To add momentum (and some extra enjoyment) to the campaign, I have added rewards for different levels of donation.  Each successive level includes the rewards given for the previous levels.  All rewards are, of course, optional; donors can forgo them if they wish.  (Also, note that two new rewards have been added to the line-up since the campaign began.)

"Singer"

Donors at this level ($10) will receive updates on the project every six months.  These periods will cover the four major phases of the project: compilation, transcription, editing, and annotation.  I may supplement the updates with news of other interesting developments related to the project, if and when they occur.  If 6,000 of Delany's readers donate at this level, the campaign goal will be reached.

"Scorpion"

Donors at this level ($60) will receive what is, in my view, the most purely fun reward of the lot: a Samuel Delany T-shirt.  The photographer Becket Logan has given me permission to use his striking photo portrait of Delany, with graphic enhancement, as the basis for the shirt.  Readers of Dhalgren may think of the shirt as a set of Scorpion chains: by this garment Delany fans everywhere will be able to recognize one another.


I have pegged the minimum donation for this reward at $60, because if I receive 1,000 such donations, the campaign goal will be met.  So the implicit question this reward poses is: are there 1,000 Delany readers out there willing to donate $60 to this project?  I suspect there are.  Perhaps you are one of them.

"Liberator"

Donors at this level ($100 and above) will be listed (if they so desire) on a special Acknowledgments page in Autumnal City.

"Liberator Plus" 

First of two new perks here!  Donors at this level ($100 and above) will receive all the preceding rewards (notifications, shirt, acknowledgments), plus a hardcover copy of either In Search of Silence (Volume One) or Autumnal City (Volume Two).  Your choice.  Bear in mind that In Search of Silence is projected to hit the bookstores at the end of this year, while Autumnal City will take a few more years to appear physically.  (Note also that because this new perk is pegged at the same donation value as the earlier one, donors who have already given a "Liberator"-level donation will, unless they specify otherwise, receive the rewards of the "Liberator-Plus" level.  Yes, you get a book!)

"Sygn"

Second of two new perks!  Donors at this level ($200) will receive the preceding rewards, plus hardcover copies of both In Search of Silence and Autumnal City. Again, bear in mind that the two volumes will be released at different times.

"Golden"

Donors at this level ($500 and above) will receive a hardcover copy of In Search of Silence, signed by Delany.  At present I am offering only 20 copies, but will add more if this reward receives a strong response.  

If the Funding Goal is Exceeded

If the total donations exceed the campaign goal of $60,000, then the extra funds will go directly toward work on the third volume.  Potential donors may take this as an incentive to be generous, since, unless budgeting needs change, any funding the third volume receives now should help reduce the funding needs for that volume later.  And if I may indulge in a little speculative fiction: if, during the current campaign, a full $60,000 becomes available for the third volume, then any funds raised beyond that will be put toward the fourth volume... and so on.  (Note also: if the funding goal is reached before the campaign ends, anyone making a "Liberator"-level donation after that point will be listed on the Acknowledgments page for the third volume rather than the second -- so those who would like to be listed in the second volume should donate early.)


Previews

To whet your appetite for Autumnal City, I have secured permission from Wesleyan to present some material associated with the first volume, In Search of Silence. Here’s the cover:

As you can see, it’s a handsome volume, and the series as a whole is going to make an impressive set.  The cover image, incidentally, shows a portion of a sculpture by Dame Barbara Hepworth called “Orpheus (Maquette 2) (Version II).”  Delany’s readers will recognize this as an appropriate image for the period of his career covered in the first volume.

Next, some endorsements for In Search of Silence:

“Mesmerizing . . . a true portrait of an artist as a young Black man . . . already visible in these pages are the wit, sensitivity, penetration, playfulness and the incandescent intelligence that will characterize Delany and his extraordinary work.”

—Junot Díaz, author of The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao

“This is a tremendously significant and vital addition to the oeuvre of Samuel Delany; it clarifies questions not only of the writer’s process, but also his development—to see, in his juvenilia, traces that take full form in his novels—is literally breathtaking.”

—Matthew Cheney, author of Blood: Stories

“These journals give us the very rare experience of being able to watch genius escaping from the chrysalis.”

—Jo Walton, author of Among Others

Finally, here are a few paragraphs from the early pages of the volume, part of a longer entry Delany wrote when he was a seventeen-year-old high school student in New York City.  Enjoy.

…It was hot with people, and in the bus you have to strain to reach over [the] old lady's shoulders so that you can grab the strap, and when you finally get back where there are not enough people to be uncomfortably crowded and too many to feel free (and my coat was for the brittle winter air outside, not the effluvia of body heat that bloats up a crowded bus) you can reach a fair sort of balance between agony and simple displeasure.  The back seat of the bus runs from one side to the other.  The rest are placed either in rows along the side or (in those places just over the wheels) with the seat backs to the wall so that the people in them must stare straight across the aisle into the dull faces of those people perched above the other wheel who are staring back.

There was a boy in the back seat, with a blue zipper jacket on – he was near fourteen.  He had good hands; I remember that's what first made me look at him.  Then suddenly he turned away behind the shoulder of a bigger boy who was sitting next to him and spit up a handful of brownish fluid into his palm.  He must have been trying to hold it in, but he couldn't, and he vomited again, this time all over the shoulder of the boy next to him.  He got out his handkerchief and tried to wipe his hand, and wipe off the boy's shoulder.  The boy turned around and saw what was happening, and gave the kid another handkerchief.  Then he tapped the knee of a young guy who was sitting on the other side of the kid.  The guy was probably asleep, and the boy had to hit him hard, but when he woke up, he looked and then moved to a seat in front of the back seat, and he tried to tell the poor kid to relax.  The kid sat there with his hands filthy and all wrapped up in the dirty handkerchiefs.

He was embarrassed as hell, and when he had to spit up again, he looked around and tried to do it in the seat behind the first boy, only it ran all down his blue zippered jacket.  The first boy had moved forward in his seat and now he rested his arms on the back of the chair [before] him and put his head down on his arms.  The guy who had moved was now patting the kid on the knee and telling him to relax and there were tears streaked across the kid’s face, not from crying but from the effort of trying to keep it back.  The kid just sat there with his jacket streaked and his hands and pants messy.  I could smell it now.

One middle-aged man in a brown coat, clutching a New York Times to his breast, got up and changed seats so he wouldn't have to look at it.

I wanted to say to him, “You stupid ass, why don't you give the kid your paper and let him clean himself off instead of running away from it.”  There were at least two other people with newspapers who just looked in the other direction.  I would have even given the man the nickel for the paper if he had given it to the kid.  There was a young woman in a black coat who was sitting next to where I was standing and she had on a black knitted hood.  I could tell that she wanted to help as much as I did; because it wasn't disgusting; it just made you feel bad that nobody would help, or that the kid was too embarrassed just to spread his legs, lean forward and puke on the floor.  I would have said something to that guy who changed his seat if I had stayed on the bus another thirty seconds.  But it was my stop.

I felt so much for the kid because once, when I was a lot younger, I had been going to school on the bus in the rush hour, standing up, and all of a sudden I got a bloody nose.  It was a bad one and it didn't stop and I didn't even have a handkerchief and I had to hold my coat sleeve against my nose, but it kept leaking.  All the people did was move away from me.  Not one tissue was forthcoming, not one handkerchief, not even a newspaper.  I remember when I finally got off the bus, a huge clot of red mucus exploded from my nostril and the blood stopped, but my face was a mess.

Again: when he wrote the above paragraphs, Delany was seventeen years old.  

Over the course of the remainder of In Search of Silence, we witness scenes from Delany’s marriage to the poet Marilyn Hacker, travels in Europe, various encounters and correspondences with SF writers on both sides of the Atlantic, performances with musicians involved in the New York City folk scene (in addition to his writing, Delany was an active singer-songwriter during the American folk revival of the ’50s and ’60s) – and much, much more.  The first volume also presents outlines and working notes for the science fiction novels and short stories that would win him accolades in the mid- to late-’60s, samples and excerpts of poetry, erotic writing, essay drafts, and theater scripts, as well as – in what is perhaps one of the most intriguing aspects of this volume – numerous working notes for a vast corpus of non-genre fiction which Delany produced during this period but which have not seen publication.

With your support, I will be able to bring you the next volume in the series – which commences with Delany hard at work on the novel that will become Dhalgren.

I think you will agree: Autumnal City is a project well worth supporting.  

And needless to say: every little bit helps.

Thanks.

The Project

Samuel R. Delany is one of the most brilliant, stimulating, and uncompromising writers on the contemporary American literary scene.  As a gay African-American author who has produced exuberantly innovative work in a variety of genres -- science fiction preeminent among them -- Delany has won the admiration of legions of readers.  Over the course of his half-century career, Delany's writing has garnered numerous awards and honors, including four Nebula Awards and two Hugo Awards, a Lambda Literary Award, the Bill Whitehead Memorial Award for a Lifetime Contribution to Lesbian and Gay Literature, and inclusion in the prestigious Norton Anthology of African American Literature.  

Currently I am compiling and editing Delany’s personal journals.  The journals will be published by Wesleyan University Press in what is projected to be a series of at least five volumes, with each volume covering approximately one decade’s worth of material.  I have recently completed the first volume, In Search of Silence; this volume is now in the final stages of production at Wesleyan and is slated to appear at the end of this year. It covers the period from Delany’s teenage years in the late 1950s to the end of the 1960s, during which time Delany established himself as a major figure in what came to be called New Wave science fiction.  The second volume, Autumnal City, will present Delany’s journals from the 1970s, during which time he wrote the bulk of what many consider the pivotal work of his career, Dhalgren (1975), as well as Trouble on Triton (1976), the first volume of the Nevèrÿon tetralogy (Tales of Nevèrÿon [1979]), and many works of criticism.

In this campaign I am seeking funding to produce the second volume.  If I secure this funding, the project – which involves researching, compiling, transcribing, editing, and annotating the text – will take two years to complete.  The total amount I am seeking, for two years of full-time work on the project, is $60,000.  This will cover three areas: personal expenses, expenses associated with the project (travel, office expenses, and so on), and expenses associated with this campaign (fees and percentages, cost and shipping of rewards, and so on).

Funds raised in this campaign will not go to Wesleyan University Press, but rather directly to me, in support of my scholarly labor.  In academic publishing, the primary income of the author comes not from the publisher through book advances or sales, but rather from a university paycheck (and usually the author and publisher are affiliated with different universities).  If the author is an independent scholar, as I am, then that primary income is understood to come from some other external source.  For this project, you will be that source.

story:
To donate - please follow this link to the 3rd campaign! 

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/reverse-reve...

Part II

I have launched part two of my fundraiser for Pavarotti Education Center. I was able to reach my first goal of $500 dollars and gained so much support from many networks I did not think was possible. I now have another goal to match that $500 in another 60 days. Help me make this possible! I want to do everything that I can to provide money for books for the students that impacted my life more than words can describe. Here is the link to the first campaign to see how we did - https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/pavarotti-re...

I was interviewed by my school newspaper about my fundraiser and trip to Guatemala. It printed last week and I couldn't be more excited! You can read it at the following link - http://www.ucdadvocate.com/trip-guatemala-inspires-fundraiser/

Guate - Guate - Guatemala! 

In May, I got an amazing opportunity to study abroad during Maymester with CU Denver in San Lucas Toliman, Guatemala. We stayed at Pavarotti Education Center and got to work with the students. During our first day there we were taken on a tour of the school and got to walk through the classrooms and library. Being a future teacher the tour made me very emotional, and those aspects stuck out the most to me. The students are in need of books. They have a library that has a small supply. They are teaching the students English with Shakespeare poetry because they have no other option.  Before I left to come home I knew that I wanted to do something about what I saw. I believe that every child deserves an education no matter what their background is.

While we were at the school we took place in a cultural exchange with the students and taught them the Cha Cha Slide while they taught us a dance of their own. It was such an incredible time teaching each other our dances and then dancing together in front of the school. We were able to communicate great even with the language barrier. Some of the words in the Cha Cha Slide tell you to reverse, and then reverse again. That is why my fundraiser has the name that it does.

Lack of books - Why should you help?

Guatemala is one of the poorest countries in Latin America. 75% of the population lives below poverty line, and 58% lives below the extreme poverty line. 60% are illiterate in indigenous population and 75% are illiterate in rural areas. Families make on average $4 a day. Indigenous Mayans make up half population and account for less than a quarter of the income/ consumption. 

Two-thirds of the children are in poverty. The average schooling is 4 years and THREE out of 10 graduate 6th grade. “In 2007, only 63% of boys and 64% of girls enrolled in Primary school reached the final grade of Primary education,” (UNESCO Institute for Statistics). 9 out of 10 schools lack books and 1 out of 10 rural Guatemalan children even get opportunity to attend school. 

Schools are poorly funded, don’t have adequate teaching materials, lack adequate books, teaching guides, literacy materials and teachers are not trained properly. Many children cannot stay in school; they have to drop out to support their families, they cannot afford uniforms, books, supplies, and transportation. School is free but the fees are too high. 

The “Civil War” has a lot to do with education lacking – Mayans are still excluded from benefits of the country and still remain targets of racism and exclusion from land, labor, and education. When your country is being attacked, reading seems less important.

“Humankind will not recover from its mistake without global education.” 
              - Rigoberta Menchú Tum

Impact

The students at Pavarotti are some of the most talented kids I've ever gotten the experience to work with. I will be raising money to send back to Guatemala for the director of the school to purchase more books to fill the library walls. Anything and everything will be appreciated and will help those students. If you are not able to contribute then please help me spread the word and get my fundraiser out there.

San Lucas Toliman does something to you when you visit. The people, the students, the environment; it changes you. I came home with a piece of Guatemala in my heart, very close to me. I think about those students and my experiences everyday. I have never been so passionate about something before and I have the students to thank for that. I got very lucky to be able to travel down to Guatemala. Those students made such an impact on me and I want to be able to help them as much as I can.
story_txt:
To donate - please follow this link to the 3rd campaign! 
https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/reverse-reve...
Part II
I have launched part two of my fundraiser for Pavarotti Education Center. I was able to reach my first goal of $500 dollars and gained so much support from many networks I did not think was possible. I now have another goal to match that $500 in another 60 days. Help me make this possible! I want to do everything that I can to provide money for books for the students that impacted my life more than words can describe. Here is the link to the first campaign to see how we did - https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/pavarotti-re...


I was interviewed by my school newspaper about my fundraiser and trip to Guatemala. It printed last week and I couldn't be more excited! You can read it at the following link - http://www.ucdadvocate.com/trip-guatemala-inspires-fundraiser/

Guate - Guate - Guatemala! 
In May, I got an amazing opportunity to study abroad during Maymester with CU Denver in San Lucas Toliman, Guatemala. We stayed at Pavarotti Education Center and got to work with the students. During our first day there we were taken on a tour of the school and got to walk through the classrooms and library. Being a future teacher the tour made me very emotional, and those aspects stuck out the most to me. The students are in need of books. They have a library that has a small supply. They are teaching the students English with Shakespeare poetry because they have no other option.  Before I left to come home I knew that I wanted to do something about what I saw. I believe that every child deserves an education no matter what their background is.
While we were at the school we took place in a cultural exchange with the students and taught them the Cha Cha Slide while they taught us a dance of their own. It was such an incredible time teaching each other our dances and then dancing together in front of the school. We were able to communicate great even with the language barrier. Some of the words in the Cha Cha Slide tell you to reverse, and then reverse again. That is why my fundraiser has the name that it does.
Lack of books - Why should you help?
Guatemala is one of the poorest countries in Latin America. 75% of the population lives below poverty line, and 58% lives below the extreme poverty line. 60% are illiterate in indigenous population and 75% are illiterate in rural areas. Families make on average $4 a day. Indigenous Mayans make up half population and account for less than a quarter of the income/ consumption. 
Two-thirds of the children are in poverty. The average schooling is 4 years and THREE out of 10 graduate 6th grade. “In 2007, only 63% of boys and 64% of girls enrolled in Primary school reached the final grade of Primary education,” (UNESCO Institute for Statistics). 9 out of 10 schools lack books and 1 out of 10 rural Guatemalan children even get opportunity to attend school. 
Schools are poorly funded, don’t have adequate teaching materials, lack adequate books, teaching guides, literacy materials and teachers are not trained properly. Many children cannot stay in school; they have to drop out to support their families, they cannot afford uniforms, books, supplies, and transportation. School is free but the fees are too high. 
The “Civil War” has a lot to do with education lacking – Mayans are still excluded from benefits of the country and still remain targets of racism and exclusion from land, labor, and education. When your country is being attacked, reading seems less important.
“Humankind will not recover from its mistake without global education.”               - Rigoberta Menchú Tum

Impact

The students at Pavarotti are some of the most talented kids I've ever gotten the experience to work with. I will be raising money to send back to Guatemala for the director of the school to purchase more books to fill the library walls. Anything and everything will be appreciated and will help those students. If you are not able to contribute then please help me spread the word and get my fundraiser out there.
San Lucas Toliman does something to you when you visit. The people, the students, the environment; it changes you. I came home with a piece of Guatemala in my heart, very close to me. I think about those students and my experiences everyday. I have never been so passionate about something before and I have the students to thank for that. I got very lucky to be able to travel down to Guatemala. Those students made such an impact on me and I want to be able to help them as much as I can.

story:
A year on from his accident, we're raising money to celebrate Max's recovery, for a very special present.

Back in November 2013 Max was the victim of a severe road cycling accident. Thanks to a combination of NHS lifesavers, physical strength and rehabilitation, Max has been able to recover from his injuries over the past year and is now fully embracing being back amongst his friends, family and loved ones. 

Of course, the ultimate test for Max is being able to get back onto a snowboard and get shredding this Christmas. To celebrate a year on from the accident we want to give him the snowboard of his dreams, the K2 Ultra Split.

What's this snowboard?

It's a split-board, a snowboard that turns into a pair of skis, allowing riders to explore the back country, hike up mountains and give them the means to find the freshest powder. To discover more about the snowboard, watch this video or read about it on K2.


How much should I donate?

Our goal is to raise £500 (in 31 days) - so it's up to you how much you'd like to donate. Every penny counts!

How to donate?

Click on the 'Contribute Now' button on the page and you're one step closer to donating!

story:
Our First National Tour!

We are so excited to announce the launch of our first national Rock For Human Rights Tour - September 2014!

R4HR Founder Wil Seabrook is teaming up with African superstar Alexio Kawara to play live music concerts for college students and local communities all over the eastern US this fall. 

The shows will feature live music sets from Wil and Alexio as well as a brief discussion of the 30 human rights found in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. 

Audience members will walk away with a free booklet entitled "Know Your RIghts" which explains each of the 30 Human Rights found in the Universal Declaration in plain English. 

The first step in making human rights a reality is educating people on what those rights actually are. This tour will inspire, uplift and educate each audience with a mix of American and African music.


What We Need & What You Get

In order to make this tour happen we have to: 

Pay for Alexio's travel visa approval from Zimbabwe to the US as well as his flight and travel expenses.

Pay to bring three super talented musicians from Los Angeles to the east coast of the US and back again, along with their gear. 

Pay to rent a van (and put lots of gas in it) and wrap it with our awesome logo so that thousands of people will hear about the tour as we travel thousands of miles all over the eastern US. 

Pay for sound equipment so people can actually hear the music.

Make sure everyone has food and a safe place to sleep every night. 

The total price tag for the tour is $40,000. 

Rock For Human Rights is a registered 501c3 non-profit, so your donation is 100% tax deductible!


    The Impact

    Have you ever wondered why it is that some countries observe the rule of law and protect the rights of their citizens and some just don't? 

    In order to make human rights a fact rather than just an idealistic dream, the very first step is making people aware of what their human rights are. 

    The tour is designed to share this information with people in a way that's emotionally engaging and uplifting rather than preachy or depressing. And we get to introduce Alexio Kawara, ZImbabwe's #1 music artist, to an American audience in the process!


      Risks & Challenges

      Over three years of hard work have gone into making this first tour possible. We have corporate sponsors who are interested in helping us make the tour a huge national event in 2015. But before that can happen, we need to show them that the tour isn't just a great idea, but that it's something that people love and respond to. Your donation is the thing that will make that possible!


        Other Ways You Can Help

        Please take a few minutes and email friends and family the link to this page:

        https://www.indiegogo.com/campaigns/rock-for-human-rights-national-tour-2014

        Tell them it's worth three minutes of their time to check out our video. Doing that exact thing is the only way we'll get this tour funded and we can't thank you enough for your support. 

        THANK YOU FOR HELPING US MAKE THIS DREAM A REALITY! WE'LL SEE YOU ON THE ROAD! :)

story:
"Education is the most powerful weapon we have to change the world." Nelson Mandela

The primary school of "Alexandru Donici" is a breath of fresh air in the midst of tough times. The school is located in Cahul, a southern city in the Republic of Moldova. This tiny landlocked country between Romania and Ukraine is riddled with strife. From tough economic times, a dismal job market, a floundering education system, high human trafficking rates and prevalent poverty... it is an equation for failure. 
Yet there are schools and individuals who press on in hopes of changing the future of this country, beginning with the enrichment of education for children. Alexandru Donici is one of these schools filled with many of those individuals. With over 300 students, they are one of the only fully inclusive education schools in the country, integrating over 20 children with severe disabilities. Their "Step by Step" education focuses on the success of the individual student and their progressive teaching styles and zero-tolerance on violence policy has parents lining up to enroll their children. 
Currently, the school has a kindergarten for 25 children, however; a waiting list has caused the school to look for solutions. Our goal is to renovate a new additional space and furnish it for an expansion that would double the kindergarten class to 50 students. 
No matter where you live in the world or what your circumstances are: every children should benefit from a solid and safe education beginning from the moment they first enter a school. Help us change the lives of youth for generations to come. 

Here is What We Need & This is What You Get

  • 8 tables (Total: 11600 lei | 657 USD)
  • 25 chairs (Total: 10000 lei | 566 USD)
  • 8 pull out beds (these fold out to accommodate 3 children each) (Total: 22400 lei | 1269 USD)
  • 3 new windows (Total: 13500 lei | 764 USD)
  • Linoleum flooring (Total: 5000 | 283 USD)
  • Paint and Materials (Total: 1000 lei | 56 USD)
  • TOTAL: 63500 lei | 3598 USD (Depending on Exchange Rate Variation
  • Wire transfer ($25 USD) + Indiegogo fee (4%) 
  • Total Asking: $3750 USD
What can you get!?
  • $50 donation will get you a "Thank You" postcard from Moldova signed by some superstar Moldovan students!
  • $100 donation will get you your name painted into our kindergarten mural upon project completio + "Thank You" postcard from Moldova
  • $500 donation will get you you very own bottle of Moldovan wine shipped to your front door! + your name painted into the kindergarten mural + "Thank You" postcard from Moldova!

The Impact

This project is bringing together the director of the Primary School "Alexandru Donici", the teachers, the parents association and volunteers serving in the community. The school budget and parents association together will be fronting the renovation and installation costs as part of a community contribution and in-kind contribution to the project. 

After the furnishings and materials are bought and delivered upon campaign completion (end of March) we will spend April, May and June finishing the room and come August, the kindergarten will expand from 25 students to 50 students in the school year 2015-2016!

This project will double class size for generations to come. Impacting the lives of 25 students annually. You never know what those students will go on to do with the rest of their lives!

Our team has completed projects and grants such as renovating a kitchen, carrying out healthy lifestyle seminars, running tolerance and anti-violence campaigns, building a Regional Resource Center for Persons with Disabilities, creating after school clubs on social topics, and starting a computer lab through "Connect Cahul". We are motivated individuals changing the lives of youth in the community on Cahul. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that perhaps you cannot donate money at this time but you can help us in other ways!

  • Please share our fundraising campaign via Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and other social media. 
  • Or email your friends, family and colleagues about our cause!

We thank you in advance for all your help and support in making this project a reality!

story:
Our School's Philosophy

Our new State Charter School doesn't just teach language, we teach culture.  We offer a Dual-Language Immersion Education in French, German, Mandarin and Spanish in combination with English.  We are rich in culture.  At the International Charter School of Atlanta, we don't just teach language we also teach the culture.  We are teaching tomorrow's leaders to understand their global counterparts and to be accepting of all cultures, so they can strive in our global economy. 

What We Need

1. Funding to help defray the cost of our facility configuration and build out.  From  the architectural designs to the actual materials used in construction.  Fortunately, we are assuming a site that previously housed a school, so we are able to keep these costs to a minimum.

2. Technology is an essential component to operating a school and to teaching today's children.  We need funding to build our school's network infrastructure, incorporate and purchase our software systems, and to purchase computers and hand held devices for our students to use in class.

Our Impact on the Community

The International Charter School of Atlanta is the first of it's kind in the entire state of Georgia.  Our curriculum is taught in four target languages:

  • French
  • German
  • Mandarin
  • Spanish

Each language track is taught in combination with English and is weighted according to ability and grade.  We are so excited to offer this option to our community.  We will serve grades K through 4 in our inaugural school year of 2015 -2016.

story:
My name is Irvine Muzuva.I come from Zimbabwe Kufunda Village and i have been in Sweden  for six months now. I am participating in leadership program in the name YIP(International Youth Initiative Program). I am in this program to explore who am i and rooting into the understanding of myself the gift i can receive and offer to the world. This is a one year program and it is ending in June. By then i will have to go back to my country in Zimbabwe. I have chosen to take some of time being here in Sweden to strengthen my leadership and also outside YIP. By doing so I have applied to participate in a one week intensive leadership gathering called ALIA taking place in Netherlands from the 23 - 29 March 2014

What is ALIA

ALIA is a convener of pioneering leaders and networks who are implementing positive change. It is also a place of applied learning and skill-building in the art and practice of authentic leadership, systems change, and social innovation.

from the website of ALIA institute

Why participating in ALIA

I am interested to participate in the Leadership Intensive because  I want to be part of the Learning community. Meeting young  leaders form all over the world while bringing our energy, stories and questions into sharing.  Inspiring and learning from each other. I am holding a questions of curiosity to others young people and our elders who have wisdom.  What time is it we are at now? What am I supposed to be doing NOW in terms of following  my intutive voice, practicing and living the change with my society not just dreaming it ?

Yes I have been exposed and i have experiance  with the tools of art of hosting and flow game so far, not just that but also a lot in discovering my gifts and how i can offer myself and my gifts to the world with my best heart. I feel it is not enough. I still need to learn and to be streangthened, finding new ways and tools in which i can offer my gifts to the world. I have been listened to my story so many times and this a gift i can offer to others. deep listening and exchanging  the sharing.  being part of the network of people who have chosen to be awake and ready to walk in the manifestation of the world they want to live in.

The support I need from you...

  • I have been offered a partial scholarship to participate in the gathering. So because I do have to contribute a little bit and cover the costs towardsfood and accommodation. 
  • The whole budget all together for this is € 900  in $ 1350 and the other 100 will go to the indiegogo fee, the bank percentage and transaction fee.

The Impact

By your gifting, you are supporting me to anchor and strengthen my leadership skills. You are giving me space to be inspired and allowing to take the inspiration back with me to Africa.

Other Ways You Can support me...

Any support is welcome. Only little is enough and it always contribute to the bigger purpose. Please you can also share this with friends and the universe around you.

story:
Background

Hello World! I am a creative, intelligent, hard-working casualty of the new economy, who got a Bachelor's Degree in 2004 from San Francisco State and went to work as an office jockey for a non-profit. After a couple failed entry-level jobs, I went solo. I've managed to scrape by that way, but I know things could be much better for me, so I went searching outside of my city. While finding steady work in the USA has been all but impossible, I've already secured a job teaching English in Taiwan to begin in July. Finally, a chance to earn what I am told is the "average" salary of an American with a BA... and I'll be making it in a different country!

What I Need & What You Get

I need funds to get set up over in Taiwan. There was a time when I could have easily funded this move by myself, but things just haven't been the same since 2009 (I'm sure you feel me on this).

What you get is the satisfaction of knowing that you helped an otherwise capable man to have a second chance in a foreign country where there is no shortage of jobs for English-speaking people with college degrees. My job, pay and hours are already secured- I just have to get over there.

You'll also get the perks here in the sidebar, which I think are pretty awesome deals, personally.

The Impact

This project is a useful expenditure of your money in a few ways-

1. It keeps someone off the street and from being a tax burden in America (you're probably paying for my survival right now and you aren't even getting any vacuum-sealed stinky tofu for it!).

2. It allows for you follow the progress of an American making a new start in a foreign country- a country that wishes to follow in the footsteps of America while hoping to avoid some of our mistakes.

3. As I have experience in the renewable energy field, and Taiwan is in great need of some assistance in that area, I plan to volunteer a number of hours each month helping my city to build out a plan for sustainability. And cleaner air is worth a few bucks to me.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share the word, hook me up with cheap housing in Taiwan, let me use some of your Frequent Flier Miles, or write me directly and work out a loan agreement with me if you don't wish to trust me with a grant.

There was a time when I could have easily funded this move by myself, but things just haven't been the same since 2009 (I'm sure you feel me on this).What you get is the satisfaction of knowing that you helped an otherwise capable man to have a second chance in a foreign country where there is no shortage of jobs for English-speaking people with college degrees. My job, pay and hours are already secured- I just have to get over there.You'll also get the perks here in the sidebar, which I think are pretty awesome deals, personally.The ImpactThis project is a useful expenditure of your money in a few ways-1. It keeps someone off the street and from being a tax burden in America (you're probably paying for my survival right now and you aren't even getting any vacuum-sealed stinky tofu for it!).2. It allows for you follow the progress of an American making a new start in a foreign country- a country that wishes to follow in the footsteps of America while hoping to avoid some of our mistakes.3. As I have experience in the renewable energy field, and Taiwan is in great need of some assistance in that area, I plan to volunteer a number of hours each month helping my city to build out a plan for sustainability. And cleaner air is worth a few bucks to me.Other Ways You Can HelpShare the word, hook me up with cheap housing in Taiwan, let me use some of your Frequent Flier Miles, or write me directly and work out a loan agreement with me if you don't wish to trust me with a grant.

story:
Coach Keese Memorial Scholarship 2014

Last year, we were able to give a $1,000 scholarship to a very deserving Refugio High School senior, Logan Meyers. This year, we are fundraising again! We are hopefully able to raise enough to give out 2 scholarships!

In 2013, we raised $1,700, therefore, $700 plus anything we raise this year will help one or more RHS students achieve their dreams.

Each donor is recognized with the award letter notification, and words cannot describe how much it means to the recipient.  

Indiegogo was our venue selected for this year because it allows the easiest way to provide donations 24/7.  


Thank you all for your contributions!

Sincerely,

Coach Keese Scholarship Fund
